questions.text: A 2-year-old male appears with pellagra-like lesions and urine that contains amino acids. Out of the four siblings in the family, two are experiencing the same symptoms while two siblings, and the parents remain unaffected. The most likely conclusion is:
questions.solution:
Hartnup disease is an autosomal recessive disorder resulting in impaired functioning of transport protein in intestines and kidneys. This results in wasting of neutral amino acids which manifests as pellagra like clinical symptoms.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 298.

questions.text: Which of the following can be determined using a dried blood drop from an infant?
questions.solution:
Dried blood drop of an infant can be used to know inborn errors of metabolism with the help of tandem mass spectrometry.

Blood samples from infants can be screened using tandem mass spectrometry for the presence and quantities of amino acids, fatty acids, and other metabolites. A number of hereditary illnesses, including phenylketonuria, ethylmalonic encephalopathy, and glutaric acidemia type 1, can be diagnosed by abnormalities in metabolite levels.


 

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 645

questions.text: Pick the incorrect change with respect to cancers
questions.solution:
(1) Methylation of tumor suppressor genes, (2) Hypomethylation of oncogenes, and (3) Loss of heterozygosity  - all are commonly seen in cancer cells. 
Methylation of tumor suppressor genes leads to their underexpression and contributes to carcinogenesis
Hypomethylation of oncogenes leads to overexpression and contributes to proliferative drive in cancer cells.
Loss of heterozygosity too is commonly seen. 

Mutations in introns (4) is incorrect with respect to cancers.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 366.

questions.text: Which of the following given terms refers to the ability to methylate and acetylate a gene without changing the gene's actual content?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Epigenetics

The term Epigenetics means 'Epi'- above and 'genetics'- genes. Epigenetics is defined as the heritable changes in genetic expression without a change in the underlying DNA sequence.
The primary mechanisms of Epigenetics include



Option 2 : Translocation -  translocation: a transfer of a chromosomal segment to a new position, especially on a nonhomologous chromosome.

Option 3 : Inversion - a segment of DNA in the context of a chromosome that is reversed in orientation relative to a reference karyotype or genome.

Option 4 : Transduction - Transduction is the process by which foreign DNA is introduced into a cell by a virus or viral vector.

In all the other options the structure of chromosomes is changed which causes genetic alterations.


 

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 680,681

questions.text: Genetic alterations that do not change the DNA's sequence are referred to as epigenetic changes. The following can all identify epigenetic change, with the exception of:
questions.solution:
HPLC is used in the determination of plasma levels of drugs/metabolites. 
Its also used to separate, identify, and quantify each part of a mixture.
It's not used to identify epigenetic changes.

Reference: Lippincott's Illustrated Reviews, 5th edition, Page no 25.

questions.text: Which disease shown is in the karyotype?
questions.solution:
• The karyotype in the picture shows a partial deletion of chromosome 5p.
  • The Cri-du-chat syndrome is caused by a partial deletion of the short arm of chromosome 5.
  • Children that are affected suffer congenital cardiac problems, a cat-like cry, microcephaly, and mental impairment.


 

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 3075

questions.text: A 10-month-old boy who has a healthy weight is experiencing vomiting after eating fruit. He has only ever received breast milk. The physician suggests fructose intolerance as the cause. Which of the following enzymes could this child be lacking in?
questions.solution:
The symptoms of hereditary fructose intolerance occur at typically six months of age(since milk has lactose made of glucose and galactose but no fructose), following ingestion of fructose or sucrose(glucose+fructose), and include vomiting and hypoglycemia. This condition occurs due to a deficiency of the Aldolase B enzyme.

Reference: Lippincott's Illustrated Reviews, 5th edition, Page no 100.

questions.text: Determine the pedigree's inheritance pattern.
questions.solution:
The given inheritance pattern is X-linked recessive.
 
  • Only Males are affected - females are carriers as seen in the above pedigree suggesting X-linked recessive inheritance. 
  • A few well-identified clinical disorders like Hemophilia/ Color Blindness have X-linked recessive inheritance.
  • The Y chromosome is not homologous to the X, hence mutant X chromosome genes do not have matching Y chromosome alleles.
  • The male is said to be hemizygous for X-linked mutant genes as a result, and as a result, the male manifests these illnesses. 
  • Females are hemizygous - hence - act as carriers, and do not manifest the disease. 
The following table summarises identification points for various modes of inheritance: 
 




Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 640

questions.text: Which from the list given below does not undergo post-translational modification?
questions.solution:
Selenocysteine is not formed as a result of post-translational modification, but rather is directly introduced through co-translation into a developing polypeptide during translation.

Thus, selenocysteine is often referred to as the "21st amino acid."

But unlike the other 20 amino acids, selenocysteine's incorporation is controlled by a substantial and intricate genetic component for the peculiar tRNA that makes use of the STOP-signaling UGA anticodon.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 18.

questions.text: A five-year-old female child has odd coarse facial traits, an oversized head, hepatosplenomegaly, corneal clouding, a protruding abdomen, breathing problems caused by obstructive sleep apnea, and thickened heart valves. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Peculiar facial features, enlarged head, hepatosplenomegaly, corneal clouding, protuberant abdomen, breathing difficulty with obstructive sleep apnea, and cardiac valve thickening are suggestive of Mucopolysaccharidoses. 
  • Since the child is a female - it cannot be Hunter's disease since Hunter is inherited in an X-linked recessive manner. 
  • The likely diagnosis is Hurler's syndrome and it is characterized by a deficiency of alpha-L-iduronidase enzyme. 




Other options

Option 2 - Hunter's is also a MPS with similar features (coarse facial features, enlarged head, hepatosplenomegaly, protuberant abdomen, cardiac valve thickening etc ) but since its X-linked recessive - its seen only in Boys, not girls. Hunter also does NOT have corneal clouding. 

Option 3 -  Fragile X disorder - The most common inherited cause of intellectual disability and has features which include Long face, large ears, macroorchidism in males with developmental delay. It does not have coarse facial features or cardiac valve thickening. 

Option 4 - Tay Sachs occurs due to Hexosaminidase A deficiency and has neurodegeneration, developmental regression, hyperacuisis, cherry-red spot on macula but no organomegaly. 





Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 811,812

questions.text: A DNA's structure is displayed below. What ties two nitrogenous bases together?
questions.solution:
Nitrogenous bases are held together by hydrogen bonds.

Deoxyguanosine nucleotide and deoxycytidine nucleotide are joined by three hydrogen bonds created by hydrogen linked to electronegative N or O atoms, while the A-T pair is joined by two hydrogen links.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 397.

choices.text: Turner syndrome with the webbed neck is more likely to develop CVS defects than non-webbed neck
Coarctation of the aorta is more likely in non-webbed neck

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Turner's syndrome is correct?
questions.solution:
• Turner Syndrome with a Webbed neck is 3 times more likely to develop CVS abnormalities than a non-webbed neck.
  • The most common CVS defect in Turner's syndrome is the Bicuspid aortic valve followed by the Coarctation of the Aorta.
  • Turner syndrome is typically characterized by features such as short stature, webbed neck, and other physical abnormalities, but intelligence is usually normal. There may be some learning difficulties, but overall cognitive ability is not significantly impaired. 
  • Hence among options 1 and 3, 1 is better answer than option 3.

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 637,638

questions.text: What changes in a gene results from RNAi?
questions.solution:
RNA interference (RNAi) is a biological process in which RNA molecules inhibit gene expression or translation by neutralizing targeted mRNA molecules. This process is known as Knock down. 


Reference: Lippincott's Illustrated Reviews, 5th edition, Page no 459.

questions.text: Which of the following syndromes is not caused by uniparental disomy?
questions.solution:
• Prader Willi Syndrome - Hypotonia, feeding difficulties, Intellectual disability, hyperphagia, and obesity. Paternal deletion of chromosome 15 or uniparental disomy of maternal chromosome 15.
  • Angelman Syndrome - "Happy Puppets" - ataxia, seizures, developmental delay, frequent laughter. Maternal deletion of chromosome 15 or uniparental disomy of paternal chromosome 15
  • Russel Silver Syndrome - Characterized by Skeletal asymmetry in limbs, Small triangular forehead prominence, small chin, and incurved fifth finger (clinodactyly). One of the causes is maternal uniparental disomy 7, seen in 10% of cases.
  • Bloom Syndrome is not caused due to uniparental disomy but due to DNA repair defect. So, answer is 4


 

Reference:Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 676

questions.text: What is the specific site in gene research where CRE recombinase binds?
questions.solution:
The LoxP site is the particular location in gene research where the enzyme CRE recombinase interacts.
 
Fact based Q. 

Online Reference: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cre-Lox_recombination

questions.text: Which of the following syndromes is not associated with uniparental disomy?
questions.solution:
• Uniparental disomy is not related to bloom syndrome. Bloom syndrome is due to DNA repair defect. 
  • When both of a pair of chromosomes in a person with a normal number of chromosomes have been inherited from just one parent, the condition is known as uniparental disomy.
  • Uniparental disomy is linked to Angelman syndrome, Prader-Willi syndrome, and Russell-Silver syndrome.
  • Uniparental disomy and a genomic imprinting (chromosome 15) abnormality are the causes of the Prader-Willi and Angelman syndromes.
 

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 634
 Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 676

questions.text: When total cholesterol is 300 mg/dL, HDL is 25 mg/dL, and triglycerides are 150 mg/dL, what is the value of LDL?
questions.solution:
Total cholesterol=HDL+LDL+TG/5
Therefore LDL=Total cholesterol-HDL-TG/5
LDL=300-25-30
LDL=245mg/dl

Reference: Lippincott's Illustrated Reviews, 5th edition, Page no 179.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy complains of increasing muscle weakness. On examination, his calves are bulky and show muscle tightening. His serum creatine kinase levels are increasing with age. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The signs are indicative of Dystrophin deficiency causing Duchenne's Muscular dystrophy. Its other features include -

1. Progressive muscle weakness and wasting, beginning in the lower limbs.
2. Difficulty in ambulation due to leg weakness and contractures.
3. Abnormal gait and foot deformities, including contractures of the Achilles tendon and plantar fascia, toe walking, and hyperextension at the knees.
4. Low endurance, leading to fatigue and exhaustion early in physical activities.
5. Respiratory muscle weakness, leading to impaired pulmonary function.
6. Respiratory infections due to weak respiratory muscles.
7. Difficulty with fine eye movements
8. Cognitive deficits
9. Cardiomyopathy and progressive heart failure


 

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 589,590

questions.text: What is the phenomena whereby future generations run the danger of manifesting diseases at an earlier and more severe stage?
questions.solution:
Anticipation refers to the situation whereby future generations run the danger of manifesting  diseases at an earlier and more severe stage. It is also known as Sherman's paradox. 

It is commonly seen in trinucleotide repeat disorders such has Huntington's disease- CAG repeats and Myotonic dystrophy-CTG repeats. 

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathology,10th edition, page no 145.

Maternal meiotic Nondisjunction of Chr 21 is cause of Down’s syndrome in 95% of cases. Downs is the most common trisomy.

Option 3 – Robertsonian translocation and Option 4 – mosaicism are also  included in genetic basis of trisomy 21.

questions.solution:
Blood group antigens and histocompatibility are two such examples showing codominant inheritance.

choices.text: It codes for more than 20% of respiratory chain enzymes are coded
One set is inherited from both maternal and paternal chromosomes each
It is less prone to mutations than human DNA

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct about mitochondrial DNA?
questions.solution:
Mitochondrial DNA is much more likely to accumulate mutations compared to nuclear DNA.
It encodes for 20% of the enzymes found in the respiratory chain and is transmitted solely
via the mother's egg. Its size is smaller than that of the nuclear genome, measuring
16 kilobase pairs. It also has a high mutation rate (5-10 times that of nuclear DNA). 

Hence, amongst the given options - only option (1) is correct.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathology,10th edition, Page no 15.

questions.text: In which of these inheritance patterns given below are males more commonly affected than females?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: X-linked recessive

Males are more commonly affected than females in diseases which have X-linked recessive inheritance.
 
  • In X-linked recessive inheritance, the gene responsible for the disorder is located on the X chromosome.
  • Since, males have one X chromosome and females have two X chromosomes, the presence of a single copy of the mutated gene on the X chromosome in males is sufficient to cause the disorder.
  • In contrast, females need to have two copies of the mutated gene (one on each X chromosome) to be affected.
  • Since males have only one X chromosome, they have a higher chance of inheriting and expressing X-linked recessive disorders.
  • Females, on the other hand, have a second X chromosome that can act as a "backup" and may carry a normal copy of the gene, reducing the likelihood of exhibiting the disorder.
Examples of X-Linked Recessive diseases are
 
  1. Hemophilia A
  2. Hemophilia B (Christmas disease)
  3. Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD)
  4. Becker muscular dystrophy (BMD)
  5. X-linked agammaglobulinemia (XLA)
  6. Fragile X syndrome
  7. Lesch-Nyhan syndrome
  8. Hunter syndrome (Mucopolysaccharidosis II)
 

Reference - Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 640

questions.text: In a surgical intensive care unit, restriction fragment length polymorphism (RFLP) was used to identify five different staphylococci species. In which of the following situations do restriction enzymes act?
questions.solution:
Restriction enzymes recognize palindromic sequences. In this case, “GATTAC” on one strand is complemented by “CATTAG” on the opposite strand, forming a palindromic sequence that is recognized and cut by certain restriction enzymes.

Reference: Lippincott' Illustrated Reviews, 5th edition, Page no 465.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about ataxia telangiectasia?
questions.solution:
• Ataxia telegiectasia is an autosomal recessive condition that cause a rise in AFP.
  • 2. ATM gene on chromosome 13: This is incorrect. The ATM gene is located on chromosome 11, not 13.
  • 3. Autosomal dominant: Ataxia Telangiectasia is inherited in an autosomal recessive manner, not dominant.

questions.text: Which one of the following is a gene editing tool?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: CRISPR

Genome editing tool derived from bacteria.
Consists of
  • A guide RNA (gRNA) which is complementary to target DNA sequence
  • Endonuclease (Cas9) which makes either single or double stranded break at the target site.
The resultant break either gets
  • Imperfectly repaired by non-homologous end joining or
  • A donor DNA sequence gets added to fill the gap using homology-directed repair.


Reference: Lippincott' Illustrated Reviews, 5th edition, Page no 469.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man goes for a routine examination and finds to have an early diastolic murmur ( family pedigree mentioned ). Name the pattern of inheritance of the disease in this patient.
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: AD
If we study the following pedigree.
  • All 3 successive generations are affected which suggests Dominant disease.
  • Both male and female offspring are affected suggesting Autosomal inheritance
  • Male to male transmission is also present thus it cannot be an X-linked disease.
An autosomal dominant disease presenting with an early diastolic murmur in a young individual is most likely to be Aortic regurgitation.
The following table summarises identification points for various modes of inheritance:

questions.text: The karyogram below demonstrates a chromosomal defect. Location of the chromosome where the mutation has occurred is
questions.solution:
• Chromosome 13 is normally acrocentric, but in the given image - the arrow is pointed at the centromere located at the center of the chromosome showing a metacentric translocation defect. Hence, option(2) is the correct answer, not option(1).
  • Classification of chromosomes Depending on the position of the centromere, chromosomes are classified as—
  1. Metacentric: Both p and q are of equal size (p = q).
  2. Submetacentric: The q arm is slightly longer than the p arm (p < q).
  3. Acrocentric: The p arm is very small compared to the q arm (p <<< q).
  4. Telocentric: The p arm is completely absent. This type does not exist in humans.

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 631

questions.text: Which is a biomarker of alcoholic hepatitis?
questions.solution:
In alcoholic hepatitis, AST is typically elevated and often shows a higher level compared to ALT (Alanine Aminotransferase), usually with an AST/ALT ratio greater than 2:1.
This ratio is a hallmark of alcoholic liver disease.
 

While GGT (gamma-glutamyl transferase) and ALP (alkaline phosphatase) can also be elevated in liver disease, AST is the more specific biomarker for alcoholic liver injury.
LDH (lactate dehydrogenase) is less specific and can be elevated in various conditions.


Reference: Lippincott' Illustrated Reviews, 5th edition, Page no 251.

choices.text: Ultrasound showing streak ovaries and a small uterus
Ultrasound showing hepatomegaly and altered echo texture

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl is brought by her mother to the OPD. She worries about being shorter than her peers. Upon examination, the patient has webbed neck, shield-like chest, and ptosis on the right side. What would you expect to discover after evaluation?
questions.solution:
Girls and women are affected by the hereditary condition known as Turner syndrome.
  • Turner syndrome is brought on by an entirely or partially absent X chromosome.
  • Short stature, irregular periods, and lack of breast development are among the signs of Turner syndrome.
  • The majority of patients, who are often female, have streak ovaries, which can cause primary amenorrhea or premature ovarian failure. Usually, the ovaries initially develop correctly, but the egg cells die too soon, and the majority of the ovarian tissue deteriorates before delivery.
  • The majority of girls need hormone therapy to reach menarche and develop secondary sexual characteristics.
  • Although the ovaries will have streaks, the uterus, fallopian tubes, and vagina will all develop normally.

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 637,638

questions.text: DNA is changed in genomic imprinting by:
questions.solution:
Imprinting's biological basis is still not well understood. Gene expression is known to be influenced by DNA methylation, and imprinting is frequently linked to various DNA methylation patterns. Histone H4 deacetylation and methylation are other methods.

Reference: Lippincott' Illustrated Reviews, 5th edition, Page no 460.

questions.text: The picture of a patients karyotype is shown below. Which of the following features can be seen in this karyotype?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Gynaecomastia and long arms

The above karyotypic study is showing 2 X chromosomes and one Y chromosome. This 47 XXY karyotypic abnormality is known as Klinefelter syndrome.
 
  • It is the most common sex chromosome aneuploidy
  • It is the most common genetic cause of infertility in males
  • Clinical features –
  1. Tall
  2. Absence of facial and body hair
  3. Small penis and testis
  4. Crypto-orchidism
  5. Gynaecomastia
  6. Male breast cancer
  7. Low IQ
  8. Increased risk of extragonadal GCT
All the other options like short wended neck, polydactyly and flat occiput are seen in Down’s syndrome.



Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 638

questions.text: DNA estimation is possible using:
questions.solution:
DNA estimation by spectrophotometer is a laboratory technique used to determine the concentration and purity of a DNA sample.

It involves measuring the absorbance of the sample at different wavelengths and then calculating an approximate concentration.

This technique can also be used to assess the amount of contamination in a DNA sample and determine if it is suitable for further analysis.

Other options: -
  • Spirometer- measures lung volumes
  • pH meter- measures pH
  • Sphygmometer- measures BP 

Reference: Lippincott' Illustrated Reviews, 5th edition, Page no 14.

questions.text: Match the following with the correct option.
questions.solution:
Swyer Syndrome : 46 XY
Turner syndrome : 45 XO
MRKH (Mayer-Rokitansky-Küster-Hauser) : 46 XX
AIS ( Androgen Insensitivity syndrome) : 46 XY


Reference: Shaw’s textbook of Gyaecology Edition 17 th Page No 141-146

questions.text: When many codons correspond to the same amino acid, this occurrence is referred to as:
questions.solution:
Degeneracy is a feature of the genetic code where more than one 3-nucleotide sequence (called a codon) can code for the same amino acid in a protein. This is also referred to as synonymous codon usage.

The genetic code contains an inherent redundancy, meaning that multiple codons can be used to represent a single amino acid. This means that even if one codon is mutated, a different codon that codes for the same amino acid can be used instead.

This allows some degree of protection against the deleterious effects of certain single-codon mutations, improving the accuracy and reliability of the translated protein.

Reference: Lippincott' Illustrated Reviews, 5th edition, Page no 433.

questions.text: Which of the following abnormalities is not found in Down's syndrome?
questions.solution:
• Deletion of chromosome number 21 is not seen in Down's syndrome.
  • Most of Down's syndromes have trisomy 21, so their chromosome count is 47.
  • In some cases of Down syndrome, the extra chromosomal material derives from the presence of a robertsonian translocation of the long arm of chromosome 21 to another acrocentric chromosome (e.g., 22 or 14).
  • Approximately 1% of Down syndrome patients are mosaics. usually having a mixture of cells with 46 and 47 chromosomes.
 

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 635

questions.text: Why are CG islands in our DNA important?
questions.solution:
The cytosine nucleotide is followed by a guanine nucleotide at the CpG sites, also known as CG sites, in a linear sequence along the 5' 3' orientation of the DNA molecule.
CpG islands are genomic areas having a high frequency of CpG sites.

CpG dinucleotides' cytosines can be methylated to create 5-methylcytosines. A gene's expression can be altered by this methylation. 

Methylation results in silencing/decreasing the expression of the gene. 

Reference: Lippincott' Illustrated Reviews, 5th edition, Page no 460.

choices.text: No need to worry as there is no increased risk

questions.text: What advice will you provide to the couple to prevent a child from being born with Down syndrome when one of the parents has a balanced translocation between chromosomes 15 and 21?
questions.solution:
• Advice given to the couple to prevent a child being born with Down's syndrome is (1)prenatal diagnosis and advice abortion
  • If any of the two parents is a 'balanced translocation' carrier to another chromosome (usually 13, 14, 15, 22) then the recurrence risk is about 1 in 8.
  • In the question, balanced translocation is present in one of the parents who has a translocation between chromosome 15 and 21.
  • Prenatal diagnosis and abortion will prevent a child being born with Down's syndrome.

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 659-662

questions.text: What percentage of the total human genome is made up of coding DNA?
questions.solution:
Coding DNA makes 1-2% of the total DNA in human body. 

Reference: Lippincott' Illustrated Reviews, 5th edition, Page no 465.

questions.text: Which of the following is a true statement about trisomy 13?

Important Head and neck features of Trisomy 13(Patau syndrome):

  • Microphthalmia

  • Microcephaly

Note: While rocker bottom feet can be seen in Trisomy 13, however- microphthalmia/cleft lip and other head/neck abnormalities are more characteristic of Trisomy 13 while rocker bottom feet are more characteristic of Trisomy 18(Edward Syndrome). Hence, option (1) is a better answer than option (3)



 

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 638

questions.text: What results from cytosine methylation?
questions.solution:
Epigenetic mechanisms involved in cancer include methylation of specific cytosine bases in genes, resulting in silencing of certain genes. Post-translational modifications of histones, such as acetylation, methylation, phosphorylation and ubiquitination also affect gene expression.

remember acetylation - kind of activation and methylation is like deactivation.

questions.text: What determines the exact placement of a genomic loci?
questions.solution:
Exact location of a genetic loci is identified by Fluorescent in-situ hybridization (FISH).

FISH, which uses fluorescent rather than radioactively labeled probes, is a very sensitive technique for determining the exact location of a genetic loci.

This frequently places the gene on a given band or region of the chromosome.

questions.text: The following is not observed in cystic fibrosis:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Obstruction of sweat gland ducts

CYSTIC FIBROSIS à ONE OF THE MOST IMPORTANT TOPICS FREQUENTLY TESTED IN EXAMS:-
  • Autosomal Recessive inheritance
  • Defect in CFTR gene on chromosome 7 (  F508 )
  • Most common lethal genetic disease.
  • PATHOPHYSIOLOGY :- 
  • Normally CFTR encodes ATP gated chloride channel which is responsible for secretion of chloride ions in lungs and gastro intestinal tracts, and reabsorption of chloride ions in sweat glands.
  •  F508 deletion decreases secretion of chloride and water à Increase in intracellular chloride ions results in compensatory increase in sodium and water reabsorption à Thus thick mucus gets secreted in lungs and gastrointestinal tract. Increased sodium reabsorption leads to development of negative transepithelial potential difference.
  • DIAGNOSIS :-
  • Increased chloride ion concentration is Pilocarpine induced sweat test—Diagnostic
  • Increased Immunoreactive Trypsinogen in Newborn screening test
  • CLINICAL FEATURES :-
  • Recurrent Pulmonary Infections ( commonly by Staph aureus – children ; Pseudomonas -- adult )
  • ABPA, Bronchiectasis , Chronic Bronchitis
  • Nasal polyps
  • Pancreatic Insufficiency, Malabsorption , Steatorrhea , deficiency of fat soluble vitamins
  • INFERTILITY – MALES à Due to ABSENCE OF VAS DEFERENS ; FEMALES --. THICK CERVICAL MUCUS [ VV IMP –FREQUENTLY TESTED ]
  • TREATMENT :-
  • Multifactorial
  • Chest physiotherapy
  • Aerosolized Dornase Alfa—inhalation route
  • Pancreatic Enzyme Replacement Therapy
  • Combination of LUMACAFTOR OR TEZACAFTOR ( corrects misfolded proteins ) with IVACAFTOR ( opens chloride channels )

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 392,393

questions.text: A light microscope can be used to see chromosomes with a resolution of ____?
questions.solution:
Chromosomes are visualized through a light microscope with resolution of 5 mb.

This analysis is called Karyotype analysis.

It helps to detect both numerical and structural chromosomal aberrations.

Overall resolution in this procedure is 5 Mega bases (mb).

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathology,10th edition, Page no 164.

questions.text: What is the term for differentiating the expression of a gene based on the parent of origin?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Genomic imprinting
 
  • MOSAICISM – Presence of genetically distinct cell lines in the same individual
(Example – McCune Albright syndrome )
  • ANTICIPATION – Increased severity or earlier onset of disease in succeeding generations ( Example – Trinucleotide Repeat disorders )
  • NONPENETRANCE- It means that not all individuals with the disease shows the disease due to incomplete or non penetrance.

GENOMIC IMPRINTING :-
  • In this one gene copy is silenced by methylation while the other copy is expressed based on parent of origin.
  • Examples :- PRADER WILLI SYNDROME , ANGELMAN SYNDROME
 


[TRICK –
PRADER WILLI SYNDROME – PAPA KA BETA- PATERNAL GENE DELETED -Spoiled brat—only eats thus obese
ANGELMAN SYNDROME – ANGEL- MEANS MOTHER- MATERNAL GENE DELETED ]



Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 634

questions.text: What is the objective of a real-time polymerase chain reaction?
questions.solution:
Real time polymerase chain reaction is done for monitoring amplification of target nucleic acid.

A quantitative polymerase chain reaction (qPCR), also known as real-time polymerase chain reaction, is a molecular biology laboratory technique that uses the polymerase chain reaction (PCR) to amplify and simultaneously quantify the targeted DNA molecule.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 66.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about Noonan syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Abnormal Karyotype

The karyotype in Noonan syndrome is typically normal, 46,XX in females and 46,XY in males. Noonan syndrome is not caused by a chromosomal abnormality but by mutations in specific genes involved in the RAS-MAPK signaling pathway, most commonly in the PTPN11 gene



A few points to remember about NOONAN SYNDROME:-
  • Autosomal Dominant condition
  • Found in boys or girls with normal karyotype
  • Clinical Features include :-

-Short stature
-Webbed neck
-Low posterior hairline
-Congenital Heart Defects – Pulmonary stenosis, HOCM, ASD
-Delayed puberty in girls
-Cryptorchidism in boys




 

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 398

questions.text: How does one identify the exact location of a genetic loci is?
questions.solution:
Amongst the given options - Fluorescent in-situ hybridization (FISH) can help in identifying the exact location of genetic loci.

Fluorescent in-situ hybridization (FISH) is a molecular cytogenetic technique that is used to detect and locate the presence or absence of specific DNA sequences on chromosomes. It uses fluorescent probes that attach to very specific regions of DNA, allowing for the visualization of the exact location or loci of specific genes on a chromosome.

FISH can be used to detect genetic rearrangements associated with diseases, chromosomal abnormalities, and even the presence of specific genes in a sample. 

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathology,10th edition, Page no 165.

questions.text: What is a possible cause of the darkening of urine after standing?
questions.solution:
The correct Option is 1: Alkaptonuria

 

HOMOGENTISATE OXIDASE – This enzyme helps in the conversion of Homogentisic Acid to Maleylacetoacetic acid.
ALKAPTONURIA –
  • Congenial deficiency of the Homogentisate oxidase enzyme leads to the accumulation of pigment-forming homogentisic acid which accumulates in the tissues.
  • Autosomal Recessive condition
  • Benign condition
  • Bluish black coloration of connective tissue, ear cartilage, sclera, synovium deposits (Ochronosis )
  • Urine turns black on standing because of prolonged exposure to air
  • Also causes debilitating arthralgias as homogentisic acid is toxic to cartilages.
  • TREATMENT – Nitisinone; Supplementation of vitamin c

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 700,701

questions.text: For which of these is real time polymerase chain reaction done?
questions.solution:
A real-time polymerase chain reaction (real-time PCR, or qPCR) is a laboratory technique of molecular biology based on the polymerase chain reaction (PCR). It monitors the amplification of a targeted DNA molecule during the PCR (i.e., in real time), not at its end, as in conventional PCR. 

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 66.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about phenylketonuria is false?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is option (3) Excess Melanin

Phenylketonuria is characterised by the absence of enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase. This results in increase in levels of phenyalanine (hence, option 2 is true) and decrease in levels of tyrosine (hence, option 1 is true) - the product of phenylalanine conversion. Lack of tyrosine causes lack of melanin since tyrosine is a precursor of melanin (not excess melanin as given in option 3). Hence, option 3 is the false statement. 
PKU is inherited in an autosomal recessive manner. (hence, option 4 is correct)



PHENYLKETONURIA:
  • Deficiency of phenylalanine hydroxylase enzyme.
  • Increase in Phenylalanine which in turn leads to increase in passage of phenylalanine through urine
  • Autosomal recessive inheritance.
  • Lack of Phenylalanine to leads to low tyrosine and hence, low thyroxine/ low melanin(which would lead to hypopigmentation) and low dopamine. 
  • Excess of phenylalanine gets converted into phenyllactate/phenylpyruvate/acetate which are toxic to brain causing clinical features like microcephaly and intellectual disability. 
  • Urine has musty odour due to excretion and presence of phenylalanine and its metabolites (phenylacetate in particular) 
  • Treatment includes - Avoid artificial sweetener aspartate; Decreased phenylalanine and Increased tyrosine in diet. 
 

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 695

questions.text: What does the division of a chromosome perpendicular to the normal axis of division lead to?
questions.solution:
Isochromosomes show loss of one arm with duplication of other due to perpendicular rather than horizonta separation of chromosomes. 

Most common isochromosome encountered is 2 q arms of X chromosome which is seen in ~ 15% patients of Turner's syndrome. 



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathology,10th edition, Page no 166.

questions.text: Given below is a pedigree chart, What is the inheritance pattern seen?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Mitochondrial inheritance

From the given pedigree we can interpret that in every generation the disease is only getting transmitted from a diseased female to her offspring. The disease is not getting transmitted from a diseased male to his offspring. Therefore, this pedigree describes Mitochondrial inheritance. 

The following table summarises identification points for various modes of inheritance: 




 

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 640

questions.text: Which of these is absent from the Klenow fragment's activity?
questions.solution:
The Klenow fragment of DNA polymerase is used for random primer labelling because it lacks a 5'-> 3' exonuclease activity. This is prepared by cleavage of DNA polymerase with subtilisin, giving a large enzyme fragment which has no 5' - 3' exonuclease activity, but still acts as 5'- 3 'polymerase.

Reference: Lippincott' Illustrated Reviews, 5th edition, Page no 402.

questions.text: The most common tumour associated with Neurofibromatosis-I (NF-1) in a child is-
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Juvenile Myelomonocytic Leukemia (JMML) 
  • Children with NF-1 have a higher incidence of JMML compared to other leukemias, such as Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ALL) or Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML).
  • While other malignancies may also be seen in NF-1 patients, JMML is the one most commonly associated with the condition.



[Trick to remember –
VON RECKLINGHAUSEN - 17 letters à chromosome 17 à NF1
NF2 à Chromosome 22 ]


 

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 601,576,577
Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 522.5

questions.text: Which of the following methods has RNA as its foundation?
questions.solution:
PCR facilitates the expansion and study of DNA extracted from single cells, hair follicles, or spermatozoa and thus has plenty of utilization in forensic medicine. Apart from that, it is also used to detect hidden viruses, diagnose fetal genetic issues, identify gene polymorphisms, confirm tissue types of transplants and analyze the evolution via retroviral reverse transcriptase-derived c DNA copies of mRNA (RT-PCR method).

Reference: Lippincott' Illustrated Reviews, 5th edition, Page no 479.

questions.text: Which of the following congenital heart conditions is most frequently linked to Down syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Atrioventricular Septal Defect (AVSD)

DOWN SYNDROME :- ( VV IMP- FREQUENTLY TESTED )
  • Trisomy 21
  • Most common viable chromosomal disorder and most common cause of genetic intellectual disability
  • PATHOPHYSIOLOGY :- meiotic nondisjunction with advanced maternal age
  • CLINICAL FEATURES :-
-Intellectual Disability
-Flat facies
-Prominent epicanthic folds present
-Single palmar crease
-Gap between 1st and 2nd toes in foot
-Brushfield spots on iris
-Increased risk of umbilical hernia
 
  • SOME COMMON ASSOCIATED DISEASES :-
-Hirschsprung Disease
-Duodenal atresia
-Congenital Heart disease – ENDOCARDIAL CUSHION DEFECT – ATRIOVENTRICULAR SEPTAL DEFECT
-Early onset Alzheimer Disease—Associated with amyloid precursor protein
-Increased risk of AML/ALL
 
  • INVESTIGATIONS :-
-FIRST TRIEMESTER USG – Increased Nuchal Translucency, Hypoplastic Nasal Bone
-Increased HCG
-Increased Inhibin
[TRICK TO REMEMBER :- 5A
-Advanced maternal age
-Atresia of duodenum
-Atrioventricular septal defect
-Alzheimer disease
-AML/ALL ]


 

Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 635-637

questions.text: What one of the following is not required to have a 5' capping?
questions.solution:
Capping is a process which protects 5' end of mRNA and polyadenylation protects 3' end against the action of exonucleases. 

mRNA, snRNA and siRNA undergo this process but tRNA and rRNA are relatively stable. Hence, they do not undergo capping at the 5' end. 

Reference: Lippincott' Illustrated Reviews, 5th edition, Page no 425.

questions.text: What alteration of the cytosine residues at CpG islands in DNA does not favour permissive euchromatin?
questions.solution:
Methylation causes inactivation of DNA and inhibits the formation of transcriptionally active euchromatin. 

It is an example of epigenetic modification. Examples include

1. Methylation of cytosine residues in CpG islands
2. Modification of histones by acetylation or methylation
3. Changes in high order chromatin structure. 

Reference: Lippincott' Illustrated Reviews, 5th edition, Page no 460.

questions.text: What is the phenomenon shown below?
questions.solution:
Complementation is a process in genetics where two strains of an organism with different homozygous recessive mutations that produce the same mutant phenotype, such as a change in wing structure in flies, are mated or crossed and the offspring has a wild-type phenotype. The blue-white assay is a technique used to screen for and detect gene uptake during genetic engineering based on the principle of alpha-complementation of the beta-galactosidase gene. A defective galactosidase gene product activity is complemented by a similarly defective gene product from a plasmid, which together become active. This can be used to determine a successful gene uptake as it disrupts the plasmid gene product and complementation cannot occur, resulting in white colonies and an unsuccessful gene insertion will result in blue colonies.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 445.

questions.text: What is the best investigation for metabolic disorders?
questions.solution:
Tandem mass spectrometry can be used to screen blood samples from newborns for the presence and concentrations of amino acids, fatty acids, and other metabolites.

Abnormalities in metabolite levels can serve as diagnostic indicators for a variety of genetic disorders, such as phenylketonuria, ethylmalonic encephalopathy, and glutaric acidemia type 1.

Reference: Lippincott' Illustrated Reviews, 5th edition, Page no 270.

questions.text: Which enzyme deficiency results in Lesch-Nyhan syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT)

Lesch-Nyhan Syndrome is an X linked recessive disorder which occurs due to deficiency of the enzyme hypoxanthine guanine phosphoribosyl transferase ( HGPRT )
HGPRT is responsible for generation of purine nucleotides such as IMP/GMP from bases such as hypoxanthine/guanine via purine salvage pathway.
As a result, purines accumulate resulting in increased degradation and generation of uric acid leading to hyperuricemia.

Clinically manifests as-
  • Self mutilation
  • Aggression
  • Intellectual disability
  • Hyperuricemia
  • Gout
Remember- Partial deficiency of HGPRTase results in Kelley-Seegmiller syndrome.

Reference: Lippincott's Illustrated Reviews, 5th edition, Page no 301.

questions.text: Regarding DNA polymerase III, which of these is accurate?
questions.solution:
In prokaryotic DNA polymerase, DNA replication is a function of DNA polymerase 3.



Reference: Lippincott's Illustrated Reviews, 5th edition, Page no 406.

questions.text: What do chaperones help with?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Protein Folding

Chaperons are a type of heat shock protein which assist in protein folding.
Mechanism of Action
  • Bind to short sequences of hydrophobic amino acids of extended polypeptide.
  • Thereby, they effectively shield the new polypeptide being synthesized from aggregating providing them with an opportunity to form an appropriate secondary structure.
Improper functioning of chaperons results in protein misfolding diseases such as
  • Prion disease: Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease and bovine spongiform encephalopathy.
  • Alzheimer’s disease
  • Beta thalassemia
Reference: Lippincott's Illustrated Reviews, 5th edition, Page no 444.

questions.text: Which of the following methods is used to find variations in gene expression and DNA sequence?
questions.solution:
Answer, option 4:- Microarray

- **Microarray** is a technique used to analyze and compare gene expression levels and variations in DNA sequences across thousands of genes simultaneously. It is commonly used to detect changes in mRNA expression (gene expression profiling) and identify mutations or single-nucleotide polymorphisms (SNPs) in DNA.  

### Other Options:
1. **Northern Blot**: Used to detect RNA (mRNA) levels of a specific gene, indicating its expression.  
2. **Southern Blot**: Used to detect specific DNA sequences in a sample.  
3. **Western Blot**: Used to detect specific proteins in a sample.  

Reference: Lippincott's Illustrated Reviews, 5th edition, Page no 483.

questions.text: Gout is a disorder associated with:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Purine metabolism

Gout is a disorder of purine metabolism characterized by formation of excessive accumulation of catabolic products of purine metabolic pathway.
Divided into primary and secondary gout.
  • Primary Gout-
Biochemical defect is increased activity of the enzymes PRPP synthase and PRPP glutamylamidotransferase  which results in increased synthesis of purines and thereby increased breakdown.

Reference: Lippincott's Illustrated Reviews, 5th edition, Page no 301.

questions.text: Lesch-Nyhan syndrome is caused by which enzyme deficiency?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyltransferase (HGPRT)

Lesch-Nyhan Syndrome is an X linked recessive disorder which occurs due to deficiency of the enzyme hypoxanthine guanine phosphoribosyl transferase ( HGPRT )
HGPRT is responsible for generation of purine nucleotides such as IMP/GMP from bases such as hypoxanthine/guanine via purine salvage pathway.
As a result, purines accumulate resulting in increased degradation and generation of uric acid leading to hyperuricemia.

Clinically manifests as-
  • Self mutilation
  • Aggression
  • Intellectual disability
  • Hyperuricemia
  • Gout
Remember- Partial deficiency of HGPRTase results in Kelley-Seegmiller syndrome.

Reference: Lippincott's Illustrated Reviews, 5th edition, Page no 301.

questions.text: Which of the following methods is used to repair DNA in CRISPR-CAS 9?
questions.solution:
The primary method of gene repair by CRISPR-Cas9 is non homologous end joining (NHEJ) repair.

CRISPR  stands for Clustered regularly interspaced short palindromic repeats.

The genome-editing technique CRISPR-Cas-9 allows specific bacteria to access genetic material.

The transcription of CRISPRs results in an RNA sequence that directs Cas-9 to a sequence that causes cleavage.

An artificial guide-RNA used in gene editing binds to Cas-9 and is complementary to the DNA sequence of interest. Double-stranded DNA breaks, also known as Double-Stranded Breaks (DSBs), are brought about by Cas9.

Then, NHEJ repair and homologous repair are used to repair DCBs. The more important of the two pathways is NHEJ repair because eukaryotes have a relatively poor homologous repair efficiency.

Reference: Lippincott's Illustrated Reviews, 5th edition, Page no 413.

questions.text: The binding of mRNA with ribosomes in eukaryotes is guided by which of the following ?
questions.solution:
mRNA has poly-A tails at the 3' end and a 7-methylguanosine cap at the 5' end.
The ribosome is able to identify the site of attachment to the mRNA with the help of the 7-methylguanosine caps.
Following the ribosome's binding to the 5' end, it scans downstream until it comes across an AUG Codon (Start codon)
The polyadenylation sequence (Poly A tail), which is located at the 3' end, helps stabilise the mRNA, facilitates its escape from the nucleus, and aids in translation.
The length of the poly-A tails steadily shortens as the mRNA moves into the cytosol.
The tRNA molecule functions as adaptors for the conversion of the information contained in the mRNA's nucleotide sequence into particular amino acids.

Reference: Lippincott's Illustrated Reviews, 5th edition, Page no 457.

questions.text: Which of the following techniques makes use of RNA
questions.solution:
A laboratory method called reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) combines Reverse transcription of RNA into DNA and target-specific DNA amplification. It is mostly employed to calculate the quantity of a specific RNA. Southern blot method is used to identify a specific DNA segment throughout the entire genome. The northern blot technique is used to show specific RNA. A technique for DNA sequencing called Sanger sequencing relies on the selective incorporation of chain-terminating dideoxynucleotides by DNA polymerase during in vitro DNA replication.

Reference: Lippincott's Illustrated Reviews, 5th edition, Page no 483.

questions.text: Which of the following is caused by RNAi in a gene?
questions.solution:
Gene knockdown- is an experimental method that lowers the expression of one or more genes in an organism. A short DNA or RNA oligonucleotide having a sequence corresponding to either a gene or an mRNA transcript can be used , or genetic modification can also result in the reduction.
Gene knockout, is a genetic technique that renders one of an organism's genes inoperative. ("knocked out" of the organism).

KO can also refer to the organism that possesses a gene knockout or the gene that has been deleted
Gene knockin- A genetic engineering technique known as a gene knock-in (abbreviation: KI) in molecular cloning and biology involves the one-for-one replacement of DNA sequence information in a genetic locus or the insertion of sequence information not present in the locus.

Gene knock up- upregulate the levels of a given protein while retaining its cell-type-specific regulation.

Reference: Lippincott's Illustrated Reviews, 5th edition, Page no 459.

questions.text: Which of the following mRNA regions does miRNA attach to?
questions.solution:
Short non-coding RNAs called miRNAs (microRNAs) regulate post-transcriptional gene expression. They typically bind to the 3'-UTR (untranslated region) of their target mRNAs and suppress the synthesis of proteins by destabilizing the mRNA and silencing translation. 

Reference: Lippincott's Illustrated Reviews, 5th edition, Page no 459.

questions.text: Mention the % of Cytosine if the % of thymine residues in DNA is 28%.
questions.solution:
Chargaff's rule is important for understanding DNA structure, as it explains the relative amounts of the four major bases in DNA molecules. The ratio of purine to pyrimidine bases in the DNA molecule is always around 1, meaning that the number of guanine and adenine molecules will be around the same, while the ratio of thymine to cytosine molecules will also be around to 1. This is important for complementary base pairing, as the A and T bases will always be equal, as will the G and C bases. This allows the double stranded DNA molecule to form its characteristic double helix structure, with complementary base pairs fitting neatly together. The shape of the double helix is maintained by the different widths of the two grooves that surround it, referred to as the major and minor grooves, with the major groove providing easier access to the DNA sequence in the helix.

Applying this rule, if thymine is 28%, adenine is also 28%.

Therefore concentration of guanine and cytosine together = 100 - (2 × 28) = 44.

Since, guanine and cytosine concentrations are equal, G=C= 44/2= 22%.

Reference: Lippincott's Illustrated Reviews, 5th edition, Page no 397.

questions.text: What is the replacement required in place of amino acid to increase UV immersion of protein at 280 nm wavelength?
questions.solution:
Proteins absorb light at specific wavelengths, with certain amino acids responsible for the absorbance. Tyrosine and tryptophan contain aromatic rings, which cause a peak of absorbance at 280nm. By measuring how much light is absorbed at 280nm, we can estimate protein concentration. This is referred to as UV absorbance at 280nm, and is a common laboratory technique for measuring protein concentration.



Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 21.

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct order of steps in  polymerase chain reaction (PCR)?
questions.solution:
The process of polymerase chain reaction involves Denaturation, Annealing, Extension

A. Denaturation - Separation of DNA by melting through 94 C for 3 minutes.
- Converts double stranded DNA to single stranded DNA

B. Annealing - Hybridization of two oligonucleotides used as primers to the target DNA to form template-primer hybridization complex. 
-At 3’end at 54C for 45seconds

C. Extension - Elongation of DNA chain by nucleotide addition from the primers
- Using DNA polymerase as catalyst in the presence of Mg2+ ions - At 72 C for 2 mins

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 452.

questions.text: Identify the hair abnormalities using polarising light microscopy?
questions.solution:
The abnormality is Trichothiodystrophy characterized  by tiger tail banding under electron microscope. 

Trichothiodystrophy:
Autosomal recessive disorder
Due to defect in DNA repair
Defective DNA Nucleotide Excision Repair (NER)


Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 380.

questions.text:
Alternate splicing occurs in a gene with segments 1, 2, 3, 4, 5 and a primer with the letters w, x, y, and z. It produces two goods, A and B.
Which primers are used to yield product A?
questions.solution:
Product A includes segment 1,3,4 and 5 in its structure.

Seg 1- Needs to be transcribed, so W is essential
Seg 2- Doesn't need to be transcribed
Seg 3- Needs to be transcribed, so Y is essential
Seg 4- Requires promotor Z but not essential since promotor Y can continue the transcription as indicated by the arrow.

There, the answer is promotor W and Y.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 399.

questions.text: What is explained by the genetic code's wobble theory?
questions.solution:
Crick proposed the 'wobble hypothesis' to explain the degeneracy of the genetic code. Except for tryptophan and methionine, more than one codons direct the synthesis of one amino acid. There are 61 codons that synthesis amino acids,therefore, there must be 61 tRNAs each having different anticodons. But the total number of tRNAs is less than 61.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 405.

questions.text:
Which of the following is correct about mitochondrial DNA?
(i) Higher chances of mutations as compared to nuclear genome
(ii) Single stranded circular DNA
(iii) Mitochondrial codons are slightly different from nuclear DNA codons
(iv) Mitochondrial DNA codes for all the ETC complex proteins
(v) It has around 16000 base pairs
questions.solution:
Mitochondrial DNA is double stranded, circular and has about 16,569 base pairs.

Mutation rate is very high because of the absence of introns, protective histones and repair enzymes.

It codes for 13 ETC proteins and follows maternal inheritance.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 369.

questions.text: Which of the following DNA repair procedures is used in CRISPR/Cas9 gene knockdown technology
questions.solution:
CRISPR/Cas9 gene is a defence mechanism in bacteria against phages. It codes for the enzyme Endonuclease Cas 9. This enzyme is used in cleaving mutation sites in Human DNA (double stranded breaks). Hence it helps in eliminating the problematic gene and replace it with the desired gene known as non-homologous end joining.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 447.

questions.text: Which of the following techniques makes use of RNA?
questions.solution:
A laboratory method called reverse transcription polymerase chain reaction (RT-PCR) combines Reverse transcription of RNA into DNA and target-specific DNA amplification.
It is mostly employed to calculate the quantity of a specific RNA.
Southern blot method is used to identify a specific DNA segment throughout the entire genome.
The northern blot technique is used to show specific RNA.
A technique for DNA sequencing called Sanger sequencing relies on the selective incorporation of chain-terminating dideoxynucleotides by DNA polymerase during in vitro DNA replication.


Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 453.

questions.text: For which of the following is FISH performed
questions.solution:
Her2/neu is a membrane receptor that belongs to the human epidermal growth factor receptor family. Amplification/ over expression is associated with increased risk of breast cancer.
Her 2/neu is graded as :
Her 2/neu 0,1 —negative
Her 2/neu 2–Equivocal result - FISH test is required to finalise
Her 2/neu 3–positive.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathology, 10th edition, Page no 183.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about telomerase?
questions.solution:
Telomerase is not involved in DNA repair.

Telomerase:
  • It is a reverse transcriptase enzyme whose main role is to prevent end replication error. 
  • A RNA dependent DNA polymerase enzyme that aids in creating DNA from RNA.
  • Only observed in eukaryotes
  • It stops cellular aging.
Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 726.

questions.text: Methylation is involved in all except
questions.solution:
Methylation of DNA is known as Epigenetics: It will cause silencing of the genes or decreased expression of genes. Chromatic remodelling RNA splicing. DNA excision and repair is done by Nucleotide excision repair genes.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 698.

questions.text: What kind of defect is found in HNPCC?
questions.solution:
DNA mismatch repair (MMR) gene mutations in the germline are the primary cause of the prevalent inherited form of neoplasia known as hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC). Human exonuclease 1 is one of the proteins that MMR proteins have been shown to bind with (hEXO1).

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 380.

questions.text: Where is a mismatch repair defect seen?
questions.solution:
DNA mismatch repair (MMR) gene mutations in the germline are the primary cause of the prevalent inherited form of neoplasia known as hereditary nonpolyposis colorectal cancer (HNPCC). Human exonuclease 1 is one of the proteins that MMR proteins have been shown to bind with (hEXO1).

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 380.

questions.text: Methylation of DNA has nothing to do with:
questions.solution:
DNA Methylation is not related with capping.

Capping refers to the addition of a 7-methylguanylate cap to the 5' end of eukaryotic mRNA and is involved in RNA processing, stability, and translation initiation.

DNA Methylation plays a very important role in a number of key processes including
  • genomic imprinting
  • X-chromosome inactivation
  • Suppression of repetitive element transcription and transposition
  • when dysregulated, contributes to diseases like cancer
  • mismatch repair
  • chromatin remodelling
Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 698.

questions.text: Correct way to estimate viral load is:
questions.solution:
Viral load can be estimated by RT PCR.

This is done by taking a sample of known viral concentration (available commercially) and running a series of 10x dilutions on the same protocol and recording the resulted CT (cycle threshold) with each known level of viral load for that specific test, run in that particular way.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 453.

questions.text: How many different amino acids may possibly be coded by such a system, if  a 4 nucleotides sequence code for an amino acid instead of 3?
questions.solution:
If there would have been two nucleotides in each codon, the chance of their varied combination will be 4 raised to the power 2, i.e. 16, and three nucleotide in each codon means there will occur 4 raised to the power 3 , i.e. 64 codons are possible. According to the above calculation, if there occurs 4 nucleotides in a codon, tire chance of their varied combination will be 4 raised to power 4, i.e. 256.


Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 16.

questions.text: Why are there multiple codons for the same amino acid?
questions.solution:
Degeneracy is the redundancy of the genetic code, where more than one triplet codes one amino acid. Degeneracy means the coding of a particular amino acid by more than one codon. Since numerous distinct codons define the same amino acid, the genetic code degenerates. This allows for greater permutations and combinations to code for a particular amino acid.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 405.

questions.text: Which of the following polypeptides is produced by the translation of the m-RNA poly (A) tail?
questions.solution:
Poly A tail is translated into the polylysine tail as AAA is the codon for lysine amino acid. The poly-A tail makes the RNA molecule more stable and prevents its degradation. Additionally, the poly-A tail allows the mature messenger RNA molecule to be exported from the nucleus and translated into a protein by ribosomes in the cytoplasm.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 412.

questions.text: What is CAP in LAC operon an example of?
questions.solution:
CAP in LAC operon is an example of positive regulator. CAP-cAMP regulator is a positive regulator for Lac operon because its presence is required for gene expression. Operon = structural genes coding for enzymes of metabolic pathway + regulatory genes that determine their transcription.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 423.

questions.text: In a polymerase chain reaction, which of the following is not used?
questions.solution:
Dideoxyribonucleotides are not used in polymerase chain reaction. The key ingredients of a PCR reaction are Taq polymerase, primers, template DNA, and nucleotides (DNA building blocks).

Dideoxyribonucleotides are used in Sanger's sequencing.

questions.text: All of the following, with the exception of ______________ can be used to detect chromosomal mutations.
questions.solution:
Denaturing gradient gel electrophoresis (DGGE) is a technique used to detect mutations or variations in DNA sequences. It separates double-stranded DNA molecules based on their melting behavior, which is dependent on their nucleotide sequence. This technique is particularly useful in detecting point mutations, deletions, and insertions in PCR-amplified DNA fragments.
On the other hand, Single strand conformational polymorphism (SSCP), Dideoxynucleotide trial sequencing, and Agarose gel electrophoresis are also methods used to detect chromosomal mutations.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 68.

Nanotechnology has found tremendous application in the diagnosis of cancers because of all of the following advantages except

To be used as fluorescent probes in biological

questions.text: What of the following does not result in a point mutation?

questions.text: Test to differentiate the chromosome of normal and cancer cells:
questions.solution:
Test to differentiate the chromosome of normal and cancer cells is

The entire DNA specimen from the sample of interest is labeled in one color and the normal control DNA specimen is indicated by another color. questions.text: Pyrimidine nucleotides are synthesized in salvage pathway of Pyrimidine synthesis through:
questions.solution:
Correct option 3:Both pyrimidine bases and nucleosides 
  • Pyrimidine nucleotides are synthesized through the salvage pathway of pyrimidine synthesis via both pyrimidine bases and nucleosides.
  • The salvage pathway is an important pathway for the synthesis of nucleotides, as it allows the reuse of nucleobases and nucleosides that are generated during the degradation of RNA and DNA.
  • In the salvage pathway, the free pyrimidine bases and nucleosides are converted into the corresponding nucleotides through the addition of a phosphate group, which is derived from ATP.
  • The enzymes involved in the salvage pathway are specific for pyrimidine bases and nucleosides, and they differ from those involved in de novo pyrimidine synthesis.
  • This pathway is energetically favorable, as it requires less ATP than the de novo pathway.
Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 342.

questions.text: The template DNA strand has the following sequence: 5'-GATATC -3'. What RNA sequence will be produced?
questions.solution:
The correct option is 2.
  • The RNA sequence produced from the given DNA template strand is 5'-GAUAUC-3'.
  • This is because RNA is synthesized by complementary base pairing with the template DNA strand, using the rules of base pairing (A with U and G with C).
  • So, for the given DNA sequence 5'-GATATC-3', the RNA sequence produced would be 5'-GAUAUC-3', where T in DNA is replaced by U in RNA. 
Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 349.

questions.text: Which of the following approaches is best for evaluating a gene's function?
questions.solution:
Option 4, Transgenic animals, is the best approach for evaluating a gene's function.
  • Transgenic animals are genetically modified organisms that have a foreign gene inserted into their genome. This gene can be specifically chosen to study the function of a particular gene or protein.
  • By creating transgenic animals, researchers can study the effects of overexpressing or under expressing a gene, as well as the effects of mutations or deletions in the gene.
  • Transgenic animals are particularly useful for studying the function of genes in vivo, which means in a living organism.
  • This approach allows researchers to study the effects of gene expression in the context of a whole organism, rather than just in isolated cells or tissues.
  • In contrast, Southern blot and Northern blot are molecular biology techniques used to detect the presence and expression of specific DNA or RNA sequences, respectively. These techniques are useful for detecting the presence or absence of a particular gene or transcript, but they do not provide information about the gene's function.
  • Gene knockout animals, on the other hand, are animals that have had a specific gene intentionally deleted from their genome.
  • These animals are useful for studying the effects of the loss of a particular gene, but they do not allow researchers to study the effects of overexpression or mutations in the gene. 
Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd Edition, Page no 454.

questions.text: Which nitrogenous bases is absent in DNA?
questions.solution:

Adenine, guanine and cytosine are seen in both DNA and RNA.

questions.text: Which of the following explains the principle of X-Inactivation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Lyon's hypothesis 
  • According to Lyon’s hypothesis, the phenotypical influence of X chromosome in a female is same as that in male who has only a single chromosome.
  • This occurs due to the fact that one of the two X chromosomes in females gets inactivated in an early embryonic period.
  • This inactivation of X chromosome is random and once inactivated, it continues to stay so for the life of the cell as well as its descendants in the body.
  • The inactivated X chromosome is known as the Barr body.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathology, 10th edition, Page no 170.

questions.text: Lactic acidosis in thiamine shortage is caused by which of the following enzyme dysfunctions?
questions.solution:
Since thiamine pyrophosphate is a cofactor for the enzyme pyruvate dehydrogenase, which catalyzes the conversion of pyruvate to acetyl Co-A, thiamine shortage prevents pyruvate from being converted to acetyl Co-A. Therefore, lactate dehydrogenase converts extra pyruvate to lactate. This is responsible for lactic acidosis. 

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 163.

questions.text: Of the following reactions, which one doesn't require biotin as a cofactor?
questions.solution:
Gamma carboxylation of glutamate: This reaction  is catalyzed by the enzyme gamma-glutamyl carboxylase despite being carboxylase does not require biotin  but it requires vitamin k.

Acetyl Co-A to Malonyl Co-A: This reaction is catalyzed by acetyl-CoA carboxylase, which requires biotin as a cofactor.
 Propionyl Co-A to methyl malonyl Co-A: This reaction is catalyzed by propionyl-CoA carboxylase, which also requires biotin as a cofactor.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about folic acid?
questions.solution:
• Fortification of wheat products (flour) is done with folic acid in the USA but not in India.
  • In 1996, the United States Food and Drug Administration (FDA) published regulations requiring the addition of folic acid to enriched breads, cereals ,flours, corn meals, pastas, rice, and other grain products.

Other options
  • Folic acid is present in most green leafy (The word folate itself is derived from 'folium' meaning 'leafy' since it was present in leafy vegetables)
  • Neural tube defects are reduced if folic acid is taken peri-conception. Folate should be started atleast 1 month prior to conception. The dose is 0.4mg. 10X dose is required if the prior child had Neural tube defect. 

  • Methyl folate trap occurs when methionine synthase (MS) is defective or there is Vitamin B12 deficiency. This enzyme converts 5-methyl-THF (methyl folate) into tetrahydrofolate (THF), allowing folate to enter the active cycle. Without B12 or functional methionine synthase, folate remains "trapped" as 5-methyl-THF, leading to functional folate deficiency.

questions.solution:

Total goitre rate: Percentage of children aged 6-11 with palpable or visible goitre.
This is an indicator of iodine deficiency, which causes brain damage and mental retardation.

Classification of goitre—

Grade 0: no goiter is palpable or visible.
Grade 1: palpable goiter, not visible when neck is held in normal position.
Grade 2: a clearly swollen neck (also visible in normal position of the neck) that is consistent with a goiter on palpation.

Criteria for TGR endemicity is classified as mild (TGR 5–19.9%), moderate (TGR 20–29.9%), and severe (TGR > 30%).

questions.text: Which of the following improves iron absorption?
questions.solution:

questions.text: Which enzyme is responsible for regenerating vitamin K in its coenzyme form?
questions.solution:
The correct option is 4. Epoxide reductase.
Vitamin K is a fat-soluble vitamin that is essential for blood clotting and bone health. Vitamin K is converted to its active form, vitamin K hydroquinone, during the carboxylation of certain proteins involved in blood clotting. During this process, vitamin K hydroquinone is oxidized to vitamin K epoxide. In order to be reused, vitamin K epoxide must be reduced back to vitamin K hydroquinone. This reduction reaction is catalyzed by the enzyme epoxide reductase.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 533.

choices.text: Prolong use of antimicrobial leads to deficiency

questions.text: Which of the following statements about vitamin K is true?
questions.solution:
Vit K is a Fat soluble vitamin which is responsible for synthesis of Clotting factors 2,7,9,10. It is synthesized within the body by the gut flora. Antimicrobials can kill the good flora along with the bad bacteria and can their prolonged use can cause Vit K deficiency.

  • Anticoagulant:

    • False. Vitamin K is essential for the synthesis of clotting factors (e.g., Factors II, VII, IX, and X). It actually supports blood coagulation, not anticoagulation.

  • Prolong use of antimicrobial leads to deficiency:

    • True. Antimicrobials can disrupt gut bacteria, which produce vitamin K, leading to a deficiency over time.

  • Dietary allowance is 15-20 mg:

    • False. The recommended daily allowance (RDA) for vitamin K is much lower, typically 90-120 µg (micrograms) for adults, depending on age and gender.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 532.

questions.text: If the prevalence of follicular trachomatous inflammation (TF) in the population of children between the ages of 1 and 9 is greater than_______ mass azithromycin treatment is advised.

questions.solution:
Diarrhea, dermatitis (lesions on the neck), and a maize-rich diet - all point towards Niacin deficiency (option 1) also known as Pellagra.
It is caused by a lack of dietary niacin or its precursor, the amino acid tryptophan. A maize (corn) diet is one possible cause of pellagra, due to its low tryptophan content and hence, low conversion to niacin in the body causing niacin deficiency and symptoms of Pellagra. 




Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 528.

choices.text: Both Indian reference man and woman require 1gm/kg protein per day
Both Indian reference man and woman require 20-30 gm fat per day
Both Indian reference man and woman are in the age group of 25-35 years
Both Indian reference man and woman are recommended 2 hours of sitting & moving around

questions.text: Which of these is true about Indian reference man and woman?
questions.solution:
Option 1 is correct: Both Indian reference man and woman require 1 gm/kg protein per day.
  • The ICMR recommends that both Indian reference man and woman require a daily protein intake of 1 gm/kg of body weight.
  • This means that a man weighing 60 kg would require 60 gm of protein per day, and a woman weighing 55 kg would require 55 gm of protein per day. 
  • Option 2 is incorrect because the ICMR does not provide a specific recommendation for the daily fat intake of the Indian reference man and woman. However, it is recommended that the diet should contain 20-30% of total calories from fat.
  • Option 3 is incorrect because the ICMR defines the Indian reference man and woman as healthy individuals between the ages of 19 and 39 years, not specifically in the age group of 25-35 years.
  • Option 4 is incorrect because the ICMR does not provide a specific recommendation for the duration of sitting and moving around for the Indian reference man and woman. However, it is recommended that individuals should engage in at least 30 minutes of moderate-intensity physical activity on most days of the week.
  • A reference man: is
    • Between 19 and 39 years of age
    • Weighs 65 kg with a
    • Height of 1.77 m and
    • BMI of 20.75 and is
    • Free from disease and physically fit for active work.
    • On each working day, he is engaged in 8 hours of occupation which usually involves moderate activity.
    • While not at work, he spends 8 hours in bed, 4–6 hours in sitting and moving about, 2 hours in walking, and in active recreation or household duties.

    A reference woman: is
    • Between 19 and 39 years of age
    • Not pregnant,
    • Not-lactating, and
    • Weighs 55 kg with a
    • Height of 1.62 m and a
    • BMI of 20.95, is
    • Free from disease and physically fit for active work.
    • On each working day, she is engaged in 8 hours of occupation which usually involves moderate activity.
    • While not at work, she spends 8 hours in bed, 4–6 hours in sitting and moving about, 2 hours in walking, and in active recreation or household duties.

    2020 recommendation the RDA for protein is 0.83g/kg/day instead of 1g/kg/day (RDA 2010) and the EAR is 0.66 g/kg/day (ICMR-NIN 2020).

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 747.

questions.text: Vitamin b12 is richest in
questions.solution:
Vitamin B12 belongs to the B family of vitamins. It helps to regulate the nervous system and plays a major role in the synthesis of DNA and the production of red blood cells. It also helps to convert food into energy.

 

The most common sources of Vitamin B12 are animal-based foods such as eggs, yogurt, milk, fish, and meat products. Vegans or vegetarians may need to consume fortified foods or take a supplemental to obtain the needed quantities. Supplements are sometimes derived from microorganisms, so vegans can look for these. However, not all fortified foods are vegan, so it is important to check the label. Vitamin B12 can also be taken as an injection or topical cream.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 536.

questions.text: What vitamin is lacking if patient presents with the following?
questions.solution:
The image shows Casal necklace seen in Niacin deficieny. Vitamin B3 (also known as niacin or nicotinic acid) is an essential nutrient involved in hundreds of biochemical reactions in the body. Deficiency of this vitamin can lead to pellagra, a condition characterized by skin lesions, gastrointestinal disturbances, and mental disturbances. Symptoms of vitamin B3 deficiency can include inflamed and scaly skin in sun-exposed areas (pellagra rash), sore or inflamed tongue and mouth, mental confusion, diarrhea, headaches, anorexia and fatigue. Other possible signs of deficiency include poor circulation, depression, irritability, and a weakened immune system. If left untreated, severe deficiency can lead to seizures, coma, or even death.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 534.

questions.text: Lactic acidosis is caused by thiamine deficiencies. In this case, which enzyme activity is inhibited?
questions.solution:
Thiamine (Vitamin B1) acts as a coenzyme for various enzymes. Active form of thiamine is Thiamine Pyrophosphate (TPP).

Enzymes requiring TPP—

—Pyruvate Dehydrogenase

—Alpha ketoglutarate dehydrogenase 

—Branched Chain ketoacid dehydrogenase 

—Transketolase.
In thiamine deficiency, the activity of pyruvate dehydrogenase is inhibited, leading to the accumulation of pyruvate. Pyruvate is then converted to lactate by lactate dehydrogenase, leading to lactic acidosis.
Therefore, option 1, Pyruvate dehydrogenase, is the correct answer.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 163.

questions.text: Which of the following assertions concerning Korsakof syndrome is true?
questions.solution:
Korsakoff psychosis or Korsakoff syndrome is a long term/chronic manifestation of alcohol toxicity. It is characterised by anterograde amnesia and filling up holes in recent memory with made up facts (confabulation). It is due to the involvement of mamillary bodies and anterior thalamic nuclei.
Triad of GOA- Global confusion, Ophthalmoplegia and Ataxia is seen in Wernicke's syndrome.
Management include Thiamine supplementation and rehabilitation.

Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 534.
