questions.text: A 65-year-old patient who is bedridden is taking medication. The patient manifested the following skin lesion five days after beginning the medication, as indicated in the picture. It is because of-
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Deficiency of protein 'C'
 

  • Warfarin-induced skin necrosis is a rare but serious complication that can occur shortly after starting warfarin therapy. It is associated with a deficiency of protein C, an important natural anticoagulant protein.

    Mechanism of Warfarin-Induced Skin Necrosis:

  • Role of Protein C:

    • Protein C is a natural anticoagulant that inhibits clotting factors (especially factors V and VIII) in the coagulation cascade.
    • Warfarin initially inhibits the synthesis of vitamin K-dependent clotting factors (including factors II, VII, IX, X), which leads to a transient period of decreased anticoagulant proteins like protein C and protein S. This creates a temporary procoagulant state.

  • Timing and Pathophysiology:

    • Warfarin-induced skin necrosis typically occurs within the first few days to weeks of starting warfarin therapy, especially when it is initiated at higher doses without concurrent administration of heparin.
    • In individuals with an underlying deficiency of protein C (either inherited or acquired), this initial procoagulant effect can lead to microthrombi formation in small blood vessels, particularly in the skin.

  • Clinical Presentation:

    • Patients present with painful, erythematous plaques or patches that rapidly progress to areas of skin necrosis (blackening of the skin due to tissue death).
    • The most commonly affected areas include the breasts, thighs, abdomen, and buttocks.

  • Diagnosis and Management:

    • Diagnosis is clinical and based on the characteristic presentation of skin necrosis in a patient recently started on warfarin.
    • Management involves immediate cessation of warfarin therapy and administration of vitamin K to reverse its effects. Heparin or low-molecular-weight heparin may be used temporarily to bridge until vitamin K levels normalize.
    • Protein C concentrate or fresh frozen plasma (FFP) containing protein C can be administered to replace the deficient protein and restore anticoagulant balance.

  • Prevention:

    • To minimize the risk of warfarin-induced skin necrosis, especially in patients with known protein C deficiency, warfarin therapy should be initiated at lower doses and overlapped with heparin until adequate anticoagulation is achieved.

  • Long-Term Management:

    • Patients who experience warfarin-induced skin necrosis should be managed by a hematologist or thrombosis specialist. They may require alternative anticoagulation strategies, such as direct oral anticoagulants (DOACs), which do not affect protein C levels to the same extent.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, 8th edition, Page no 668.

questions.text:
Conversion of ferrous iron involves which of the following enzymes?
(Fe2+) to ferric iron (Fe3+)
questions.solution:
• The conversion of ferrous iron (Fe2+) to ferric iron (Fe3+) is an important step in iron metabolism.
  • Ferrireductase that causes  reduction of ferric iron to ferrous iron.
  • Ferroxidase is an enzyme that catalyzes the oxidation of ferrous iron to ferric iron, which is essential for the transport and storage of iron in the body.
  • Ferric iron is less toxic than ferrous iron and is more readily bound to transport proteins such as transferrin and ferritin. Ferricarboxylase is not involved in the conversion of ferrous iron to ferric iron. It is an enzyme that catalyzes the carboxylation of certain amino acids, which is important for the synthesis of coagulation factors in the liver. 
  • Ferrodehydogenase is not a known enzyme involved in iron metabolism.
Reference: Harper's Illustrated Biochemistry, 31st Edition, Page no 101.

questions.text: A patient who had a high-grade fever and impaired senses was taken to the emergency room. He was determined to have meningococcal meningitis. Which of the following is the most appropriate empirical therapy option?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Ceftriaxone

Ceftriaxone is the recommended first-line antibiotic for the empirical treatment of meningococcal meningitis. Ceftriaxone is a broad-spectrum antibiotic that is effective against Neisseria meningitidis and provides good coverage against other common bacteria causing meningitis.

  • It has excellent penetration into the central nervous system, making it an appropriate choice for treating meningitis.
  • Piperacillin-tazobactam (option 2) is not typically used as the first-line therapy for meningococcal meningitis. It has broader coverage against Gram-negative bacteria and anaerobes, but it is not as effective against Neisseria meningitidis.
  • Penicillin G (option 3) used to be the drug of choice for treating meningococcal meningitis, but resistance to penicillin has become increasingly common. Ceftriaxone is now preferred due to its broader spectrum and better efficacy.
  • Cotrimoxazole (option 4) is not a recommended first-line therapy for meningococcal meningitis. It may have some activity against Neisseria meningitidis, but other antibiotics like ceftriaxone are more effective and commonly used.




 

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition , Page no 1104.

questions.text: A woman brings her malnourished 3-year-old daughter to a remote clinic. She had a hemoglobin of 5 g/dL. questions.solution:

choices.text: Undiagnosed even after 1 week of thorough investigation

questions.text: Which of the following does not include the definition of "pyrexia of unknown origin"?
questions.solution:
The current definition of fever of unknown origin (FUO) does not include undiagnosed after one week of investigation. The criterion "diagnosis uncertain, after 1 week of evaluation" which was previously a part of the definition has been removed.


FUO is currently defined as:
  1. Fever >= 38.3OC (>101OF) on at least two occasions (Option 1)
  2. Duration of >= 3 weeks (Option 2)
  3. No known immunocompromised state (Option 4)
  4. Diagnosis is uncertain after thorough history taking, physical examination, and obligatory investigations.
 
  • Inflammation of Unknown Origin (IUO) is closely related to FUO. It has the same definition, except for the body temperature criterion.
  • IUO is characterized by elevated inflammatory parameters (such as CRP or ESR) on multiple occasions for at least three weeks in an immunocompetent patient with normal body temperature.
  • The causes and workups for IUO are similar to those for FUO.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 145.

questions.text: A young female presented with vaginal irritation and green frothy genital discharge. On examination, a strawberry vagina is visible. What will be the preferred drug?
questions.solution:
Metronidazole is used in treatment of Trichomonas vaginalis infection


Recommended Regimen
Metronidazole 2 g orally in a single dose
      OR
Tinidazole 2 g orally in a single dose

Alternative Regimen
Metronidazole 500 mg orally twice a day for 7 days

Students should remember some characteristic features of few genital tract infection
Microbial diseases of the reproductive system

Disease Pathogen Symptoms
Bacterial Diseases
Gonorrhea Neisseria gonorrhoeae Painful urination, discharge of pus in males, abnormal vaginal discharge in females
Nongonococcal urethritis (NGU) Chlamydia trachomatis or other bacteria, including Painful urination and watery discharge, Chronic abdominal pain in females
Syphilis Treponema pallidum Initial sore at sire of infection, later skin rashes and mild fever; final stages may be severe lesions, damage to cardiovascular and nervous systems.
Lympogranuloma venereum (LGV) Chlamydia trachomatis Swelling in lymph nodes in groin
Viral Diseases
Genital Herpes Herpes simplex virus type 2; HSV type 1 Painful vesicles in genital area
Genital warts Human papilloma viruses Warts in genital area
AIDS Human Immunodeficiency virus (HIV) loss of appetite, weight loss, persistent cough, attack on T cells (immunocompromised), easily prone to fungal and other bacterial pathogens as secondary opportunistic infections.
Fungal Disease
Candidiasis Candida albicans Severe vaginal itching, yeasty odor, yellow discharge
Protozoan Diseases
Trichomoniasis Trichomonas vaginalis Vaginal itching, greenish yellow discharge

questions.text:
A 26-year-old man from Bihar arrives with papules  which are hypopigmented and normal sensation over his face and the back of his neck.
A prolonged fever episode in childhood was documented while taking  history. What is the diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
Diagnosis of Post Kala-Azar Dermal Leishmaniasis (PKDL) is based on:
  • History of kala-azar in the past (1-5 years ago) or living in endemic area.
  • Presence of "juicy'' erythematous nodules on the central part of the face.
  • Hypopigmented macules on the central part of the trunk.
  • No nerve involvement
  • PKDL can appear weeks, months, or even years after successful treatment of visceral leishmaniasis, often occurring in endemic regions.
  • Diagnosis is typically made based on clinical examination and history of previous leishmaniasis infection, with possible confirmation through skin biopsies or serological test

Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 33.50

questions.text: Which medication is recommended for pseudomembranous enterocolitis

  • Clostridium difficile: pseudomembranous enterocolitis; mostly associated with the use of clindamycin, tetracyclines, aminoglycosides, ampicillin, etc. It is more common after colorectal surgery. The organism produces an enterotoxin which damages gut mucosa forming plaques; metronidazole and vancomycin are the drugs of choice

questions.text: Pick the Antibiotic that is characterized by time-dependent killing and post-antibiotic effect(PAE)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Clindamycin

β-lactams, glycopeptides and macrolides produce ‘time dependent killing’, i.e. antimicrobial action depends on the length of time the concentration remains above the MIC; division of daily dose improves the effect.

Drugs having TDK with post antibiotic effect: -
  • Clindamycin
  • Clarithromycin
  • Linezolid
  • Tetracyclines
  • Azoles
Killing Type Key Drugs Mechanism
Time-Dependent Killing - Beta-lactams (e.g., Penicillins, Cephalosporins 1st and 2nd gen), Vancomycin- Clindamycin - Effectiveness depends on time above MIC.
Concentration-Dependent Killing - Aminoglycosides- Daptomycin- 3rd & 4th Gen Cephalosporins , Azithromycin, Doxycycline - Effectiveness increases with higher drug concentration.
Both - Fluoroquinolones- Clarithromycin - Needs both time above MIC and high concentration for maximum effect.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 748.

questions.text:
The patient experienced discomfort and edoema at the same location where he had an RTA two years prior.
The features of an X-ray are as follows. What is the expected diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The given history along with radiographic appearance of button sequestrum in proximal tibia is diagnostic of chronic osteomyelitis. 
  • The patient had a previous road traffic accident (RTA) two years prior, which could have introduced bacteria into the bone. The X-ray shows a lytic lesion with sclerotic borders, which is a characteristic feature of chronic osteomyelitis.

questions.text: The WHO recommends that latent TB should be ruled out in all of the following circumstances, with the exception of which one
questions.solution:
LATENT TB INFECTION: 

State of persistent immune response to stimulation by Mycobacterium tuberculosis antigens without evidence of clinically manifested active TB. 
Latent TB should be ruled out before treatment with TNF-alpha inhibitors, in patients of silicosis and patients undergoing hemodialysis among the provided options. As these conditions can cause reactivation of TB. 


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1379.

questions.text:
A 12-year-old child complained of four hypopigmented areas on his left arm and back. Sensation was lost in the spots. Which of the following describes how this case should be treated?

Correct option is 3: {Rifampicin (450 mg) + Clofazimine (150 mg)} monthly and 50 mg/alt day and 50 mg dapsone daily

questions.text: A 30-year-old girl from a low socioeconomic class who lives in a hill station complains of amenorrhea, mild fever, loss of appetite, and frequent urination in addition to other symptoms including dysuria and hematuria. Her concerns are most likely due to:
questions.solution:

Most common site of infection of genital tuberculosis is the fallopian tubes ( spreads from lungs via hematogenous route ) and the pathological process leads to blockage of tubes. Its features include -
1. Dysuria
2. Urinary frequency
3. Urinary urgency
4. Urinalysis may show pyuria and bacteriuria

6. Weakness of stream
7. Genital ulcers

questions.text: What is the cause of Hydrops fetalis?
questions.solution:

questions.text: The cause of "Fever Blister" is
questions.solution:
Fever blisters are caused due to reactivation of latent HSV-1 virus
 
  • Oral lesions of the mouth such as fever blisters or cold sores are usually associated with recurring infection rather than with the first infection.
  • These skin lesions caused by Herpes simplex virus Type-1 (HSV-1) usually occur on the face, particularly the cheeks, chin, around the mouth, or on the forehead. On occasion, lesions may also appear on an infant's buttocks, commonly referred to as a 'napkin rash'.
  • Fever blisters or herpes febrilis is the most typical lesion and happens when the viral infection is reactivated due to elevated body temperature.




Reference: Jawetz, Melnick & Adelberg's Medical Microbiology, 27th edition, Page no 459, 463.

questions.text: Which of the following problems may result from persistent pelvic inflammation?
questions.solution:
• Pyometra, or pyometrium, is defined as the accumulation of pus in the uterine cavity resulting from interference with its natural drainage. 
  • The most common cause of pyometra is malignant diseases of genital tract and the consequences of their treatment (radiotherapy).
  • Other causes are benign tumors like leiomyoma, endometrial polyps, senile cervicitis, cervical occlusion after surgery, pelvic infections, and congenital cervical anomalies.



Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 342-345.

v. Too much tone causing birth to be restricted after birth - Hypertonia

questions.text:
A 40-year-old female with a history of fever, joint discomfort, and rash visited the OPD. NSAIDs had been recommended.
After a week, the patient's nose started to look reddish. This was caused by?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. Chikungunya

After using NSAIDs for one week, the patient developed a reddish discoloration across their nose, as shown in the image. It is known as Chik sign.
  • The mucocutaneous junction (lip, glans) is the most frequently affected region for fixed drug eruption, followed by the vaginal skin (glans). (Option 4)
  • Based on their medical history, which included chronic joint pain and rash, the most likely diagnosis was pigmentation brought on by Chikungunya. 
  • In cases of Chikungunya, the nose pigmentation is noticeable; this condition has not been noted in cases of any other viral exanthem.


Reference: Fitzpatrick's Dermatology, 9th edition, Page no 1369.

questions.text: What is the CDC regimen to treat chlamydia infection in pregnancy
questions.solution:
Correct option: 4. Azithromycin
 
  • Untreated chlamydial infection has been linked to problems during pregnancy, including preterm labor, premature rupture of membranes, and low birth weight.
  • The newborn may also become infected during delivery as the baby passes through the birth canal.
  • Exposed newborns can develop eye and lung infections.
  • CDC Regimen for Chlamydial Infection During Pregnancy Azithromycin 1 g orally in a single dose. Alternative Regimen Amoxicillin 500 mg orally 3 times/day for 7 days
  • Doxycycline and tetracycline are contraindicated in Pregnancy as it can cause nasal hypoplasia in fetus. 



Reference: Sexually Transmitted Infections Treatment Guidelines 2021, CDC (2021). URL: https://www.cdc.gov/std/treatment-guidelines/chlamydia.htm

questions.text: In a child who 2 months back experienced bloody diarrhoea with fever followed by swollen red and erythematosus joint now, there is an indication of the presence of:
questions.solution:

  • The given features are suggestive of shigella infection.
  • Shigella infection (shigellosis) can cause bloody diarrhea and fever.
  • It is also a well-known trigger for reactive arthritis, especially in individuals with a genetic predisposition (HLA-B27).

    In case of enteric fever following are some post infection complications
    • Guillain-Barry syndrome due to campylobacter
    • Reactive arthritis due to salmonella, shigella, yersinia and campylobacter.


Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 1508-1511

questions.text: Which of the following statements about H1N1 influenza is correct?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Pregnant woman with sore throat can be started immediately on oseltamivir without diagnostic testing under category B

Regarding H1N1 Influenza, a pregnant woman with a sore throat can be started immediately on oseltamivir without diagnostic testing under category B.

* Category A Patient Of H1N1 Influenza:
Patients with mild fever (less than 380 C) plus cough / sore throat with or without bodyache, headache, diarrhoea and vomitting will be categorized as Category-A. They do not require Oseltamivir and should be treated for the symptoms mentioned above. The patients should be monitored for their progress and reassessed at 24 to 48 hours by the doctor.

* Category B Patient of H1N1 Influenza:
In addition to all the signs and symptoms mentioned under Category-A, if the patient has high grade fever (Above 380 C) and severe sore throat, may require home isolation and Oseltamivir.
In addition to all the signs and symptoms mentioned under Category-A, individuals having one or more of the following high-risk conditions shall be treated with Oseltamivir:
Children with mild illness but with predisposing risk factors.
Pregnant women;
Persons aged 65 years or older;
Patients with lung diseases, heart disease, liver disease, Kidney disease, blood disorders, diabetes, neurological disorders, cancer and HIV/AIDS;
Patients on long term cortisone therapy.
No test for Influenza is required for Category-B (i) and (ii).
All patients of Category-B (i) and (ii) should confine themselves at home and avoid mixing with public and high risk members in the family.
Broad Spectrum antibiotics as per the Guideline for Community-acquired pneumonia (CAP) may be prescribed.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 853.
Online Reference: Guidelines on categorization of Influenza A H1N1 cases during screening for home isolation, testing treatment, and hospitalization (Revised on 05.10.09) https://mohfw.gov.in/sites/default/files/224678457.pdf

questions.text: Which of the following conditions does glucocorticoid use decrease mortality?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Severe typhoid
 
  • In critically ill patients with enteric fever, combining dexamethasone with chloramphenicol resulted in a significantly lower mortality rate than chloramphenicol alone.
 
  • In cerebral malaria, corticosteroids can be used to decrease swelling but can reduce the host immunity response towards the infection as well.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1295.

questions.text: What is the drug of choice to treat chlamydia infection in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. Erythromycin

Since Azithromycin and Amoxicillin are not in the option the other medicine that can be used to treat Chlamydia in pregnancy is Erythromycin.

  • Because of concerns regarding chlamydia persistence after exposure to penicillin-class antibiotics that has been demonstrated in animal and in vitro studies, amoxicillin is listed as an alternative therapy for C. trachomatis for pregnant women.
  • Erythromycin is no longer recommended because of the frequency of gastrointestinal side effects that can result in therapy nonadherence.
  • In addition, systematic reviews and meta-analyses have noted an association with macrolide antimicrobials, especially erythromycin, during pregnancy and adverse child outcomes, indicating cautious use in pregnancy.
  • Doxycycline and Tetracycline are contraindicated in pregnancy as they can cause nasal hypoplasia. 



Reference: Sexually Transmitted Infections Treatment Guidelines 2021, CDC (2021). URL: https://www.cdc.gov/std/treatment-guidelines/chlamydia.htm
Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 344.

questions.text:
A 10-year-old boy is diagnosed with myoclonus jerk, which affects his academic performance.
There is a history of fever and rash at the age of one year. The features mentioned above point to:
questions.solution:
• History of fever and rash at one year of age (probably measles) & current presentation at 10 year of age with myoclonic jerks indicate chronic complication seen in measles called Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE).
  • It is a progressive neurological disorder of children and young adults that affects the central nervous system (CNS).
  • It is a slow, but persistent, viral infection caused by  measles virus.
  • More common in regions with low vaccination rates.
  • Stages of SSPE- 
Stage 1: Gradual onset of behavioral changes, personality changes, memory loss, school difficulties, and irritability.

Stage 2: Development of myoclonus (involuntary jerking movements), seizures, and progressive intellectual decline.

Stage 3: Further neurological deterioration with worsening myoclonus, spasticity, and severe dementia.

Stage 4: End-stage disease characterized by a vegetative state, decerebrate rigidity, and eventually death.
Diagnosis- 
  • EEG: Periodic, high-voltage discharges (burst-suppression pattern).
  • CSF analysis: Elevated measles antibodies (oligoclonal bands or high titers of anti-measles IgG).
  • MRI: Brain shows signs of inflammation and demyelination.
  • Measles antibody titers: Significantly elevated in both the blood and cerebrospinal fluid.


Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 209,210

questions.text: Which of the following statements about severe malaria is not true?
questions.solution:
Hematocrit more than 15 is the incorrect statement.

Malaria with the severe form of Falciparum shows:

questions.text: Which of these causes non immune hydrops fetalis
questions.solution:
• Parvo virus B19 causes Non immune hydrops
  •  Hydrops fetalis is a serious condition characterized by abnormal accumulation of fluid in two or more fetal compartments, such as the abdominal cavity, pleural cavity, and skin.
  • Etiology: Common causes include Rh incompatibility, infections (like parvovirus B19 and toxoplasmosis), fetal anemia, cardiac defects, and chromosomal abnormalities.
  • Clinical Features: Signs may include fetal edema (swelling), polyhydramnios (excess amniotic fluid), and ultrasound findings such as thickened skin, ascites, or pleural effusion.

  • Diagnosis: Diagnosis is primarily through ultrasound imaging, which reveals the fluid accumulation



Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 360.

choices.text: Blood culture and CSF culture from shunt tap

questions.text:
Due to shunt malfunction, a 4-year-old child with hydrocephalus who has ventricular shunt had it changed.
The youngster now complains of irritation and lack of appetite that has lasted for three days with no other symptoms; the rectal temperature was 38.7 C. What will be the next step?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Blood culture and CSF culture from shunt tap
  • The child is complaining of irritation and lack of appetite, a recent history of changing shunt along with these symptoms is suggestive of shunt associated meningitis.
  • The next best step in this case will be taking blood culture and CSF sampling from shunt tap.
  • Shunt aspiration is preferable to a lumbar puncture as it allows better detection of microbes and avoids the need of a separate procedure reducing the risk of contamination.

Option 1 – Blood culture should be done on all cases of suspected meningitis but the diagnosis of meningitis is confirmed by CSF analysis obtained from shunt tap.

Option 3 – IV antibiotics are the mainstay of treatment but should be started after taking blood and CSF samples, this is not the best next step.

Option 4 – shunt patent studies are performed to determine whether shunt revision surgery is needed in the malfunctioned VP shunt. It is done using radionucleotide dyes.



Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 561-563,578

questions.text:

questions.text: When patients are being monitored daily, the tourniquet test is utilised for:
questions.solution:
• The tourniquet test (TT) is a physical examination technique that can identify and stratify dengue disease.
  • Infection with DENV may result in increased capillary permeability, a physiological state that the TT exploits by applying sustained pressure to these small vessels.
  • Positive tourniquet test with greater than 10 petechiae per one square inch.

questions.text: At 34 weeks of pregnancy, a woman experiences fluid leakage from her vaginum and meconium-colored liquor. The most likely cause amongst the following organisms:
questions.solution:
Listeria Monocytogenes

  • Listeriosis is a rare infection, but is about 20 times more common in pregnant women than in the general population.
  • Pregnant women account for 27% of all listerial infections which can cause mild illness in mothers, but can be devastating to the fetus, in some cases leading to severe disease or fetal death.
  • During the first trimester of pregnancy, listeriosis may cause miscarriage. As the pregnancy progresses to third trimester, the mother is more at risk.
  • Listeriosis can also lead to premature labor, the delivery of a low-birth-weight infant, or infant death
  • Listeria in newborns can be classified as early onset or late-onset infection. Meconium-stained amniotic fluid is common in newborns with early onset Listeria.
  • Respiratory difficulty is common, including a history of cyanotic episodes, rapid breathing, and grunting.
 



Reference: Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition, Page no 1196.
Online source https://emedicine.medscape.com/article/965841

choices.text: About 20-30% of CMV infections are symptomatic at birth
A triad of hearing loss, PDA and cataract is seen
Hearing loss can appear later in life in asymptomatic babies
Babies born to mothers who have IgG CMV are always 100% immune to the transplacental spread

questions.text: Which of the following statement about congenital CMV infection is correct?
questions.solution:
Correct asnwer is option(3).
 
  • 90% of neonates with congenital CMV infections are asymptomatic at birth and will not show any clinical symptoms. However, 10% of infected newborns present with symptoms. Hence, option 1 is incorrect.(10% of babies are symptomatic, not 20-30%)
  • Infants with symptomatic congenital CMV infections typically have a triad of Jaundice, Petechiae, and hepatosplenomegaly.  A triad of hearing loss, PDA, and cataracts is seen in congenital Rubella syndrome, not CMV.
  • The most frequent long-term complication of neonatal CMV infection is hearing loss (SNHL) - It is the most common cause of non-syndromic SNHL. Around 50% of newborns with congenital CMV infection go on to experience hearing loss in later infancy and early childhood. Hence, option 3 is correct.
  • CMV can also be transmitted from mother to fetus if the mother had a CMV infection in the past and was immune at the time of conception. This transmission can occur due to reinfection during pregnancy. Hence, option 4 is incorrect. 

Answer has been confirmed with Professors of both Microbiology and Pediatrics at AIIMS, Delhi. It's given wrong in many Qbanks.
 

Reference: Nelson textbook of Pediatrics 21st edition Page no 1719-1720

questions.text:
A 28-year-old woman has had asymptomatic dome-shaped, tiny lesions on her forehead for two months. Her 2-year-old daughter suffers from comparable lesions.
Which is the lesion's causative agent?
questions.solution:
• The pearly white papule lesions on the forehead are most likely Molluscum contagiosum, which is brought on by the poxvirus and has a history of being passed down to daughters:
  • Molluscum contagiosum (MC), often known as water warts, is a viral infection of the skin or mucous membranes that is brought on by the molluscum virus, a DNA poxvirus (MCV)
  • The lesions of molluscum contagiosum have a flesh-colored, dome-shaped, and pearly look. 
  • They are often 1-5 mm in diameter, with an umbilicated center.


Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 25.12, 25.13

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of protease inhibitors?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Inhibition of assembly of viral proteins

The action of protease inhibitors is to prevent the cleavage of viral polyprotein precursors into mature functional proteins which are necessary for replication.

questions.text: Which of the following should be monitored the most closely in a person with dengue hemorrhagic fever?
questions.solution:

questions.text: All of the following interventions are recommended to prevent mother to child transmission of HIV, except:
questions.solution:
Rest all are recommended measures to reduce mother to child transmission of HIV
The PMTCT Cascade
1. Utilization of Antenatal Care (ANC)
2. Receiving HIV pretest counseling
3. Acceptance of HIV test
4. Receiving HIV test results & post-test counseling
5. Use of ARV prophylaxis for mom and/or baby (For seropositive mom)
6. Use of Labor &Delivery services which include PMTCT interventions
7. Postnatal follow up of mom and baby with HIV test for exposed infant and timely linkage to treatment, care and support.

questions.text: Which of the following carbamazepine side effects are not idiosyncratic?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Blurred vision

Idiosyncratic reactions are adverse effects that cannot be explained by the known mechanisms of the drug, usually mediated by cytotoxic or immunologic effects triggered by the drug in an individual.

* Examples of idiosyncratic reactions by carbamazepine: -
  • DRESS
  • Skin rashes/SJS/TEN
  • Pseudolymphoma
  • Agranulocytosis, Aplastic anemia
  • Liver toxicity

questions.text: Which of the following areas of the brain is NOT connected with atrophy due to HIV infection?
questions.solution:
HIV dementia is characterized by 
  • Subcortical dementia, with white matter involvement,
  • Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy
  • Demyelination
Immunohistochemistry studies show that the virus is most densely located in the basal ganglia, subcortical regions, and frontal cortex.

Radiographic imaging reveals:
  • Cerebral atrophy and particularly
  • Prominent atrophy of the caudate region.
The cingulate gyrus is not usually involved. 



Reference: Saylor, Deanna et al. “HIV-associated neurocognitive disorder--pathogenesis and prospects for treatment.” Nature reviews. Neurology vol. 12,4 (2016): 234-48. doi:10.1038/nrneurol.2016.27. URL: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4937456/

questions.text: Contraindications to dilatation and curettage (D&C) include:
questions.solution:
PID
As D and C in a case of PID can lead to dissemination of infection, it is not recommended in those cases.
There is no indication of doing D and C in endometriosis and ectopic pregnancy but there are no contradictions either.

questions.text: How long should a child be quarantined after being told that they have bacterial meningitis in order to stop the spread of the disease?
questions.solution:
Bacterial meningitis (e.g., meningococcal, Hib) is contagious and can spread via respiratory droplets. After antibiotics are started, the child is however generally no longer contagious after 24 hours. Hence, a quarantine for 24 hours after antibiotics are started is sufficient.

Other options

  • This no need to wait for cultures to become negative (option 2) or for the full antibiotic course to be completed (option 3). 
  • Quarantine for only 12 hours after admission (option 4) is too short.

Hence, isolation precautions are recommended until 24 hours of effective antibiotic therapy is completed. 


Reference-Ghai Essential Pediatrics 9th Edition Page no 161

questions.text:
One month after commencing anti-epileptic medication, a 28-year-old patient with neurocysticercosis begins to have universal peeling of all skin surfaces apart from the palms and soles.
What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The clinical description provided above is typical of toxic epidermal necrolysis and includes a history of drug use (anticonvulsant) followed by confluent skin involvement (likely to be greater than 30%).
  • Lyell's syndrome, commonly known as toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN), is a rare, potentially fatal skin disorder that is typically brought on by a medication reaction. The condition leads to a separation between the upper epidermis and the lower dermis of the skin.



Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 119.13

questions.text: Choose the antibiotic that can be used in the treatment of fungal keratomycosis.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Silver sulfadiazine

Silver sulfadiazine is a broad-spectrum antibiotic which acts on gram positive and negative organisms and certain yeasts like C. Albicans. It has been found to be more effective than Miconazole in Ocular keratomycosis according to some trials.

* Mechanism of action – inhibits dihydropteroate synthase

Easy Trick to conclude answer, all other drugs are antibiotics used in bacterial infection, so they won't be the answer.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 757.

questions.text: One can observe Warthin Finkeldey cells in:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Measles
 
  • Warthin-Finkeldey cells are multinucleated giant cells that are characteristic histopathological findings in measles (also known as rubeola).
  • These cells are formed by the fusion of infected lymphocytes and epithelial cells. They are typically observed in the respiratory epithelium, particularly in the bronchi and bronchioles.

questions.text: Women with bacterial vaginosis are treated with which of the following drugs

questions.text: Which of the following types of oral candidiasis does not have a white patch?
questions.solution:
Chronic Erythematous (atrophic) candidiasis appears as a red, raw-looking lesion instead of a white patch seen in all other types.

Types of Oral Candidiasis
  Pseudomembranous:
Acute pseudomembranous candidiasis is a classic form of oral candidiasis, commonly referred to as thrush.
 Characterized by a coating or individual patches of the pseudomembranous white slough that can be easily wiped away to reveal erythematous, and sometimes minimally bleeding mucosa beneath.
Erythematous:
Erythematous (atrophic) candidiasis is where the condition appears as a red, raw-looking lesion.
Chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis:
Chronic candidal lesions on the skin, in the mouth, and on other mucous membranes (i.e. secondary oral candidiasis).
Hyperplastic:
This variant is also sometimes termed 'plaque-like candidiasis' or 'nodular candidiasis' or 'candidal leukoplakia'.
The most common appearance of hyperplastic candidiasis is a persistent white plaque that does not rub off.

Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 32.62

questions.text: Select the most effective treatment of severe malaria.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Artesunate

Artesunate (Artemisinin based combination therapy) is the best treatment for severe/complicated cases of Malaria.

Option 1: Doxycycline is the DOC in malaria prophylaxis if the duration of travel is <6 weeks and in treatment if ACT is not available.

Option 2: Primaquine kills hypnozoites and thus provides radical cure by preventing relapse.

Option 3: Chloroquine is used for treatment of uncomplicated malaria caused by P. Vivax, uncomplicated malaria in pregnancy and in case of ACT resistance

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 887.

questions.text: Cryoglobulinemia is associated with which of the following
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Hepatitis C
 
  • Cryoglobulinemia is a condition characterized by the presence of abnormal proteins called cryoglobulins in the blood. These proteins can precipitate and cause inflammation and damage in blood vessels, leading to various symptoms and complications.
  • The most common type of cryoglobulinemia, known as type II or mixed cryoglobulinemia, is strongly associated with chronic hepatitis C virus (HCV) infection.
  • It is estimated that approximately 80-90% of cases of mixed cryoglobulinemia are associated with HCV.
  • Ovarian cancer, diabetes, and leukemia are not typically associated with cryoglobulinemia. While cryoglobulinemia can be secondary to other underlying conditions or diseases, HCV infection is the most common and well-established association.

Some common extra-articular manifestations associated with Hepatitis C infection:






Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2604.

questions.text: A female who is sexually active presents with excessive, foamy, foul-smelling discharge as well as severe itching with exposed strawberry cervix in per speculum examination. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Trichomonas vaginalis infection
Foul smelling discharge with strawberry cervix points towards Trichomonas infection.
Trichomoniasis is a very common STD caused by infection with Trichomonas vaginalis (a protozoan parasite)
Women with it may notice-Itching, burning, redness or soreness of the genitals,discomfort when peeing; and
A clear, white, yellowish, or greenish vaginal discharge (i.e., thin discharge or increased volume) with a fishy smell.
Recommended Regimen for Trichomoniasis Among Women. Metronidazole 500 mg 2 times/day for 7 days.
Alternative Regimen for Women and Men- Tinidazole 2 g orally in a single dose.

Strawberry cervix


Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 330, 365.

questions.text: Which is the earliest clinical sign for congenital syphilis?

It can manifest as early onset and late onset syphilis

questions.text:
An 18-year-old man came in with itchiness on his fingertips.
Below is a clinical description of the lesion and its etiological agent. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The history of itching across the fingers and the presence of lesions in the finger webs as seen in the picture strongly suggest scabies.
  • Scabies is characterized by intractable itchiness, which is typically worse at night.
  • The lesions first develop on the web gaps, then spread to the sides of the fingers, the flexor surfaces of the wrists and elbows, and the anterior axillary folds.
  • The areolae in women, the buttocks, the sacrum and periumbilical regions, as well as the penis and scrotum, are other common locations for lesions.
  • Eczematous and frequently excoriated lesions are possible, but the burrow—a brief, wavy, dark line—is the hallmark lesion.


Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 34.41, 34.40

questions.text:
Some gram-negative bacteria develop an enzyme that prevents beta lactam antibiotics from acting in the periplasm.
Which arrow in the Penicillin G structural diagram represents the site of action of this enzyme?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) B
 
  • Beta-lactam is an amide bond found in the structure of Penicillin G, as represented by 'B' above.
  • Beta-lactamases are the enzymes produced by some bacteria which provide resistance to beta-lactam antibiotics like penicillins, cephamycins, and carbapenems by breaking the antibiotics' structure. 
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 766.

questions.text: Which of the subsequent illnesses is NOT caused on by parvovirus B19?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Roseola infantum

Roseola infantum, also known as sixth disease or exanthema subitum, is not caused by parvovirus B19. It is typically caused by human herpesvirus 6 (HHV-6) or, less commonly, human herpesvirus 7 (HHV-7).

On the other hand, parvovirus B19 is associated with the following conditions:
 
  1. Aplastic anemia in sickle cell disease: Parvovirus B19 infection can cause transient aplastic crisis in individuals with underlying hemolytic conditions such as sickle cell disease. It can lead to a temporary shutdown of red blood cell production, resulting in anemia.
  2. Fetal hydrops: Parvovirus B19 infection during pregnancy can lead to severe complications in the fetus, including fetal hydrops. Fetal hydrops is a condition characterized by abnormal fluid accumulation in two or more fetal compartments, such as the skin, abdomen, or thorax.
  3. Erythema infectiosum (Fifth disease): This is a common childhood illness caused by parvovirus B19. It is characterized by a distinctive rash on the face, giving a "slapped cheek" appearance, followed by a lacy rash on the trunk and limbs.







Reference: Jawetz, Melnick & Adelberg's Medical Microbiology, 27th edition, Page no 441, 443, 459.

questions.text: A 18-year-old female patient arrives at the gynaecology OPD with six months of amenorrhea, h/o low grade fever, weight loss, abdominal pain, and generalised weakness. During a clinical  examination, a pelvic mass with ascites-like symptoms was felt on the left side. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
TB with tubo-ovarian mass
Six months of amenorrhea, h/o low grade fever, weight loss, abdominal pain, and generalised weakness point towards diagnosis
GUTB, as with other cases of TB, is usually caused by infection with M. tuberculosis. However, other species of mycobacteria in the MTB complex, including Mycobacterium bovis, Mycobacterium africanum, Mycobacterium pinnipedii, Mycobacterium microti, Mycobacterium caprae, and the TB vaccine bacillus Calmette–Guérin (BCG), can rarely cause disease. In developing countries, the incidence tends to be higher at around 15 to 20%.

Medical Treatment
GUTB, in general, is treated like pulmonary TB with a four-drug regimen for six months (rifampicin, isoniazid, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol for the first two months, then isoniazid and rifampicin for four months).
Patients that may need longer treatment include patients with HIV co-infection, kidney abscesses, or bone infiltration.
Patients with multidrug-resistant TB (MDR-TB) require treatment with MDR-TB regimens that include fluoroquinolones, bedaquiline, delaminid, aminoglycosides, etc., and the regimen may extend up to 18 to 24 months.
Surgical Treatment
Patients with GUTB complicated with ureteral stricture and hydronephrosis should be treated with early stenting or percutaneous nephrostomy.
Nephrectomy is considered in patients with non-functioning kidneys, patients with co-existing renal cell carcinomas, and those with extensive disease involving the whole kidney.


Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 350-354.

questions.text: Which is the most common cause of croup in children?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Parainfluenza

Most common causative organism for Acute Laryngo-tracheobronchitis is Parainfluenza virus. 
RSV causes bronchiolytis.

questions.text: What is the most likely cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
• The given picture is of hand-foot-mouth disease caused by Coxsackie virus.
  • Hand-Foot-Mouth Disease (HFMD): After an incubation period of 4-6 days, patients with HFMD present with fever, anorexia, and malaise; these manifestations are followed by the development of sore throat and vesicles on the buccal mucosa and frequently on the tongue; these lesions are then followed by the appearance of tender vesicular lesions on the dorsum of the hands, occasionally involving the palms.
  • The vesicles may become bullae and ulcerate very soon.


Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 117.6,117.7

questions.text: Which medication from the list below is not used to treat bird flu?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Ribavirin 

  • There are specific antiviral medications for influenza, including amantadine and rimantadine for influenza A as well as the neuraminidase inhibitors zanamivir, oseltamivir, and peramivir for both influenza A and influenza B.
  • A nucleoside analogue ribavirin has action in vitro against influenza A and B viruses.
  • When given as an aerosol, it has been reported to be varyingly effective against influenza but ineffective when given orally.
  • Its effectiveness in treating influenza A or B has not been shown.
  • Hepatitis C, viral hemorrhagic fevers, and RSV are the main conditions that ribavirin is used to treat.
* Audio Explanation:


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 856.

questions.text: A boy with sickle cell anemia and non-suppurative osteomyelitis appeared. What will be the likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Salmonella

Sickle cell anemia is a genetic blood disorder characterized by the presence of abnormal sickle-shaped red blood cells. Individuals with sickle cell anemia are more susceptible to infections, including osteomyelitis, due to impaired blood flow and compromised immune function.

Among the options provided:
  1. Salmonella: Salmonella is a common cause of osteomyelitis in individuals with sickle cell anemia. Salmonella osteomyelitis tends to affect the long bones, particularly the femur and tibia.
  2. S. aureus (Staphylococcus aureus): While S. aureus is a common cause of osteomyelitis in the general population, it is less frequently associated with osteomyelitis in individuals with sickle cell anemia.
  3. H. influenzae (Haemophilus influenzae): H. influenzae is primarily associated with respiratory tract infections and meningitis. It is not a common causative organism for osteomyelitis.
  4. Enterobacter species: Enterobacter species are not typically associated with osteomyelitis.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1297.

choices.text: Helps to Diagnose cancer in Genital Tract
Helps to Diagnose other associated Genital infections in the Patient

questions.text:
A 45-year-old woman who frequently contracts Trichomonas vaginalis infection visits the gynecology outpatient department.
She was told to get a PAP Smear. She is curious about the purpose of this test and enquires about the same. What will be the appropriate response?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Helps to Screen for Cervical Cancer
 

A Pap smear, or Papanicolaou test, is primarily used to screen for cervical cancer by detecting precancerous or cancerous changes in cervical cells. While it can sometimes incidentally detect infections like Trichomonas vaginalis or other abnormalities, its primary purpose is not to diagnose infections but to catch early signs of cervical cancer.

Other options:

  1. Helps to Diagnose cancer in Genital Tract: While the Pap smear can help in identifying precancerous or cancerous cells in the cervix, it’s not a diagnostic tool for all genital tract cancers.
  2. Helps to demonstrate Trichomonas vaginalis infection: Although Trichomonas may occasionally be seen in a Pap smear, other tests like a wet mount or NAAT are more reliable for diagnosing infections.
  3. Helps to Diagnose other associated Genital infections in the Patient: Pap smears are not specifically designed for diagnosing infections.



Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 364.

questions.text: Which of the following is the reason for the development of a typical case of Hecht's Pneumonia?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Measles

HECHT’S PNEUMONIA :
  • It is also known as Giant Cell Pneumonia
  • Rare complication of measles.
  • Commonly found in children who are immunodeficient ( leukemia or HIV/AIDS).
  •  Autopsy findings: MULTINUCLEATED GIANT CELLS  lining the alveoli of the lungs


Reference:https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK448068/

questions.text:
A 24-year-old man had multiple small hypopigmented patches around his hair follicles on his upper chest and back. Macules had fine scaling that coalesced later.
Before one year, the patient received treatment, and it was successful. Which of the following tests would be most useful??
questions.solution:
• Pityriasis versicolor is a common fungal infection caused by the yeast species Malassezia furfur.
  • It presents as multiple, small hypopigmented macules on the upper chest and back which are circular, arranged around follicles and can coalesce to form large sheets with fine scaling.
  • The most appropriate investigation to confirm the diagnosis is a potassium hydroxide (KOH) preparation.
  • A KOH preparation can be done with a scraping of the affected area, which will show the characteristic short branching adapted yeasts.
  • The fungus can also be seen under the microscope with other staining techniques such as periodic acid-Schiff (PAS) and Giemsa.



Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 32.11, 32.12

questions.text: Which of the following drugs absorbs most readily after a fatty meal?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Griseofulvin
 
  • Griseofulvin inhibits microtubule formation and thereby disrupts the assembly of the mitotic spindle.
  • Improved absorption when the drug is taken with a fatty meal. 
* [Extra Edge]: Griseofulvin
  1. Griseofulvin interferes with mitosis—multi­ nucleated and stunted fungal hyphae are produced under its action. Metaphase arrest does not occur, but daughter nuclei fail to move apart or move only a short distance. It binds to polymerized microtubules and interferes with their function.
  2. The absorption of griseofulvin from g.i.t. is incomplete because of very low water solubility. Absorption is improved by taking it with fats and by microfining the drug particles. Griseofulvin is keratophilic; gets deposited in keratin forming cells of skin, hair and nails.
  3. Griseofulvin is used orally only for dermatophytosis. On getting deposited in the skin through circulation, it prevents fungal invasion of keratin. Because it is fungistatic and not cidal, the newly formed keratin is not invaded by the fungus, but the fungus persists in already infected keratin, till it is shed off.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 77.

questions.text: During a normal laboratory check, a patient's HBsAg status is discovered to be positive. Other hepatitis serological testing are unremarkable. His liver enzymes are within the normal range, and he exhibits no clinical symptoms. Which of the following options most accurately sums up his diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The above clinical scenario with HBsAg positive and other serological marker negative and with Normal aminotransferase levels points the diagnosis most probably towards Inactive HBV carrier.
 
  • In patients with chronic hepatitis B and normal aminotransferase activity in the absence of HBeAg, serial testing over time is often required to distinguish between inactive carriage and HBeAg-negative chronic hepatitis B with fluctuating virologic and necroinflammatory activity.
 
  • Such patients have IgG anti-HBc in serum; anti-HBs is either undetected or detected at low titer against the opposite subtype specificity of the antigen. These patients may (1) be inactive carriers; (2) have low-grade, mild chronic hepatitis; or (3) have moderate to severe chronic hepatitis with or without cirrhosis.

Serological markers of Hepatitis B:





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2576-2578.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman complains to the OP that her vaginal discharge is green and itchy locally. The cervix seems to be a strawberry upon close inspection. What is the course of treatment?
questions.solution:
Metronidazole
This is a typical case of green vaginal discharge with strawberry cervix suggestive of Trichomonas vaginalis.
Trichomoniasis is a very common STD caused by infection with Trichomonas vaginalis (a protozoan parasite)
Women with it may notice
Itching, burning, redness or soreness of the genitals;
Discomfort when peeing; and A clear, white, yellowish, or greenish vaginal discharge (i.e., thin discharge or increased volume) with a fishy smell.
Recommended Regimen for Trichomoniasis Among Women. Metronidazole 500 mg 2 times/day for 7 days. Partner is also given the same treatment. 
Alternative Regimen for Women and Men. Tinidazole 2 g orally in a single dose.


Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 364, 365.

Congenital Rubella Syndrome includes a triad of
  • Sensorineural Deafness

questions.text: A patient has multiple hyperesthetic and hypopigmented patches on the lateral aspect of the forearm with abundant acid-fast bacteria and granulomatous inflammation is seen. What is the diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
• Borderline lepromatous leprosy is a form of leprosy which is characterized by multiple hypoaesthetic and hypopigmented macules on the skin.

questions.text: Which of the following has recently been approved as a treatment for multidrug resistant tuberculosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Bedaquiline
 
  • The FDA granted bedaquiline approval on December 28, 2012. It is specially approved to treat multi-drug-resistant tuberculosis and was the first novel treatment to treat TB in more than 40 years.
  • The ATP synthase proton pump is impacted by bedaquiline. All other quinolone antibiotics target DNA gyrase; this method does not.
  • Recently BPaLM regime is recommended for treatment of drug-resistant TB by Ministry of Health and Family Welfare.

  • BPaLM regimen consisting of four-drug combination – Bedaquiline, Pretomanid, Linezolid and Moxifloxacin, has been proven to be safe, more effective and a quicker treatment option than the previous MDR-TB treatment procedure.
     

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 822.
Recent Update: https://www.mohfw.gov.in/?q=/press-info/7673

questions.text: A male patient is found to have anti-HBe antibody positivity, HBs Ag antigen positivity, and HBe Ag antigen negativity. While SGOT and SGPT are raised to 6 times the upper limit of normal value, HBV DNA copies are detected to be 100,000/ml. What plausible diagnosis is there?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: HBV precore mutant
 
  • The patient has anti-HBe antibody positivity, HBsAg positivity, and HBeAg negativity. These serological markers suggest a transition from the immune tolerant phase to the immune clearance phase of chronic HBV infection. The presence of raised SGOT and SGPT levels indicates liver inflammation.
 
  • The key feature in this case is the detection of HBV DNA copies at 100,000/ml. A precore mutant HBV infection is characterized by the absence of HBeAg production due to a mutation in the precore region of the HBV genome. This leads to a decrease or absence of HBeAg in the serum, despite ongoing viral replication.
 
  • Therefore, the most likely diagnosis in this case is HBV precore mutant infection.





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2576.

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman complains of vaginal discharge and localised itching. The results of a Pap test revealed the following image. What might be the cause of this infection?
questions.solution:
Gardenella vaginalis
The history of vaginal itching with presence of CLUE CELLS indicate Bacterial vaginosis causes by Gardenella vaginalis.
Clue cells are epithelial cells covered by adherent gram-negative rods, observed in vaginal smears from women with bacterial vaginosis.
AMSEL CRITERIA IS USED FOR DIAGNOSIS OF BV

Amsel Criteria for Diagnosis of BV: Three of the following four criteria must be met. Establishes accurate diagnosis of bacterial vaginosis in 90% of affected women.

1) Homogeneous, non-clumping vaginal discharge (color and amount may vary)

2) Amine (fishy) odor when potassium hydroxide solution is added to vaginal secretions (commonly) called the "whiff test")

3) Presence of clue cells (greater than 20%) on microscopy

4) Vaginal pH greater than 4.5

Reference: Shaw's Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 330, 331.

questions.text: Which of the following does not include Hutchinson's triad?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1:  Follicular Conjunctivitis

CONGENITAL SYPHILIS :-
FEATURES –
*Rhagades – Linear scars originating from angle of mouth
*Snuffles
*Saddle nose
*Hutchinson Teeth
*Mulberry molars
*Sensorineural deafness
* HUTCHINSON TRIAD -A triad of presentations commonly found in late congenital syphilis.

Consists of  the following :-
  • Interstitial keratitis
  • Notched Incisors ( Hutchinson incisors )
  • Sensorineural Hearing Loss (Eighth nerve defect)

Reference- Nelson Essentials Of Pediatrics Edition 21 st Page No 1594

questions.text: Mid borderline leprosy is characterised by which of the following?
questions.solution:
• Borderline(BB) leprosy is characterized by hypopigmented macules or plaques with Annular Swiss cheese/inverted saucer appearance.
  • The lesions are usually variable in number ~ 10-30. 


Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 28.10

questions.text: Which one of these is a new oral medication used to treat chronic Hepatitis C?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Ledipasvir

Ledipasvir is an Inhibitor of NS5A protein. 
Commonly used in combination with sofosbuvir for treatment in chronic hepatitis C genotype I patients. 
Standard treatment regimen for Hep C - Sofosbuvir + Velpatasvir x 12 weeks
Other options: -
  • Interferon alpha and Lamivudine are used in the treatment of chronic Hepatitis B 
  • Oseltamivir is used in the treatment of Influenza
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 859.

questions.text: Specify the correct option for Dengue Discharge Protocol:
questions.solution:
Correct option: 4. Return to good appetite

Patient Discharge Guidelines:
  • Fever-free interval of at least 24 hours without the use of antipyretics.
  • Platelet count > 50, 000/mm3
  • Return of appetite
  • Good urine output
  • Platelet count > 50, 000/mm3
  • Minimum of 2 to 3 days following recovery from shock
  • Visible clinical improvement


 
Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 296.

questions.text: A young 8 years old boy with multiple, small, pin point, shiny, papular lesions on dorsal aspect of hand, forearms and his penis also. Most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
• Lichen nitidus is a rare skin disorder that is characterized by small, pinhead-sized, shiny, flat-topped papules.
  • These papules often form clusters, which can range in size from a few millimeters to up to a centimeter. They usually appear on the trunk, upper arms, neck, and face, and may be more common in children and adolescents.
  • The color of the papules can vary from yellow-brown, to pink or white. Lichen nitidus is asymptomatic and does not cause itching or irritation.
  • The diagnosis of Lichen nitidus is based on the appearance of the papules. A skin biopsy can confirm the diagnosis.
  • Treatment is usually not necessary, although topical steroids may be used to reduce any inflammation. Long-term prognosis for Lichen nitidus is excellent, as it is considered a harmless condition.

Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 37.10

questions.text: Which of the following medications kills gametes of all Plasmodium species?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Primaquine

Primaquine is gametocidal for all species of Plasmodium.
 
  • Primaquine is effective against all human malaria parasites in their hepatic stages.
  • It is the sole treatment on the market that is effective against P vivax and P. ovale's dormant hypnozoite stages.
  • Moreover, the medication shows modest efficacy against parasites in the erythrocytic stage and is gametocidal against all four human malaria species.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 878.

questions.text: What is the likely cause of the below photograph: -
questions.solution:
In the image we can see swelling of Right limb compared to the left, as it's unilateral so it's a case of lymphedema. 
 
  • Lymphedema of the lower extremity initially involves the foot and gradually progresses up the leg so that the entire limb becomes edematous.
  • In the early stages, the edema is soft and pits easily with pressure.
  • Over time, subcutaneous adipose tissue accumulates, the limb enlarges further and loses its normal contour, and the toes appear square.
  • Thickening of the skin is detected by Stemmer’s sign, which is the inability to tent the skin at the base of the toes.
  • Peau d’orange is a term used to describe dimpling of the skin, resembling that of an orange peel, caused by lymphedema.
  • In the chronic stages, the edema no longer pits and the limb acquires a woody texture as the tissues become indurated and fibrotic.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2119.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presented with painful boggy swelling of the scalp, multiple discharging sinuses, easily pluckable hairs, and lymph nodes enlarged in the occipital region. Which one of the following would be most helpful for diagnostic evaluation?
questions.solution:
• The given features (painful boggy swelling of the scalp, multiple discharging sinuses, easily pluckable hairs) are consistent with that of Kerion or Tinea Capitis.
  • Tinea capitis(scalp ringworm) is a fungal infection of the scalp and hair. It appears as patches of scaling, broken hair, and inflammation or bald spots on the scalp.
  • The most common symptom is itching, but the affected area may also be tender. The diagnosis of tinea capitis is usually based on a physical inspection of the infected area.
  • Confirmation can be achieved using laboratory testing, such as fungal culture on KOH wet mount, direct tissue examination, and Wood's lamp examination.




Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 32.39

questions.text: Which of the given options is an antitubercular medicine that causes ophthalmic toxicity?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Ethambutol

Ethambutol can cause ophthalmic toxicity in the form of optic neuritis and red green colorblindness.

* Ethambutol:
  • Retrobulbar neuritis, which causes a loss of visual acuity and red-green colorblindness, is the most frequent major adverse effect.
  • When dosages of 25 mg/kg/d are sustained for several months, this dose-related adverse effect is more likely to develop.
  • Specialists advise baseline and recurring assessments of color perception and visual acuity, paying particular attention to those who are taking higher doses or who have other conditions.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 820.

questions.text: What is cornerstone treatment of dengue fever with warning signs without shock ?
questions.solution:
IV fluids are the mainstay of treatment for a dengue patient who is exhibiting warning signals.
 
Plasma leakage resulting in shock in dengue is the primary pathology.
Therefore, the primary method of treatment is supportive management with continuous infusion of crystalloid IV fluids.


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 296, 297.

questions.text: The Ridley-Joplin classification for leprosy is based on which parameters?
questions.solution:
The Ridley-Jopling classification for leprosy is a system designed in 1967 to classify the type of leprosy a person is affected with. The classification takes into account the degree to which patients have been affected by the disease by Clinical, bacteriological and immunological parameters and assigns them one of five stages of severity: 1. Tuberculoid Leprosy: This is the least severe type of leprosy. It affects few areas of skin or nerves, and in some cases can remain stable after treatment. 2. Mid-Range Leprosy: Symptoms may include discolored skin patches, known as macules, and some nerve damage. 3. Borderline Leprosy: Symptoms may include uneven skin patches, patches with several colors, and greater nerve damage, but still no physical deformities. 4. Borderline Lepromatous Leprosy: Symptoms may include large patches with multiple colors, significant nerve damage and physical deformities, such as clubbed fingers. 5. Lepromatous Leprosy: This is the most severe type of leprosy. Symptoms include widespread skin lesions, gross deformities, and general deterioration of health. The Ridley-Jopling classification is based on the appearances of skin lesions, deformities, as well as the degree of body reactions to antigenic and bacterial tests.


Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 28.3,28.12

questions.text:
A patient is being treated with indinavir, zidovudine, lamivudine, and ketoconazole. Which drug is responsible for his development of central obesity,
nephrolithiasis, hyperlipidemia, and breast hypertrophy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Indinavir 

Protease inhibitors like indinavir can cause nephrolithiasis.
 
  • Protease inhibitors frequently cause gynecomastia/breast enlargement, dyslipidemia, and obesity.
  • Gynecomastia and breast enlargement are possible adverse effects of Ketoconazole, although none of the others are observed. Zidovudine and stavudine, two NRTIs, produce lipodystrophy and not obesity.

ART Side effects- 

Drug Class Common Drugs Most Common Side Effects
NRTIs - Abacavir- Tenofovir- Lamivudine - Lactic acidosis- Renal toxicity (Tenofovir)- Hypersensitivity (Abacavir)
NNRTIs - Efavirenz - Rash- CNS effects (Efavirenz)- Hepatotoxicity
PIs - Atazanavir- Darunavir - Hyperlipidemia- GI upset- Fat redistribution
Integrase Inhibitors - Dolutegravir - GI upset- Insomnia
Entry Inhibitors - Maraviroc - Hepatotoxicity- Muscle/joint pain
Pharmacokinetic Enhancers - Ritonavir- Cobicistat - GI upset- Liver enzyme elevation

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 865.

questions.text: What is the most common lung finding in COVID-19?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: Diffuse Alveolar Damage
 
  • Diffuse alveolar damage is a type of lung injury that is characterized by widespread inflammation and damage to the alveoli. It is the most common lung finding in COVID-19.
 
  • In COVID-19, the virus can directly damage the alveoli, or it can cause an immune response that leads to damage to the alveoli. The damage to the alveoli can lead to fluid accumulation in the lungs, which can make it difficult to breathe.
 
  • Other lung findings that can be seen in COVID-19 include:
    • Ground-glass opacities
    • Consolidation
    • Pleural effusion


Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 353.

questions.text:
An industrial worker presents to you with groin plaques that are scaly, annular, and irritating. The pruritus is reduced after applying corticosteroid ointment, however, the lesion's peripheral extension persisted and worsens.
What is the plausible diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
• The above lesions/history is suggestive of Tinea cruris(crotch itch) which is a dermatophyte fungal infection of the groin region.
  • Caused usually by Trichophyton rubrum. The clinical picture includes Itching or a burning sensation in the groin area, thigh skin folds or anus, and scaly/annular lesions.
  • Steroids being anti-inflammatory initially decrease the acute inflammation and hence the pruritis/itching but they can also make antifungal medications less effective and the primary infection worse. (Reason why peripheral extension persisted and then worsened)




Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 32.46, 32.47

choices.text: Inhibition of sterol of the cell wall
Competes with PABA in folic acid synthesis

questions.text: Dapsone is employed as an immunomodulator, antifungal, and antibacterial. What process underlies each of these actions?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Competes with PABA in folic acid synthesis

Dapsone Competes with PABA in folic acid synthesis.
 
  • Dapsone is a competitive inhibitor of dihydropteroate synthase (folP1/P2) in the folate pathway and a structural analogue of para-aminobenzoic acid (PABA).
  • Dapsone's impact on this evolutionarily conserved route also explains why it has antibacterial, anti-protozoal, and antifungal properties.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 831.

questions.text:
A dengue patient who was admitted hasn't had pyrexia in the past 24 hours and has a healthy appetite. His blood pressure is 110/70 millimeters of mercury. Hematocrit is 44%, TLC is 4K, and platelet count is 34K according to the workup. When he blows his nose, he experiences epistaxis, which has since resolved on its own. What is the best course of action to take next for this patient's care
a. IVF
b. 4 units of platelet-rich plasma
c. Reassurance and observation
d. Plenty of oral fluids
questions.solution:
Reassurance and observation with plenty of oral fluids is the next step in management.

Intravenous fluids should be reduced or discontinued when any of the following signs are present:
• Normal blood pressure, pulse and peripheral perfusion;
• Decrease in hematocrit
• Apyrexia (without the use of antipyretics) for more than 24–48 hours;
• Resolving bowel/abdominal symptoms;
• Improving urine output.

Continuing intravenous fluid therapy beyond the 48 hours of the critical phase will put the patient at risk of pulmonary oedema and other complications such as thrombophlebitis.

Indications for Platelet transfusion: 
  1. Prophylactic platelet transfusion may be given at level of <10,000/cu.mm
  2. Prolonged shock; with coagulopathy and abnormal coagulogram
  3. Spontaneous bleeding manifestations                                                                                                                                                            In case of systemic massive bleeding platelet transfusion may be needed in addition to red cell transfusion.



Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 296.
National Guidelines for Clinical Management of Dengue Fever 2023, MoHFW, Govt of India. URL: https://ncvbdc.mohfw.gov.in/Doc/National Guidelines for Clinical Management of Dengue Fever 2023.pdf

questions.text: A 45 years old patient presented with multiple hypoaesthetic patches over trunk and extremities. On examination, ulnar and lateral popliteal nerves are enlarged bilaterally. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The patient here has multiple hypo-esthetic patches (seen in border­line leprosy) and bilateral symmetrical nerve thickening (suggestive of Lepromatous leprosy).
  • Now in lepromatous leprosy(LL), there is normal anesthesia. Hence, the patient fits in the category of Borderline Lepro­matous Leprosy(BL).





Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 28.8

questions.text: A pediatrician attended an infant who had an unconjugated serum bilirubin level of 33 mg/dL. What medications could the mother have taken during the third trimester?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Cotrimoxazole
 
  • Cotrimoxazole if given near term may cause neonatal hemolysis and methemoglobinemia.
  • Cotrimoxazole is not clearly proven to be hazardous during pregnancy, especially if the dosage is decreased early on to diminish the minor risk of fetal hemolysis and methemoglobinemia.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 758.

questions.text:
What are the elements of qSOFA scoring?
A. Heart rate
B. Blood pressure
C. Respiratory rate
D. Mental status
questions.solution:
qSOFA components:
i. Hypotension- systolic BP < 100 mmHg
ii. Altered mental status
iii. Tachypnea- RR > 22/ minute

Each parameter has a score of 1.
A score of more than or equal to 2 criteria suggests a greater risk of a poor outcome.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2246.

questions.text: An apparently healthy male appears with a white area on his tongue that looks like creamy curd. The most likely cause is:
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Candidiasis
 
  • The given clinical scenario of white curdy lesions on the tongue and buccal mucosa in a patient is oral candidiasis. The drug that can be used for the treatment is clotrimazole.
  • Candida albicans is an opportunistic pathogen that causes candidiasis. It is yeast when part of the normal flora of mucous membranes but forms pseudo-hyphae and hyphae when it invades tissue.
  • They are not dimorphic. It forms germ tubes when incubated at 37 degrees Celsius. It is gram-positive and forms colonies of yeasts on Sabouraud's agar.
  • Acute pseudomembranous candidiasis: Sharply defined patch of creamy, crumbly, curdlike, white pseudomembrane



Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 32.59,32.56

questions.text: Which of the following dose reductions is not required in renal failure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Doxycycline 
 
  • Doxycycline is safe in renal failure dose reduction is not required.
  • In contrast to tigecycline, which is primarily excreted intact along with a minor quantity of glucuronidated metabolites, and minocycline, which is significantly processed by the liver prior to excretion, doxycycline is largely excreted unchanged in both the bile and urine.
  • The dosages of these drugs don't need to be adjusted for people with renal failure.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 79.

questions.text: What statement regarding CORADS is accurate?
questions.solution:
CORADS is a CT based system that is sued to assess the suspicion of pulmonary involvement in COVID -19.

CORADS score of 5 is indicative of typical COVID infection.
 

Findings of COVID-19:

—Bilateral, peripheral & lower zone predominant airspace opacities (GGOs, consolidations) on X - ray.

—Bilateral, sub pleural, peripheral GGOs, airspace consolidations, crazy pavement patterns on CT. 

—Reverse halo/Atoll sign: central area of GGO with surrounding consolidation.






Reference: Prokop, Mathias et al. “CO-RADS: A Categorical CT Assessment Scheme for Patients Suspected of Having COVID-19-Definition and Evaluation.” Radiology vol. 296,2 (2020): E97-E104. doi:10.1148/radiol.2020201473. URL: https://ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7233402/

questions.text:
The patient, a 42-year-old man, had lesions as depicted below.
Which of these is the best course of action for treating this condition?
questions.solution:
• The given image shows Leonines facies (thickened nodular lesions on foreheard, ears, eyebrows, and cheeks) seen in and classically described for Lepromatous leprosy.
  • Hence, the patient should be started on MDT for leprosy.
  • In Lepromatous leprosy, the skin and soft tissues of the face can thicken, leading to a lion-like appearance, which is where the term "leonine" comes from.
  • This change is due to the effects of the disease on the skin and underlying tissues, including loss of eyebrows and changes in the nose's structure.


Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 28.9

questions.text: What is the vancomycin's mode of action?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Cell wall synthesis inhibition
 
  • Vancomycin inhibits cell wall synthesis.
  • Vancomycin and teicoplanin bind with a high affinity to the D-alanyl-D-alanine terminal of cell wall precursor units to prevent sensitive bacteria from synthesizing cell walls.
  • They cannot pierce the gram-negative bacteria's outer membrane due to their huge molecular size.
  • Vancomycin infusion is associated with red man syndrome due to degranulation of mast cells. 
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 806.

questions.text: Within 4-6 hours after showing signs of high-grade fever and inspiratory stridor, a kid experiences swallowing difficulties and saliva dribbling. Which of the following needs to be administered in addition to airway management?
questions.solution:
Along with airway management IV Ceftriaxone needs to be given.

The given features are suggestive of acute epiglottitis and it’s treatment has following components:
  • Urgent airway management
  • IV Fluids
  • IV 3rd generation cephalosporin


Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 21st edition, Page no 1487, 1488, 1734, 2203, 2204.

questions.text: A patient comes to your OPD with the following lesion which was associated with itching. The most likely diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
• Tinea corporis, also known as ringworm, is a fungal skin infection typically caused by a type of fungus known as dermatophytes.
  • It typically presents as an itchy, annular (ring-shaped) plaque with well-defined borders, peripheral papulopustular, scaling, and central clearing.
  • The most common organism responsible for this infection is a type of dermatophyte named Trichophyton rubrum.
Trick: -
Annular lesion with central clearing- Tinea
Annular lesion with central scarring- Lupus vulgaris
Annular lesion with central crusting- Cutaneous leishmaniasis 

Reference- Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page number 32.35, 32.36, 31.26

questions.text: A patient on antitubercular medication experienced tingling in his lower limb. Which of the following, when substituted, can result in symptom improvement?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Pyridoxine
 
  • Pyridoxine can be given for improvement of symptoms.
  • Pyridoxine can be used as a preventative measure to halt ATT-induced neuropathy. Peripheral neuritis, which most frequently manifests as paresthesia of the hands and feet in patients taking isoniazid 5 mg/kg daily, can develop if pyridoxine is not administered concurrently.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 829.

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient arrived with skin lesions that are easily ruptureable and flaccid bullae. Suprabasal split was found after a biopsy. What diagnosis is most likely?
questions.solution:
• Using histopathology, an intradermal blister is seen. The basal layer's intercellular edema and loss of intercellular linkages are the initial signs of alteration.
