  • MULTIBACILLARY – 12 months within 18 months has to get completed
  • PAUCIBACILLARY – 6 months within 9 months has to get completed
  • FOLLOW UP: -
    • PAUCIBACILLARY –More than/equal to 5 years
    • MULTIBACILLARY – More than/equal to 10 years
  • DRUGS USED: -
    • PAUCIBACILLARY – Dapsone, Rifampicin
    • MULTIBACILLARY -Dapsone, Rifampicin, Clofazimine

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 834.

questions.text: Which of these nanoparticles has antibacterial properties against candida?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) All the above
 

Various types of nanoparticles have been studied for their antibacterial properties against Candida, including:

  • Silver Nanoparticles: Silver nanoparticles are particularly well-known for their broad-spectrum antimicrobial activity, including against Candida species.
  • Metal Oxide Nanoparticles: Nanoparticles of metals such as zinc oxide, titanium dioxide, and copper oxide have also shown antibacterial effects against Candida.
  • Polymeric Nanoparticles: Nanoparticles made from biocompatible polymers can be functionalized with antimicrobial agents or designed to disrupt microbial membranes effectively.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 952.

questions.text: Select the option that is a second-line antiretroviral drug according NACO.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Ritonavir

Ritonavir is the best answer among the 4 given options.



Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 871.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is not associated with causes of peripheral neuropathy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Rifampicin
 
  • Rifampicin is not typically associated with causing peripheral neuropathy.
  • Peripheral neuropathy refers to damage or dysfunction of the peripheral nerves, leading to symptoms such as numbness, tingling, and weakness in the extremities.
  • The drugs commonly associated with peripheral neuropathy include certain chemotherapeutic agents and medications used to treat infections.
  • Peripheral neuropathy is not a commonly reported side effect of rifampicin.
* [Extra Edge]: Drugs known to be associated with peripheral neuropathy
  • Vincristine
  • Paclitaxel
  • Cisplatin
  • Platinum-based drugs
  • Didanosine
  • Stavudine
  • Zalcitabine
  • Isoniazid
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 818.

questions.text: Which anti-retroviral medication among the following inhibits both C-C chemokine receptor type 2 (CCR2) and type 5 (CCR5) activity?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option is 2) Cenicriviroc
 
  • Cenicriviroc is an anti-retroviral medication that inhibits both C-C chemokine receptor type 2 (CCR2) and C-C chemokine receptor type 5 (CCR5) activity.
  • CCR2 and CCR5 are chemokine receptors that play a role in the entry of the human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) into host cells.
  • By blocking these receptors, cenicriviroc interferes with the entry of HIV into host cells and helps to control viral replication.

  • Cenicriviroc for the treatment of liver fibrosis in adults with nonalcoholic steatohepatiti



Online Reference: 
Anstee QM, Neuschwander-Tetri BA, Wong VW, Abdelmalek MF, Younossi ZM, Yuan J, Pecoraro ML, Seyedkazemi S, Fischer L, Bedossa P, Goodman Z, Alkhouri N, Tacke F, Sanyal A. Cenicriviroc for the treatment of liver fibrosis in adults with nonalcoholic steatohepatitis: AURORA Phase 3 study design. Contemp Clin Trials. 2020 Feb;89:105922. doi: 10.1016/j.cct.2019.105922. Epub 2019 Dec 24. PMID: 31881392.

questions.text: The following cephalosporin has an antipseudomonal activity?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Cefepime
 
  • Antipseudomonal cephalosporins are a class of antibiotics that are effective against Pseudomonas aeruginosa, a common and often antibiotic-resistant bacterium that can cause severe infections, especially in hospitalized patients and those with compromised immune systems.
  • These cephalosporins have enhanced activity against Pseudomonas aeruginosa compared to other cephalosporins. 

  1. Ceftazidime:

    • Ceftazidime is a third-generation cephalosporin that exhibits potent activity against Pseudomonas aeruginosa. It is commonly used for severe infections caused by this bacterium, including respiratory tract infections, urinary tract infections, and bloodstream infections. Ceftazidime is often used in combination with other antibiotics for more comprehensive coverage.

  2. Cefepime:

    • Cefepime is a fourth-generation cephalosporin that also has excellent activity against Pseudomonas aeruginosa. It is structurally similar to third-generation cephalosporins but has broader coverage against Gram-negative bacteria, including extended-spectrum beta-lactamase (ESBL)-producing organisms. Cefepime is frequently used in hospitals for serious infections, including nosocomial pneumonia, complicated urinary tract infections, and septicemia.
    • Cefepime has enhanced activity against Pseudomonas aeruginosa compared to earlier generation cephalosporins.

  3. Ceftolozane/Tazobactam:

    • Ceftolozane/tazobactam is a novel antipseudomonal cephalosporin/beta-lactamase inhibitor combination. It was specifically developed to combat multidrug-resistant Pseudomonas aeruginosa strains. Tazobactam, a beta-lactamase inhibitor, enhances the activity of ceftolozane against beta-lactamase-producing bacteria, including some strains of Pseudomonas aeruginosa resistant to other cephalosporins.
* [Extra Edge]: Drugs useful in Pseudomonas infection



Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 779.

questions.text: Which of the following antibiotics blocks protein synthesis by interfering with the translocation step?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Erythromycin
 
  • Aminoglycosides, such as gentamicin and streptomycin, are a class of antibiotics that work by binding to the 30S subunit of the bacterial ribosome.
  • By binding to the ribosome, aminoglycosides interfere with the accurate reading of the mRNA codons during protein synthesis.
  • This interference disrupts the translocation step, which is the movement of the ribosome along the mRNA strand during protein synthesis.
  • Ultimately, the disruption of translocation leads to the inhibition of bacterial protein synthesis.



Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 801.

questions.text: Which of the following is the only antimalarial medication used to treat malaria effectively?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Primaquine

Primaquine is gametocidal to all species of Plasmodia, while artemisinins have weak lethal action on early stage but not mature gametes.
A single dose of primaquine is employed immediately after clinical cure of falciparum malaria to kill the gametes and cut down transmission to mosquito.
  • Primaquine is an antimalarial medication that is primarily used for the prevention and treatment of relapse in certain types of malaria caused by Plasmodium vivax or Plasmodium ovale.
  • It is the only medication effective against the dormant liver stage of these malaria parasites, preventing the reemergence of the infection.
  •  By eliminating these hypnozoites, primaquine significantly reduces the reservoir of malaria parasites in the population and decreases the transmission of P. falciparum.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 878.

questions.text: Which one of the aforementioned Fifth Generation Cephalosporins is active against MRSA?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Ceftaroline
 
  • Ceftaroline is a fifth-generation cephalosporin antibiotic that exhibits activity against methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) bacteria.
  • It possesses a unique mechanism of action, targeting penicillin-binding proteins (PBPs) that are involved in cell wall synthesis.
  • The spectrum of activity of ceftaroline includes not only MRSA but also other gram-positive and gram-negative bacteria.



Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 779.

questions.text: Which antimalarial drug among the following has the greatest impact in lowering P. falciparum transmission?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Primaquine
 
  • Primaquine is an antimalarial medication that is primarily used for the prevention and treatment of relapse in certain types of malaria caused by Plasmodium vivax or Plasmodium ovale.
  • It is the only medication effective against the dormant liver stage of these malaria parasites, preventing the reemergence of the infection.
  •  By eliminating these hypnozoites, primaquine significantly reduces the reservoir of malaria parasites in the population.
  • It is also effective against gametocyte hence decreases the transmission of P. falciparum.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 878.

questions.text: Except for ______, all of the following sulfonamide are used topically.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Sulfadiazine
 
  • Sulfonamides are a class of antimicrobial medications that inhibit the growth and reproduction of bacteria by interfering with the synthesis of folate.
  • When it comes to topical use, sulfonamides are commonly used in the treatment of various skin and eye infections.
  • Sulfadiazine is not typically used topically due to poor skin penetration. It has limited ability to effectively reach deeper layers of the skin where the infection may be present.
  • Systemic absorption of sulfadiazine can occur when applied topically, increasing the risk of adverse effects and systemic side effects.
  • Sulfadiazine is primarily administered orally or intravenously for the treatment of systemic infections
* Other options:
  • Sulfacetamide is a topical sulfonamide commonly used in the treatment of eye infections, such as conjunctivitis.
  • Silver sulfadiazine is a topical antimicrobial agent that is used for the prevention and treatment of burn wound infections.
  • Mafenide is a topical sulfonamide used as an antibacterial agent in the treatment of burns.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 757.

questions.text: What is most frequently linked to pill induced esophagitis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Doxycycline
 
  • Pill-induced esophagitis is caused when the pill lodges within the lumen of the esophagus. This pill causes direct damage to the mucosa. The risk factors for pill-induced esophagitis include poor pill-taking habits, consuming inadequate liquids, and lying down immediately after consuming the pill.
  • Among the options provided, doxycycline is most frequently associated with causing pill-induced esophagitis.
  • The mechanism behind doxycycline-induced esophagitis is thought to be related to its direct irritant effect on the esophageal lining and the potential for local tissue damage.
* [Extra Edge]: Drugs causing esophagitis 
  • Doxycycline
  • Quinidine
  • Phenytoin
  • NSAIDs
  • Bisphosphonates
Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 1182.

questions.text: Which of the following carbapenems should not be used to treat nosocomial infections?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Ertapenem
 
  • Ertapenem is a carbapenem antibiotic that has a narrower spectrum of activity compared to other carbapenems.
  • While it is effective against many common community-acquired pathogens, it may not provide adequate coverage for multidrug-resistant organisms commonly found in nosocomial (hospital-acquired) infections.
  • Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a gram-negative bacterium known for its intrinsic resistance to many antibiotics, including ertapenem.
  • Therefore, when treating infections caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa, other carbapenems like imipenem, meropenem, or doripenem would be more suitable due to their broader spectrum of activity and better efficacy against Pseudomonas aeruginosa.



Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 782.

questions.text: Ertapenem does not work well against:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Pseudomonas
 
  • Ertapenem is a carbapenem antibiotic that has a narrower spectrum of activity compared to other carbapenems.
  • While it is effective against many common community-acquired pathogens, it may not provide adequate coverage for multidrug-resistant organisms commonly found in nosocomial (hospital-acquired) infections.
  • Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a gram-negative bacterium known for its intrinsic resistance to many antibiotics, including ertapenem.
  • Therefore, when treating infections caused by Pseudomonas aeruginosa, other carbapenems like imipenem, meropenem, or doripenem would be more suitable due to their broader spectrum of activity and better efficacy against Pseudomonas aeruginosa.



Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 782.

questions.text: When compared to vestibular toxicity, which aminoglycoside is more toxic to the cochlea?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Kanamycin
 
  • Aminoglycoside antibiotics are known to have the potential for both vestibular and cochlear toxicity, which can result in balance and hearing disturbances, respectively.
  • Among the given options, kanamycin (option C) is generally considered to have a higher risk of cochlear toxicity compared to vestibular toxicity.
  • Cochlear toxicity refers to damage to the structures of the inner ear responsible for hearing, while vestibular toxicity refers to damage to the structures responsible for balance and spatial orientation.
  • The decreasing order of potency for neuromuscular blockade: Neomycin -> Kanamycin -> Amikacin -> Gentamicin -> Tobramycin
Cochleotoxic drugs- KAN ( meaning ear)
Kanamycin 
Amikacin 
Neomycin- most toxic 

Vestibulo-toxic drugs-
Streptomycin
Gentamycin 

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 795.

questions.text: What is Gramicidin S?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Cyclic Decapeptide 
 
  • Gramicidin S is an antibiotic peptide composed of 10 amino acid residues, making it a cyclic decapeptide.
  • It is produced by the soil bacterium Bacillus brevis and has potent antimicrobial activity against a wide range of bacteria.
  • Gramicidin S is known for its ability to form ion channels in cell membranes, disrupting the normal functioning of bacterial cells.
  • Due to its mode of action, gramicidin S is primarily used as a topical antibiotic and is not typically administered systemically.
  • A group of peptide antibiotics from BACILLUS brevis. Gramicidin C or S is a cyclic, ten-amino acid polypeptide and gramicidins A, B, D are linear. Gramicidin is one of the two principal components of TYROTHRICIN.
Online Reference: 
PubChem [Internet]. Bethesda (MD): National Library of Medicine (US), National Center for Biotechnology Information; 2004-. PubChem Compound Summary for CID 73357, Gramicidin S; [cited 2024 Sept. 14]. Available from: https://pubchem.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/compound/Gramicidin-S

questions.text: Which anti-tubercular drug among the following has the highest sterilising effect?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Rifampicin
 
  • Rifampicin is known for its potent bactericidal activity against Mycobacterium tuberculosis, the bacterium that causes tuberculosis (TB).
  • It is a key component of the standard first-line drug regimen for treating TB.
  • Rifampicin has a high sterilizing effect, meaning it is effective in killing both replicating and non-replicating bacteria, including those in the dormant or persistent state.
  • It targets bacterial RNA polymerase, inhibiting RNA synthesis and thus preventing bacterial replication.
  • This unique mechanism of action contributes to its high sterilizing effect, reducing the bacterial load in TB infection and facilitating the eradication of the disease.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 818.

questions.text: Which antitubercular drug among the following has the best chance of halting the development of isoniazid resistance?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Rifampicin
 
  • Rifampicin is known for its potent bactericidal activity against Mycobacterium tuberculosis, the bacterium that causes tuberculosis (TB).
  • It is a key component of the standard first-line drug regimen for treating TB.
  • It targets bacterial RNA polymerase, inhibiting RNA synthesis and thus preventing bacterial replication.
  • When used in combination with isoniazid, rifampicin has been shown to reduce the risk of the development of isoniazid resistance.
  • The combination of rifampicin and isoniazid is often recommended as a frontline therapy to prevent the emergence of drug resistance and improve treatment outcomes.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 818.

questions.text: What is the preferred treatment for tuberculosis during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) HRZE for 2 months followed by HRE for 4 months according to NTEP
 
  • The preferred treatment regimen for tuberculosis (TB) during pregnancy follows the same principles as non-pregnant individuals, aiming to provide effective treatment while considering the safety of the mother and fetus
  • This treatment regimen provides adequate drug coverage to effectively treat TB while reducing potential risks to the mother and fetus.



Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 827.

questions.text: Rifampicin is being used to treat a patient. In the first-line HAART regimen for Rifampicin-based tuberculosis treatment, which of the following medicines is not preferred?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Nevirapine
 
  • Rifampicin, a key component of tuberculosis (TB) treatment, can significantly affect the metabolism of certain antiretroviral drugs used in the treatment of HIV/AIDS.
  • Rifampin, phenytoin, and nevirapine are microsomal enzyme inducers. Nevirapine, a non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NNRTI), is known to have a significant interaction with rifampicin.
  • Rifampicin can enhance the metabolism of nevirapine, leading to decreased plasma levels and potential loss of efficacy.
  • Due to this drug-drug interaction, nevirapine is not preferred in the first-line HAART regimen for Rifampicin-based TB treatment.
  • Rifampicin is a medication commonly used to treat tuberculosis, and it is also a potent inducer of certain liver enzymes. These enzymes can increase the metabolism and decrease the effectiveness of other medications that are metabolized by the same enzymes. In the case of HIV treatment, Rifampicin can reduce the effectiveness of certain antiretroviral drugs, including Nevirapine. As a result, Nevirapine is not preferred in the first-line HAART regimen for Rifampicin-based tuberculosis treatment.
  • Instead, other antiretroviral drugs that are less affected by Rifampicin-induced liver enzyme induction are preferred, such as Efavirenz. Therefore, option 2 is the correct answer. Zidovudine and Lamivudine are both nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NRTIs), which are not affected by Rifampicin-induced liver enzyme induction. These drugs are commonly used in HIV treatment and are not contraindicated in Rifampicin-based tuberculosis treatment.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 864.

choices.text: Treatment should be initiated within 48 hours of symptom onset
Should not be co-administered with the vaccine
Orally active with a Bioavailability of >60 percent

questions.text: Each of the following statements concerning oseltamivir is correct except ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Should not be co-administered with the vaccine 
 
  • Oseltamivir is a neuraminidase inhibitor (option A) and is commonly used for the treatment and prophylaxis of influenza virus infection.
  • It is most effective when initiated within 48 hours of symptom onset (option B), as early treatment can help reduce the severity and duration of symptoms.
  • Oseltamivir can be co-administered with the influenza vaccine (option C), and there are no significant interactions between oseltamivir and the vaccine. In fact, it is often recommended to receive the influenza vaccine even while taking oseltamivir for treatment or prophylaxis.
  • Oseltamivir is orally active, meaning it can be taken by mouth, and it has a bioavailability of over 60 percent (option D). This indicates that a significant portion of the drug is absorbed and available for therapeutic effect when taken orally.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 853.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis in case of a patient who was given primaquine develops dark coloured urine one day after administration of the drug?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency
 
  • Primaquine is an antimalarial medication commonly used for the treatment and prevention of malaria.
  • It is known to cause hemolytic anemia in individuals with glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency.
  • G6PD deficiency is an inherited enzyme deficiency that affects red blood cells, making them more susceptible to oxidative damage.
  • When individuals with G6PD deficiency are exposed to certain triggers, such as certain medications or infections, their red blood cells can undergo hemolysis, resulting in the release of hemoglobin.
  • The breakdown products of hemoglobin can give urine a dark or reddish color, known as hemoglobinuria.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 76.

questions.text: Which deficiency is caused by the Prolonged treatment with INH ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Pyridoxine 
 
  • Isoniazid (INH) is an antitubercular medication commonly used for the treatment of tuberculosis (TB).
  • Prolonged use of INH can lead to a deficiency of pyridoxine (vitamin B6).
  • INH inhibits the conversion of pyridoxine to its active form, pyridoxal phosphate, which is required for various enzymatic reactions in the body.
* Side effects of isoniazid include:
  • Peripheral neuritis due to interference with the production of active coenzyme pyridoxal phosphate from pyridoxine. Therefore, pyridoxine 10mg/day (vitamin B6) is given prophylactically along with isoniazid to prevent neurotoxicity.
  • Hepatitis - isoniazid must be stopped at the first sign of hepatotoxicity.
  • Rashes
  • Anaemia
  • Arthralgia
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 818.

questions.text:
Which of the following electrolytes is mandatorily monitored during Amphotericin B treatment?
1. \(Na^+\)
2. \(Ca^{2+}\)
3. \(K^+\)
4. \(Mg^{2+}\)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) \(K^+\)
 
  • Amphotericin B can cause renal toxicity, leading to renal tubular dysfunction and electrolyte imbalances.
  • One of the most significant electrolyte imbalances associated with Amphotericin B is hypokalemia (low potassium levels).
  • Hypokalemia can occur due to increased renal potassium excretion caused by the medication.
  • Therefore, regular monitoring of potassium (K+) levels is essential during Amphotericin B treatment to ensure appropriate management and prevention of complications.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 839.

questions.text: Which of the following Integrase inhibitors is approved for HIV1 and HIV 2 ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Raltegravir 
 
  • Raltegravir is an integrase inhibitor and is active against both HIV-1 and HIV-2. It can be used in adults and children >1 month old.
  • Integrase inhibitors block the action of the enzyme integrase, which is responsible for integrating the viral DNA into the host cell's DNA during the replication of the HIV virus.
  • By inhibiting integrase, Raltegravir prevents the integration of viral DNA into the host cell's DNA, thereby inhibiting viral replication.
  • Raltegravir is commonly used as part of combination antiretroviral therapy (ART) for the management of HIV infection.
  • Elvitegravir is effective against hiv-1 but it's efficacy against hiv-2 is not proven yet.
  • Lopinavir and Indinavir are protease inhibitors.
* [Extra Edge]: Lifecycle of HIV



Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 866.

choices.text: Transduce the signal to T-cell following antigen recognition
Present antigens for recognition by T-cell antigen receptors

questions.text: What does Major Histocompatibility Complex (MHC)-1 and -2 do?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Present antigens for recognition by T-cell antigen receptors

The main function of the MHC molecule is to bind peptide fragments of foreign protein for presentation to appropriate antigen-specific T cells.
  • Class I MHC molecules display peptides that are derived from cytoplasmic proteins, including normal proteins and virus- and tumor-specific antigens, which are all recognized bound to class I MHC molecules by CD8+ T cells.
  • Class II MHC molecules present antigens derived from extracellular microbes and proteins following their internalization into endosomes or lysosomes.
  • MHC molecules play several key roles in regulating T cell–mediated immune responses.
  1. First, because different antigenic peptides bind to different MHC molecules, it follows that an individual mounts an immune response against a protein antigen only if he or she inherits an MHC variant that can bind peptides derived from the antigen and present it to T cells.
  2. Second, by segregating cytoplasmic and internalized antigens, MHC molecules ensure that the correct immune response is mounted against different microbes—CTL-mediated killing of cells harboring cytoplasmic microbes and tumor antigens, and helper T cell–mediated antibody production and macrophage activation to combat extracellular and phagocytosed microbes.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 195.

questions.text: Where is the IgE receptor found?
questions.solution:
The IgE receptor (FcεRI) is primarily found on: Mast cells/Basophils and Eosinophils (to a lesser extent)

This receptor binds IgE antibodies, playing a crucial role in allergic reactions and parasite defense. When an allergen cross-links IgE bound to mast cells, it triggers degranulation, releasing histamine and other inflammatory mediators.

Other options

  • Promonocyte (2): These are precursors to monocytes/macrophages and do not express FcεRI.

  • T lymphocyte (3): T cells do not have FcεRI; they interact with antigens via T-cell receptors (TCR).

  • NK cell (4): Natural Killer (NK) cells express Fcγ receptors (for IgG) but not FcεRI.


  

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 100.

questions.text: Choose the statement that is untrue for NSAIDs.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Used in Neuropathic Pain.
  • NSAIDs are helpful for nociceptive pain (they inhibit COX which produces Prostaglandins which mediates nociceptive pain) but cannot relieve neuropathic pain as the physiologic process behind both are different.
  • NSAIDs do not affect the tenderness induced by direct application of PGs, but block the pain sensitizing mechanism induced by bradykinin, TNFα, interleukins (ILs) and other analgesic substances primarily by inhibiting COX-2. This constitutes the peripheral component of the analgesic action of NSAIDs. They are, therefore, more effective against inflammation associated pain. Drugs like Gabapentin/SSRIs are used for Neuropathic pain.

Option 2 and 3 are correct regarding NSAIDs interaction: Renal effects of NSAIDs become significant in those with CHF, hypovolemia, hepatic cirrhosis, renal disease and in patients receiving diuretics or antihypertensives. In them Na+ retention and edema can occur; diuretic and antihypertensive drug effects are blunted.
Option 4 is correct as NSAIDs have been marketed in topical formulations (mostly as gels) for application over painful muscles or joints.
It is presumed that the drug would penetrate to the subjacent tissues attaining high concentrations in the affected muscles/joints, while maintaining low blood levels. Some Topical Preparations are Diclofenac gel 1%, Ibuprofen 10% etc.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 210.

choices.text: Risk factors include sepsis and cardiac surgeries
It’s a cause of noncardiogenic pulmonary edema
Plasma is more likely to cause it than whole blood

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect about transfusion-related acute lung injury?
questions.solution:
Develops after 24 hours is thee incorrect statement.
 
  • TRALI typically develops within 6 hours of BT. In rare cases, it may develop upto 72 hours.
  • TRALI usually results from the transfusion of donor plasma that contains high-titer anti-HLA class II antibodies that bind recipient leukocytes.
  • The leukocytes aggregate in the pulmonary vasculature and release mediators that increase capillary permeability.
  • Clinical Features: The recipient develops symptoms of hypoxia (PaO2/FiO2 <300 mmHg) and signs of non-cardiogenic pulmonary edema. 
  • Diagnosis: Testing the donor's plasma for anti-HLA antibodies can support this diagnosis.
  • Treatment: Treatment is supportive, and patients usually recover without sequelae.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 891, 894.

questions.text: What kind of DNA repair is defective in severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID)?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Non-homologous end-joining repair

Non-homologous end joining repair is defective in severe combined immunodeficiency disease (SCID).
Other examples of human disease of DNA damage repair:
  1.  Defective Non homologous end joining repair
    1. SCID
  2. Defective homologous repair
    1. ATLD
    2. NBS
    3. Bloom syndrome
  3. Defective DNA nucleotide, excision repair
    1. Xeroderma pigmentosum
    2. TTD
  4. Defective DNA mismatch repair
    1. HNPCc
                  
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 242.

questions.solution:
Memorizing Trick: -
PApaine- cleaves Above


Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 96.

questions.text: What is Abatacept, a new drug inhibiting costimulation, used for treating?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Rheumatoid Arthritis
 
  • Abatacept is composed of the Fc region of the IgG1 fused to the extracellular domain of CTLA-4.
  • It inhibits the costimulation signal by binding to CD80/86 and preventing T cell activation. 
  • It's used in the treatment of Rheumatoid arthritis. 

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 230.

choices.text: Painful genital and oral blisters and ulcers

questions.text: Testing revealed a nucleolar pattern of ANA staining in a 30-year-old female patient with polyarthritis. What is the most likely course of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Sclerodactyly, esophageal dysmotility, and Raynaud’s phenomenon

#Controversial
  • Systemic sclerosis is an autoimmune connective tissue disorder characterized by fibrosis and vascular abnormalities causing sclerodactyly (thickening and tightening of the skin on the fingers), esophageal dysmotility (difficulty swallowing due to impaired movement of the esophagus), and Raynaud's phenomenon (spasms in the blood vessels of the fingers or toes in response to cold or stress). Polyarthritis can also be a component of systemic sclerosis.
 
  • Systemic features like Polyarthritis are more diagnostic of Diffuse SSc rather than Limited SSc (CREST syndrome)
  • Moreover, In Diffuse SSc generally, Sclerodactyly is followed by Raynaud's phenomenon whereas in Limited SSc (CREST) Raynaud's phenomenon precedes much before other features.
 
  • The nucleolar pattern of ANA staining is associated with certain autoimmune conditions, including Systemic sclerosis.

The other options mentioned in the question correspond to different autoimmune conditions:
 
  • Option 1: Malar rash, alopecia, and renal failure are features seen in systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).
  • Option 4: Painful genital and oral blisters and ulcers are associated with mucous membrane involvement in Behcet's disease.





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2776, 2778-2780.

questions.text: The characteristic anomaly noticed in Langerhans Cell Histiocytosis is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Birbeck granules
 

  • The Penta laminar tubules known as Birbeck granules, which contain the protein langerin are characteristic of Langerhans cell histiocytosis.

  • These Birbeck granules frequently have a dilated terminal end that gives them the appearance of a tennis racket.
* [Extra Edge]: Langerhans cell Histiocytosis


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 627.

questions.text: Which disease's immunopathogenesis is associated with antibody-dependent enhancement?
questions.solution:
• Antibody-dependent enhancement (ADE) also known as the Halsted phenomenon happens when non-neutralizing antiviral antibodies make it easier for viruses to enter host cells, increasing the cells' capacity to spread infection.
  • Some cells lack the typical receptors that viruses employ to attach to their surfaces. The antiviral proteins, or antibodies, attach to antibody Fe receptors found on the plasma membrane of certain of these cells. The antigen-binding site on the antibody's opposite end is where the viruses attach.
  • The scenario of dengue virus infection is the most well-known instance of ADE (DENV). This virus can infect human macrophages through this route, turning a typically moderate viral infection into a potentially fatal condition.
  • The phenomenon of ADE may be observed when a person who has previously been infected with one serotype of DENV becomes infected many months or years later with a different serotype.
  • This explains the finding that while primary infections (initial infections) primarily result in moderate disease (DF) in children, secondary infections (re-infections at a later time) are more frequently linked to severe disease (DHF and/or DSS) in both children and adults.
Audio explanation for the above.


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 270.

questions.text: Which of the following anti-rheumatoid medications that change illness functions by raising extracellular adenosine?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Methotrexate
 
  • Methotrexate is a disease-modifying anti rheumatoid drug that increases extracellular adenosine.
  • It relates to the inhibition of amino-imidazole carboxamide ribonucleotide (AICAR) transformylase and dihydrofolate reductase (DHFR).
  • AICAR accumulates intracellularly, and competitively inhibits AMP deaminase, leading to an accumulation of AMP. 
  • The AMP is released and converted extracellularly to adenosine, which is a potent inhibitor of inflammation.
  • As a result, the inflammatory functions of neutrophils, macrophages, dendritic cells, and lymphocytes are suppressed.
Online Reference:
Riksen NP, Barrera P, van den Broek PH, van Riel PL, Smits P, Rongen GA. Methotrexate modulates the kinetics of adenosine in humans in vivo. Ann Rheum Dis. 2006 Apr;65(4):465-70. doi: 10.1136/ard.2005.048637. Epub 2005 Nov 24. PMID: 16308339; PMCID: PMC1798086.

questions.text: Penicillin was being used to treat a patient. He started to look paler, but there was no wheezing, urticaria, or shortness of breath. Investigation revealed that his blood had anti-penicillin antibodies. What kind of hypersensitive reaction did this patient most likely experience?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Type II hypersensitivity
 
  • This is an example of a type II, antibody-mediated hypersensitivity reaction. The paleness points towards Antibody-mediated RBC destruction causing anemia and pallor.
  • Type I hypersensitivity is IgE mediated with the release of mast granules causing wheezing/urticaria/SOB.  
  • Type III Hypersensitivity involves immune complex formation, type IV is cell-mediated in nature (macrophages/T-h1 cells) being the mediators (no antibody formation).




Reference: Jawetz, Melnick & Adelberg's Medical Microbiology, 27th edition, Page no 145.

questions.text: Which gene in the thymus is responsible for self-antigen recognition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1): AIRE
 
  • The gene responsible for self-antigen recognition in the thymus is AIRE (Autoimmune Regulator).
  • AIRE gene plays a crucial role in central tolerance by promoting the expression of a diverse array of tissue-specific antigens (TSAs) within thymic epithelial cells.
  • This allows developing T cells to encounter and recognize self-antigens, leading to the deletion of autoreactive T cells and the development of self-tolerance.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 216.

questions.text: What causes naive T-cell activation?
questions.solution:
While Dendritic cells, Macrophages, and B-lymphocytes - all three are APC(Antigen-presenting cells) - The Naive T-cells get activated predominantly by dendritic cells. They are the most crucial antigen-presenting cells for triggering T-cell responses against protein antigens.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 140.

questions.text: Rheumatoid arthritis is treated with the disease-modifying drug etanercept. What is its mode of operation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option1) Inhibition of TNF alpha

It is a recombinant fusion protein of TNF-receptor with Fc portion of human IgG1 and is administered by s.c injection 50 mg weekly. It binds to and prevents TNFα from activating TNF receptors on the membrane of T-cells/macrophages.

TNF alpha inhibitors memorising trick:

Trick: -
ACE Inhibitor ko Goli maro
A-Adalimumab
C- Certolizumab
E- Eternacept
I-Infliximab
Goli- Golimumab

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 230.

questions.text: Of the following vasculitis, which one does not affect adults?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Kawasaki disease
 
  1. Takayasu arteritis: Takayasu arteritis primarily affects large blood vessels, particularly the aorta and its main branches. It is more common in young adults, especially women.
  2. Susac syndrome: Susac syndrome is a rare autoimmune condition characterized by inflammation and damage to small blood vessels in the brain, retina, and inner ear. It typically affects young women, usually between the ages of 20 and 40.
  3. Henoch-Schonlein purpura: Henoch-Schonlein purpura (HSP) is a systemic vasculitis that affects small blood vessels. It commonly occurs in children, although it can also affect adults. It is characterized by purpura (purple spots on the skin), joint pain, abdominal pain, and kidney involvement.
  4. Kawasaki disease: Kawasaki disease primarily affects children, typically those under the age of 5. It involves inflammation of medium-sized blood vessels throughout the body, including the coronary arteries. It is characterized by symptoms such as prolonged high fever, rash, red eyes, swollen lymph nodes, and changes in the extremities.
Therefore, among the options provided, Kawasaki disease is the vasculitis condition that does not typically affect adults.





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2816.

questions.text: Where are MHC Class II proteins expressed?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) B-cells, dendritic cells and macrophages

  • Class II MHC molecules present antigens derived from extracellular microbes and proteins following their internalization into endosomes or lysosomes. Here, the internalized proteins are proteolytically digested, producing peptides that then associate with class II heterodimers in the vesicles, from which they are transported to the cell surface as stable peptide-MHC complexes.
  • In contrast to class I molecules, class II molecules are mainly expressed on cells that present ingested antigens and respond to T-cell help (macrophages, B lymphocytes, and DCs).
  • Platelets and all nucleated cells have MHC I. 

* Audio Explanation:
 



Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 198.

questions.text: What is the name of the procedure whereby macrophages engulf various cells as seen in the picture?
questions.solution:
• Emperipolesis is the active engulfment of one cell by another, which remains intact. Seen in Rosai Dorfman disease.
  • In contrast to phagocytosis, where the engulfing cell is killed by the protective action of lysosomal enzymes, it exists momentarily within another cell and with an entire normal structure.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathology,10th edition, page no 840.

questions.text: Which drug should be used as the least-resort treatment for a male with insulin-dependent diabetes who has macular edema and develops glaucoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Prostaglandin analogue
 
  • Prostaglandin analogues can potentially worsen diabetic macular edema and is generally not recommended in patients with diabetic retinopathy due to its potential effects on retinal fluid dynamics.
  • Therefore, it would be considered the least appropriate choice for managing glaucoma in this context. Common side effect of prostaglandin analogue is Cystoid Macular edema.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 169.

questions.text: Pick the inflammatory condition has association with HLA-B27 in 90% cases?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Ankylosing spondylitis

Ankylosing spondylitis (AS) is a chronic inflammatory disease that primarily affects the axial skeleton, causing inflammation and progressive stiffness in the spine and sacroiliac joints. HLA-B27 is a specific human leukocyte antigen (HLA) class I gene that is found in approximately 90% of individuals with Ankylosing spondylitis.
 
  • Option 2: Reiter's arthritis (reactive arthritis): Although HLA-B27 is associated with reactive arthritis, the prevalence of HLA-B27 in cases of reactive arthritis is variable and lower than in Ankylosing spondylitis.
  • Option 3: Ormond's disease is a.k.a Idiopathic Retroperitoneal Fibrosis, commonly associated with IgG4 related diseases
  • Option 4: Rheumatoid arthritis: Rheumatoid arthritis is not primarily associated with HLA-B27. Instead, it is associated with another genetic marker called the HLA-DRB1 shared epitope.





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2790, 2793.

questions.text: patient came in with an intermittent fever, no weight loss, and no anorexia, but a retroperitoneal tumor. Results from the peripheral smear were normal. The mass is shown in both gross and microscopical form. What’s the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Castleman’s disease


*Clinical Features:

  1. B symptoms: fever, weight loss, night sweats, fatigue 

  2. Splenomegaly or Hepatomegaly

  3. Fluid accumulation (edema, anasarca, pleural effusion)

* [Extra Edge]: Castleman disease

  1. Castleman disease (CD) is a rare, nonclonal lymphoproliferative disorder having distinct subtypes depending on its etiology, pathology, and clinical presentation. It can affect lymph nodes of any body region, imitating both benign and malignant malformations, including the neck, chest, abdomen, and pelvis.

  2. The hyaline vascular type has an increased number of lymphoid follicles with a broad mantle zone and hypoplastic germinal center. Centrally placed germinal center is surrounded with small lymphocytes arranged in concentric circles, forming an "onion skin-like" structure. The center of these follicles is penetrated by hyalinized capillaries resembling a "lollipop" (also known as the lollipop sign).

  • Histopathologic screening of lymph nodes is done to assess a single node involvement (suggestive of UCD) or a multimode involvement (suggesting MCD) after excluding other infectious, malignant, and autoimmune disorders that exhibit their characteristic features in the lymph nodes. In addition, their characteristic lymph node features are also noted.

  • The lymph node size must be enlarged.

  • IL-6 has proven to be a specific biomarker for this disease, contributing to its pathogenesis, symptomatology, and histopathology. 

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 257.
Online Reference: Ehsan N, Zahra F. Castleman Disease. [Updated 2023 Apr 27]. In: StatPearls [Internet]. Treasure Island (FL): StatPearls Publishing; 2024 Jan-. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK576394/

questions.text: Which of the following contributes to killing caused by antibodies?
questions.solution:
Effector cells that mediate Antibody dependent cell-mediated cytotoxicity include NK Cells, monocytes, macrophages, neutrophils,   eosinophils and dendritic cells.
 
Antibody-dependent cellular cytotoxicity is a different process that can result in antibody-mediated cell death (ADCC).
A number of effector cells, primarily NK cells and macrophages, destroy cells that are coated with IgG antibodies by binding to the largest amount of the Fc fragment of IgG, which results in cell destruction without phagocytosis.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 139.

questions.text: Allopurinol is used to treat:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option  2) Gout
 
  • Allopurinol is a purine antimetabolite and a competitive inhibitor of the xanthine oxidase enzyme.
  • It prevents the conversion of hypoxanthine and xanthine to uric acid reducing plasma uric acid levels.
  • The metabolite of allopurinol called oxypurinol is a non-competitive inhibitor of xanthine oxidase.
  • It is used in the treatment of hyperuricemia in patients with gout and also in patients with haematological malignancies about to undergo chemotherapy.
* [Extra Edge]: Drugs used in Gout

+ Acute gout:
Drugs that relieve inflammation and pain:
  • NSAIDs
  • Colchicine
  • Glucocorticoids

+ Uricosuric drugs- These drugs increase the excretion of uric acid.
  • Probenecid
  • Benzbromarone
  • Lesinurad



Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 233.

questions.text: Which of the following medications is a calcineurin inhibitor?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Cyclosporine
 
  • The immune system's T cells are activated by the calcium and calmodulin-dependent serine/threonine protein phosphatase known as calcineurin.
  • It dephosphorylates the transcription factor nuclear factor of activated T cell, cytoplasmic (NFATc), activating it. The nucleus is where the activated NFATc is translocated after which it increases the expression of IL-2, which in turn derives the development and differentiation of T cells.
  • A class of medications known as calcineurin inhibitors, which includes cyclosporine, pimecrolimus, and tacrolimus, target calcineurin.


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no 937, 939.

questions.text: Without a positive ANA, which of the following conditions is highly unlikely to be the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Drug-induced lupus
 
  • Without a positive ANA, drug-induced lupus cannot be diagnosed.
  • An ANA positive syndrome known as drug-induced lupus is characterized by symptoms including fever, malaise, severe arthralgias/myalgias, serositis, and/or rash.
  • Drug-induced lupus is classically marked by antinuclear and anti-histone antibodies and, in some cases, anti­ double-stranded DNA or perinuclear anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibody (p-ANCA) antibodies.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 229.

questions.text: Which of the following is an immune privilege site?
questions.solution:
Seminiferous tubule of testis is an immune-privileged site.

Immune-privileged sites
  • Due to the tissues' inability to communicate with the blood and lymph, some antigens are hidden (sequestered) from the immune system.
  • Self-antigens in these tissues consequently do not trigger immunological responses and are generally disregarded by the immune system.
  • Such sites are referred to as immune-privileged sites because it is challenging to elicit immune responses in response to antigens injected into them.
  • Eye lens, CNS, and testis are examples of Immune Privileged sites. 
Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 188.

questions.text: Which type of steroid is more potent at the same concentration:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Ointment

 The vehicle is the carrier of the drug, and it depends on the region affected and the type of lesion present. 

* TABLE SHOWING THE DIFFERENT TYPES OF VEHICLES FOR DRUG DELIVERY:-



Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 10.

questions.text: Skin biopsy of an SLE patient shows irregular particulate deposition at the Epidermo-dermal junction after using FITC-labeled human IgG antiserum. It shows the presence of which of the following?
questions.solution:
• A skin biopsy of a Systemic Lupus Erythematous (SLE) patient using Fluorescein Isothiocyanate (FITC) labeled human Immunoglobulin G (IgG) antiserum is used to show the presence of immune complex deposits at the dermo-epidermal junction.
  • In SLE, the body's immune system produces high levels of autoantibodies, and these autoantibodies form immune complexes due to a defective clearance from the circulation. These deposits can be seen as irregular particles at the dermal-epidermal junction using FITC labeled IgG antibodies.
  • These deposits are thought to contribute to the skin symptoms of SLE by activating local inflammatory processes that cause damage to the skin and other organs.


Reference: Fitzpatrick's Dermatology, 9th edition, Page no 1051.

questions.text: Dendritic cells possess:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Both HLA1 and HLA 2
 
  • Class 1 HLA antigens are found on all nucleated cells of the body and platelets as well as platelets.
  • Class 2 HLA antigens are present on the surface of antigen presenting cells. 
Since, dendritic cell is a nucleated as well as an antigen presenting cell, it will have both the classes of HLA antigen. 

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 196.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions exhibit anti-centromere antibodies?
questions.solution:
Anti-centromere antibodies are seen in scleroderma.

The CREST (calcinosis cutis, Raynaud's phenomenon, esophageal dysmotility, sclerodactyly, and telangiectasia) variety of the restricted type of systemic sclerosis is frequently characterized by a chronic course and anticentromere antibodies.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 17th edition, Page no 2089.

questions.text: What is colchicine's mode of action in acute gout?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Leukocytes, lymphocytes inhibition & microtubular inhibitor.
 
  • Colchicine works to treat acute gout by inhibiting neutrophilic migration, which is the movement of white blood cells (neutrophils) to the site of inflammation caused by the accumulation of uric acid crystals in the joint. This inhibition reduces the inflammatory response in the affected area and thus helps to alleviate pain, swelling, and tenderness. 
  • It binds to tubulin and inhibits microtubule polymerization thereby impairing neutrophil chemotaxis and degranulation.
  • Colchicine does not inhibit urate oxidase, xanthine oxidase, or cyclooxygenase, which are enzymes involved in the production of uric acid or inflammation. Allopurinol inhibits Xanthine oxidase while NSAIDs inhibit cyclooxygenase.
  • Colchicine is considered a second-line treatment for acute gout, used when nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) or corticosteroids are ineffective, contraindicated, or not tolerated.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 231.

questions.text: Drug-induced lupus is not observed with:
questions.solution:
Penicillin does not cause drug induced lupus, also known as SLE (Systemic Lupus Erythematosus). 

Drugs causing lupus are associated with Anti-histone antibodies and have equal incidence in males as well as females. 


Drugs causing Drug-induced Lupus are: [Mnemonic- SHIP]
  • Sulphonamides
  • Hydralazine
  • Isoniazid
  • Procainamide etc.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2749.

questions.text: Where are MHC antigens absent?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Erythrocyte

MHC antigens are absent on erythrocytes. 

  • HLA class I antigens (A, B and C) are found on the surface of virtually all nucleated cells and platelets. They are the principal antigens involved in graft rejection and cell-mediated cytolysis.
  • HLA class II antigens are more restricted in distribution, being found only on cells of the immune system- macrophages, dendritic cells, activated T cells, and particularly on B cell
*Audio Explanation:
 


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 198.

questions.text: What purpose does the technique shown in the image serve?
questions.solution:
The given diagram is known as the hybridoma technique for the development of monoclonal antibodies.

A mouse is given an antigen to which B cells in the spleen make antibodies.
These lymphocyte cells (seen as spleen cells in the diagram) are gathered and combined with myeloma cells to form hybridomas.
These hybridomas then divide and produce monoclonal antibodies.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 150.

questions.text: How does colchicine work to treat acute gout?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Inhibits neutrophilic migration
 
  • Colchicine works to treat acute gout by inhibiting neutrophilic migration, which is the movement of white blood cells (neutrophils) to the site of inflammation caused by the accumulation of uric acid crystals in the joint. This inhibition reduces the inflammatory response in the affected area and thus helps to alleviate pain, swelling, and tenderness.
  • Colchicine does not inhibit urate oxidase, xanthine oxidase, or cyclooxygenase, which are enzymes involved in the production of uric acid or inflammation. Allopurinol inhibits Xanthine oxidase while NSAIDs inhibit cyclooxygenase.
  • Colchicine is considered a second-line treatment for acute gout, used when nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) or corticosteroids are ineffective, contraindicated, or not tolerated.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 231.

questions.text: A child was taken for CECT Chest and Post IV Contrast; the child developed swelling which gradually increased. There is numbness; pain on the passive extension of the fingers.  Pulse was present. Next Step?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. Immediate Fasciotomy
 
  • Compartment syndrome is a medical condition caused by excessive pressure within the musculature in a particular area of the body, such as the arm.
  • When contrast medium is injected into an arm, the injection often causes swelling, but if the contrast medium is injected too quickly or in too large of an amount, the excess pressure can lead to compartment syndrome.
  • Symptoms of compartment syndrome can include numbness, pain, and swelling. If not treated quickly, compartment syndrome can lead to permanent nerve or muscle damage.
  • The best treatment for compartment syndrome caused by extravasation of contrast medium is immediate fasciotomy, which is a surgical procedure that relieves the excessive pressure and allows the contrast medium and fluid to be drained.
  • This can offer the patient relief from their symptoms and prevents potentially serious, long-term complications like Volkman's ischemic contracture. 



Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 33.

choices.text: Transduce the signal to T cells following antigen recognition
Present antigens for recognition by T cell antigen receptors

questions.text: What are the functions of Major Histocompatibility Complex-1 and -2?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3): Present antigens for recognition by T cell antigen receptors
 
  • Major Histocompatibility Complex (MHC)-1 molecules present antigens derived from intracellular pathogens to CD8+ T cells.
  • MHC-2 molecules present antigens derived from extracellular pathogens to CD4+ T cells.
  • Transducing the signal to T cells following antigen recognition and enhancing the secretion of cytokines are functions associated with T cell receptors and co-stimulatory molecules, not MHC molecules.
* [Extra Edge]: MHC I Vs MHC II


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 198.

questions.text: What stimulates IFN-beta?
questions.solution:
IFN-beta is stimulated by viral infection.

After being stimulated by viruses or polynucleotides, fibroblast and epithelial cells synthesize beta interferon (IFN-B), formerly known as fibroblast interferon. It is glycoprotein in nature. 
Types of Interferons: •IFN alpha - Leukocyte Interferon, has antiviral activity. •IFN beta - Produced by fibroblasts and epithelial cells, has antiviral activity. •IFN gamma - Produced by T- lymphocytes, has immunomodulatory and anti- proliferative functions.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathology,10th edition, page no 352.

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with Rheumatoid arthritis was on medications. Which drug is responsible to cause blurring vision and corneal opacity post 2 years of medication?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Chloroquine

  • For RA, Chloroquine has to be given for long periods accumulate in tissues (especially melanin containing tissue) and produce toxicity, particularly in the eyes.
  • These include retinopathy, blurred or distorted vision, loss of central vision, Corneal Opacity and difficulty seeing in dim light.
  • In some cases, long-term use of chloroquine can lead to irreversible retinal damage and a condition known as pigmentary maculopathy, which can cause a permanent loss of vision.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 229.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Sjogren's syndrome's is untrue?
questions.solution:
Due to a decrease in the serous component of saliva, Sjogren's syndrome patients have higher concentrations of sodium and IgA. (ductal secretions are unaltered). Due to the fact that phosphate is produced by the gland rather than a duct, the concentration is essentially the same.





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2789, 2790.

questions.text: Which of the given options is the immunological marker of Langerhans cell histiocytosis?
questions.solution:
Correct answer is (Option 1) CD1a

Amongst the given options, CD1a is the immunological marker of LCH (Langerhans cell histiocytosis).
Option 2 CD20 is present on B-Cells.
Option 3 and 4 CD16 and CD56 are present on NK-cells. 

* [Extra Edge]: Langerhans cell Histiocytosis


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 627.

questions.text: Which of the following determines whether an immunoglobin will get secreted or remain membrane bound?
questions.solution:
Alternative splicing—can produce a variety of protein products from a single hnRNA (heterogenous nuclear RNA) sequence (eg, transmembrane vs secreted Ig, tropomyosin variants in muscle, dopamine receptors in the brain, host defense evasion by tumor cells).

 

  • Alternate splicing of the immunoglobulin (Ig) heavy chain gene determines whether the immunoglobulin will be secreted or remain membrane-bound. During B cell development, the splicing mechanism can generate two different forms of the immunoglobulin: a membrane-bound form that is part of the B cell receptor (BCR) and a secreted form that is released into the bloodstream as an antibody.

    The other options are not directly involved in determining whether the immunoglobulin will be secreted or membrane-bound:

    2. Class switching refers to the change in the constant region of the immunoglobulin heavy chain (e.g., switching from IgM to IgG), not whether it is secreted or membrane-bound.

    • 3. Differential RNA Processing is a broader term that could refer to various modifications in RNA, but in this context, alternate splicing specifically controls the secretion or membrane binding.

    • 4. Allelic Exclusion ensures that each B cell produces antibodies from only one allele of the immunoglobulin gene, but it does not affect the secretion vs. membrane-bound decision.

Reference: Harpers Illustrated Biochemistry, 32nd edition, Page no 371.

questions.text: Pick the drug which would prevent motion sickness in a person who is planning to travel by bus.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Promethazine

  • Promethazine is a first-line medication for the prevention and treatment of motion sickness. It is generally effective for preventing nausea and vomiting due to motion. It works by blocking dopamine, a neurotransmitter that helps regulate nausea.
  • It also has antihistamine properties that can help provide relief from symptoms of motion sickness such as dizziness, irritability and headache.
  • In addition, it is a sedative and calming agent, which can help to relieve anxiety associated with motion sickness.
* Other options: 

Option 2 Meclizine- It is also a first generation antihistaminic used in prevention of motion sickness but it is not as effective as promethazine 
Option 3 and 4 They are second generation antihistaminic therefore can't cross BBB and not effective in motion sickness.


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 183.

questions.text: A 27-year-old man complains of low back pain that starts in the morning, is accompanied by stiffness, and lasts for longer than 30 minutes. His chest expansion is likewise constrained upon examination. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Given features suggest a diagnosis of Ankylosing Spondylitis. (Option 4)

Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA) and Ankylosing Spondylitis (AS) manifest differently in people:
 
  • AS tends to onset at a younger age, and is more common among men with a 3:1 ratio, while RA is more common among women and tends to onset later in life after 40-50 years.
  • RA causes peripheral polyarthritis, mainly in hands and feet, while AS affects mainly the spine and sacroiliac joints, with only oligoarthritis in larger joints.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2791-2793.

questions.text: Where are Bence Jones proteins derived from?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3): Gamma Globulins
 
  • Bence Jones proteins are derived from gamma globulins.
  • Bence Jones proteins are abnormal proteins produced by certain plasma cells in individuals with multiple myeloma, a type of blood cancer.
  • They are light chain proteins that can be detected in the urine and are indicative of the presence of multiple myeloma.
Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 872.

choices.text: It mediates  the release of histamine and other chemical mediators
It is the primary antibody involved in allergic reactions
It is involved in anti-parasitic immune responses
May cross the placenta and fix complement

questions.text: Which of the following statements about IgE antibodies is incorrect?
questions.solution:
People who have been exposed to certain antigens in the past and have developed antibodies to it (IgE) may experience an immediate allergic response if re-exposed, known as Immediate or Type I Hypersensitivity. This is a fast-acting immunologic reaction which can happen within minutes following the combination of the antigen and the antibodies to it, bound to mast cells. IgE antibodies do NOT cross the placenta. IgG is the only class of immunoglobulins which can cross the placenta
Ig E has the following features:
•Half-life 1 to 5 days.
•Causes type 1 hypertensivity reaction.
•It is the only heat liable antibody.
•Levels are raised in helminthic infections.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 101.

questions.text: What injection amongst the following was given to a patient of biliary colic which worsened the pain?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Morphine
 
  • Morphine is an opioid drug that is often used to treat pain.
  • In the case of biliary colic, however, morphine can worsen the pain because of the bile duct spasm that can cause constriction of sphincter of oddi and lead to increased billiary pressure to 10 folds, which can lead to an increase in pain. 

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 502.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old man came in with significant pain and edema in his left great toe. On X-ray, a punched out lytic lesion with sclerotic boundaries and overhanging bone edges is evident on the phalanx.
The diagnosis seems to be:
questions.solution:
The given clinical history is suggestive of Gout.

  • Gout is a metabolic disease that most often affects middle- aged to elder men and postmenopausal women.
  • Acute attack typically involves the first metatarso-phalangeal joint (Great toe).

X-ray of feet in gout shows:

  • soft tissue swelling
  • cystic changes
  • well-defined 'punched-out' type lytic lesions with sclerotic margins
  • overhanging bony edges (Martel's sign, G sign or rat-bite erosion).

 



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2863, 2864.

questions.text: Which of these is a condition depicted in flow cytometry?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Hyper IgM syndrome
 
  • The given flow cytometric findings are suggestive of hyper IgM syndrome.
  • This is because B cells are positive for CD-19 on X-axis and negative for CD-40 on Y-axis when compared to normal individual.
  • Lack of CD-40 on the surface of B cells is the cause of hyper IgM syndrome.
  • In this disorder, affected patients have IgM antibodies but are deficient in IgG, IgA, and IgE antibodies.
  • Mature B cells are present, but they are incapable of Ig class switching and affinity maturation, because of a defect in CD4+ helper T cells or an intrinsic B-cell defect.
  • Approximately 70% of individuals with hyper-IgM syndrome have the X-linked form of the disease, caused by mutations in the gene encoding CD40L located on Xq26 that interfere with CD4+ helper T cell function.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 244.

questions.text: Which is the complement complex that attacks cell membrane?
questions.solution:
Membrane attack complex(MAC) formed as the end result of Complement pathways is made up of C5-C9 complement proteins.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 126.

questions.text: Choose the option that best describes a prucalopride-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) 5HT4 Agonist
 
  • Prucalopride, a 5HT4 agonist, increases intestinal motility is licensed for the treatment of chronic constipation in females who are resistant to laxatives. It is also used in GERD and gastroparesis. Most common side effect is diarrhea.
  • Tegaserod, mosapride, and cisapride are further medications in this class.
  • Tegaserod and cisapride are banned due to the possibility of QT prolongation.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 724.

questions.text: A young man with impaired eyesight and a history of recurrent epididymitis complains of painful mouth and glans penis ulcers. Which of the following diagnoses is most likely?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Behcet's disease

Behcet's disease is a chronic relapsing autoimmune disorder characterized by recurrent painful oral ulcerations, penile ulcerations, and visual disturbances, associated with the presence of HLA-B51.

Symptoms typically begin in young individuals, affect both men and women equally, and involve inflammation of both small and large vessels.

International Study Group Criteria for Diagnosis of Behcet Syndrome:





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2817.

questions.text: The options are genes involved in SCID . Identify the exception.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) BTK

BTK (Bruton tyrosine kinase) mutation is seen in Bruton X-linked agammaglobulinemia.

* [Extra Edge]: SCID (Severe combined immunodeficiency)
Both humoral and cell-mediated immunity are defective in SCID
  • X LINKED SCID
Most common and results from a mutation in the gamma chain subunit of cytokine receptors.
This protein is a signal-transducing component of the receptors for IL2, IL4, IL7, IL9, IL11, IL15, and IL 21
  • AUTOSOMAL RECESSIVE SCID
Adenosine deaminase deficiency is the primary cause of AR SCID.
  • Other Causes
  • Recombinase activating gene mutation (RAG)
  • JAK3 intracellular kinase mutation: Important for signal transmission via the cytokine receptor gamma chain.
Remember IL7 Receptor is most commonly mutated in SCID if nothing else is mentioned in the question, it is NOT ADA Defciency, it comes next after IL7R.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 242.

questions.text: Select the complement factor that is a marker of humoral rejection.
questions.solution:
• Deposition of Complement breakdown product "C4d" in allo­grafts is a strong indicator of humoral rejection because C4d is pro­duced during activation of the complement system by the Antibody­ Dependent classical pathway.
  • It also provides the rationale for treating affected patients with B-cell-depleting agents(eg. Rituximab)
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathology,10th edition, page no 237.

questions.text: In which of the following do we use pegloticase-
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Chronic Gout
 
  • Pegloticase is a recombinant mammalian uricase that is covalently attached to methoxy polyethylene glycol (mPEG) to prolong the circulating half-life and diminish immunogenic response.
  • Pegloticase is the newest urate-lowering therapy to be approved for the treatment of refractory chronic gout.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 235.

choices.text: It is a prodrug and converted to Mycophenolic acid

questions.text: Which of the given statements about Mycophenolate Mofetil is false?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Most common adverse effect is Nephrotoxicity

Nephrotoxicity is not the most common adverse effect of Mycophenolate Mofetil (MMF). While MMF can have adverse effects on the kidneys, the most common adverse effects associated with MMF include gastrointestinal symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and abdominal pain.

Rather, MMF+ Glucocorticoid + Sirolimus is a non-nephrotoxic combination used in patients developing renal toxicity with Cyclosporine/ tacrolimus.

Other reported adverse effects include bone marrow suppression, increased risk of infections, and increased susceptibility to malignancies.
The correct information about Mycophenolate Mofetil is:
  1. Used in Transplant rejection: Mycophenolate Mofetil is commonly used as an immunosuppressive medication in organ transplantation to prevent rejection. It inhibits the proliferation of T and B lymphocytes, which are involved in the immune response against the transplanted organ.
  2. It is a prodrug and converted to Mycophenolic acid: Mycophenolate Mofetil is a prodrug that is rapidly and completely converted to its active metabolite, Mycophenolic acid (MPA), in the body. MPA is responsible for the immunosuppressive effects of Mycophenolate Mofetil.
  3. Is not used with Azathioprine: Mycophenolate Mofetil is often used as an alternative to Azathioprine in immunosuppressive regimens, particularly in organ transplantation. But it should not be combined with Azathioprine. These medications have similar mechanisms of action but different side effect profiles, and the choice between them depends on individual patient factors and clinical considerations.


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no 942.

questions.text: Identical twins with following graft:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Isograft
 
  • Graft exchanged between identical twin is isograft
  • Graft exchanged between individuals of same species is allograft
  • graft from one species to another is xenograft
  • Autograft is tissue from patient's own body

Online Reference: Oli AN, Babajide Rowaiye A, Adejumo SA, Anazodo FI, Ahmad R, Sinha S, Haque M, Adnan N. Classic and Current Opinions in Human Organ and Tissue Transplantation. Cureus. 2022 Nov 1;14(11):e30982. doi: 10.7759/cureus.30982. PMID: 36337306; PMCID: PMC9624478.

questions.text: Which of these is not a antigen-presenting cell?
questions.solution:
Antigen-presenting cells (APC)

  • These cells process and present antigens via MHC II to Th-cells. The immune system contains three types of antigen-presenting cells, i.e., macrophages, dendritic cells, and B cells.
  • Langerhans cells are developmentally similar to dendritic cells. M cells express the protease cathepsin E, similar to other antigen-presenting cells.
  • Thymocytes are not antigen-presenting cells.
Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 140.

questions.text: An older woman with migraines who is currently receiving therapy reports recent onset chest pain with no history of angina or MI. Which of the following drugs might have caused this presentation
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) 5HT2 Agonist

Drug 5HT1b/1d agonists like sumatriptan have mechanics of actions causing these presentations.

* 5HT Agonists:
  • Sets off the migraine's vasoconstrictor phase.
  • Takes part in the neurogenic inflammation of the blood vessels
  • Major side effects include Tightness in chest and head, Dizziness, Weakness, Bradycardia, Seizures.
  • Contraindications are Ischemic heart disease, hypertension, epilepsy, hepatic or renal impairment and pregnancy.
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 194.

questions.text:
Which investigation should be carried out next to assist you diagnose the ailment if the patient has cutaneous vasculitis,
glomerulonephritis, and peripheral neuropathy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: ANCA
 
  • ANCA testing (option 1) is the most relevant investigation for the presented clinical scenario.
  • RA factor (option 2) is associated with rheumatoid arthritis and is not specific to the described symptoms.
  • HbsAg (option 3) is a marker for hepatitis B infection and is not directly related to the presented symptoms.
  • MIF (option 4) stands for Macrophage Migration Inhibitory Factor, which is not a specific test for the mentioned symptoms.

ANCA testing is commonly used in the evaluation of vasculitis, specifically in distinguishing between different types of vasculitis. ANCA-associated vasculitis (AAV) is a group of autoimmune disorders that includes granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA), microscopic polyangiitis (MPA), and eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (EGPA). ANCA testing helps in detecting the presence of specific autoantibodies that target neutrophil components and are associated with these types of vasculitis.






Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2803, 2804.

questions.text: 6 years old child presented to OPD with eczematous rash. On evaluation was found to have fever, platelet= 80,000. On enquiring there is h/o multiple hospitalization for recurrent infection. Diagnosis
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Wiskott Aldrich syndrome  
 
  • The presentation of eczematous rash, fever, and thrombocytopenia along with a history of recurrent infections suggests a primary immunodeficiency disorder.
  • Among the options given, the most likely diagnosis in this case is Wiskott Aldrich syndrome (WAS).
  • WAS is an X-linked disorder characterized by thrombocytopenia, eczema, and recurrent infections. It results from mutations in the WAS gene, which plays a role in the function of immune cells. Patients with WAS have defective T and B lymphocyte function, which leads to increased susceptibility to infections.
Option 1 and 2 Chediak Higashi Syndrome and Bruton's agammaglobulinemia may present with recurrent infections, but thrombocytopenia and eczematous rash are not typical features of these disorders.

Option 4 Severe combined immunodeficiency can also present with recurrent infections, but it is usually associated with severe T and B lymphocyte dysfunction leading to severe combined immunodeficiency.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 246.

questions.text: What is Serum sickness?
questions.solution:
• Serum Sickness is an example of a Type III Hypersensitivity reaction.
  • The most common diseases involving a type III hypersensitivity reaction include serum sickness, post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis, systemic lupus erythematosus, farmers' lungs (hypersensitivity pneumonitis), and rheumatoid arthritis.
  • Eg of Type 3 hypersensitivity reaction: Post streptococcus glomerulonephritis, SLE, Polyarteritis nodosa, Reactive arthritis, Serum sickness, Arthur reaction, Farmer's lung, Hypersensitivity pneumonia, Type 2 lepra reaction, Henoch schonlein purpura.


Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 164.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding the medications used to treat gout is correct
A. Aspirin is not used as it decreases the uric acid secretion
B. Diclofenac is used as it concentrates in the joint
C. Indomethacin is used as it acts by multiple pathways
D. Aspirin is used as it is most powerful NSAID
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Statement A, B & C

Gout results from the precipitation of urate crystals in the tissues and the subsequent inflammatory response. Acute gout usually causes painful distal mono arthritis and can cause joint destruction, subcutaneous deposits (tophi), and renal calculi and damage. In most patients with gout, hyperuricemia arises from underexcretion rather than overproduction of urate.
