* The aims of treatment are to:
  • Decrease the symptoms of an acute attack
  • Decrease the risk of recurrent attacks
  • Lower serum urate levels
Statement C Indomethacin is a potent nonselective inhibitor of the COXs. It also inhibits the motility of polymorphonuclear leukocytes, depresses the biosynthesis of mucopolysaccharides, and may have a direct COX-independent vasoconstrictor effect. Indomethacin has prominent anti-inflammatory and analgesic-antipyretic properties like those of the salicylates.
Statement B The drug accumulates in synovial fluid after oral administration, which may explain why its duration of therapeutic effect is considerably longer than its plasma t1/2.
Statement A Aspirin has a bimodal effect on the renal handling of uric acid: High doses of aspirin (>3 g/day) are uricosuric (probably by blocking urate reabsorption), while low dosages (1–2 g/day) cause uric acid retention (probably via inhibiting urate secretion). Low-dose aspirin, indicated for the prophylaxis of cardiovascular events, can cause changes in renal function and uric acid handling in elderly patients.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 33, 842.

questions.text: What is Basiliximab?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: IL-2 receptor antagonist

Basiliximab is a monoclonal antibody that binds specifically to the alpha chain of the IL-2 receptor (CD25) on activated T lymphocytes. By blocking the IL-2 receptor, basiliximab inhibits IL-2 signaling and T-cell activation, which is crucial in the immune response. It is commonly used as an immunosuppressive agent in organ transplantation to prevent acute rejection.

The other options are incorrect:
  1. IL-1 receptor antagonist (anakinra) is a different medication used to block IL-1 signaling and is used in the treatment of certain inflammatory conditions such as rheumatoid arthritis.
  2. Anti-CD3 antibody (muromonab-CD3) is a different medication that targets CD3 antigen on T cells and has been used in the past for immunosuppression in transplant and autoimmune diseases.
  3. TNF inhibitors are a class of medications that specifically target tumor necrosis factor-alpha (TNF-alpha), a pro-inflammatory cytokine involved in various autoimmune diseases such as rheumatoid arthritis, psoriasis, and inflammatory bowel disease. Examples of TNF inhibitors include drugs like adalimumab and infliximab.
Memorizing trick- 
Basiliximab- B is the 2nd letter of English alphabet hence IL-2 


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no 943.

questions.text: Which of the following induces the production of IgE by B cells?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) IL-4

The cytokine that induces the production of IgE by B cells is IL-4. 

  • IL-4 is produced by activated T cells and plays a critical role in the regulation of immune responses, especially in the context of allergic reactions. It is a key cytokine in the differentiation of Th2 cells, which are involved in the production of IgE and the development of allergic responses.
  • IL-4 also induces the expression of CD23, which is the receptor for IgE on B cells, and promotes the survival, proliferation, and differentiation of B cells into IgE-producing plasma cells.
     

Option 1 IL-2 is a cytokine that is mainly involved in the proliferation and differentiation of T cells and natural killer (NK) cells.

Option 3 IL-1 is a proinflammatory cytokine that is involved in the regulation of immune responses, including the activation of T cells and the production of other cytokines.

Option 4 IL-6 is a pleiotropic cytokine that is involved in a wide range of physiological processes, including the regulation of immune responses, hematopoiesis, and inflammation.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 200.

choices.text: Transduce the signal to T-cells following antigen recognition
Present antigens for recognition by T-cell antigen receptors

questions.text: What role does Major Histocompatibility complex-1 and complex-2 play?
questions.solution:
MHC proteins - Their role is in the recognition and presentation of antigens to the immune system. MHC class I (MHC1) - Present on all nucleated cells and platelets - They are responsible for presenting HIV, EBV, and CMV viruses, among others, to our immune system. MHC class II (MHC2) - Present on Antigen-presenting cells - are responsible for presenting pollen, foods, and other foreign proteins to the immune system.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 141.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient who has been using low-dose aspirin for the past six months was diagnosed with rectal haemorrhage. Which of the following substances is likely to be inhibited and cause the bleeding?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Thromboxane A2
 
  • Aspirin is an irreversible inhibitor of the COX (cyclooxygenase enzyme). Aspirin at low doses (75mg) primarily acts by inhibiting cyclooxygenase 1 (COX-1).
  • Low-dose aspirin, used for antiplatelet action, results in selective inhibition of platelet COX-1 (thromboxane synthase) inhibiting its ability to form thromboxane A2 (needed for platelet aggregation).
  • At higher doses, aspirin also inhibits COX-2 and results in decreased production of prostacyclin from endothelium. This may nullify the beneficial anti-aggregatory effect of aspirin.
  • Side effects: Gastric ulceration, tinnitus (CN VIII). Chronic use can lead to acute renal failure, interstitial nephritis, GI bleeding. Risk of Reye syndrome in children treated with aspirin for viral infection. Toxic doses cause respiratory alkalosis early, but transitions to mixed metabolic acidosis-respiratory alkalosis.
* [ Extra Edge ]: Mechanism of Actions 
 

 

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 215.

questions.text: Which of the following is present in rheumatoid arthritis seropositive patients?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: All

Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is a chronic autoimmune disease primarily affecting the joints. Seropositive rheumatoid arthritis refers to the presence of certain autoantibodies, particularly rheumatoid factor (RF) and anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide (anti-CCP) antibodies, in the blood of affected individuals.

In seropositive rheumatoid arthritis, patients typically exhibit the following characteristics:
  1. Multiple joints affected: Rheumatoid arthritis commonly affects multiple joints throughout the body. Small joints of the hands, wrists, and feet are frequently involved, but larger joints can also be affected.
  2. Symmetrical joint symptoms: The joint involvement in rheumatoid arthritis is usually symmetrical, meaning that if a joint on one side of the body is affected, the corresponding joint on the other side will likely be affected as well.
  3. Joint pain and swelling: Joint pain and swelling are hallmark symptoms of rheumatoid arthritis. The affected joints may be tender, warm to the touch, and show signs of inflammation.

Here's a table listing the common patterns of joint involvement in Rheumatoid Arthritis (RA):

 



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2751, 2752, 2759.

questions.text: Pick the diagnosis in the kid of A 5 years old child presented to the clinic with h/o of recurrent infections. O/e the child had rashes as shown below. Routine blood investigations revealed the patient had low platelets.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Wiskott Aldrich syndrome

  • Wiskott Aldrich Syndrome (WAS) is a rare X-linked recessive disorder caused by mutations in the WAS Protein Gene.
  • The syndrome is characterized by recurrent infections, eczema, and thrombocytopenia (low platelet count).
     
  • Patients are also at risk for autoimmunity, allergies, and malignancy. WAS is usually diagnosed in infancy, but it can be diagnosed in later life in rare cases.
  • The diagnosis is made with the use of laboratory tests, physical exams, and examining family histories.
  • Treatment typically involves managing infection risk with antibiotics, managing eczema with topical steroids and other treatments, and managing thrombocytopenia with platelet transfusions and/or immunomodulatory medications. Bone marrow transplantation may also be an option for some patients.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 246.

questions.text: What is opsonin?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2:  C3b

Opsonin is an antibody or other substance which binds to foreign microorganisms or cells making them more susceptible to phagocytosis.
C3b is known to be the best opsonizer.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 124.

questions.text: Which medication from the list below is not used to treat rheumatoid arthritis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Febuxostat

Febuxostat, a nonpurine selective xanthine oxidase inhibitor, which is used to treat hyperuricemia and has fewer hypersensitivity reactions than allopurinol in lowering blood uric acid level in patients with hyperuricemia and gout.

Option 1, 2 and 4 Etanercept, leflunomide, and methotrexate are commonly used in the management of rheumatoid arthritis.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 235.

questions.text: Plasmapheresis is not used in:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Cholinergic crisis 
 
Plasmapheresis, also known as therapeutic plasma exchange, is a procedure in which plasma is separated from the blood and replaced with a substitution fluid. It is used as a therapeutic intervention in various conditions involving autoimmune or immune-mediated processes.

Plasmapheresis is commonly used in the following conditions:
 
  1. Myasthenic crisis: Plasmapheresis can be used as a treatment for acute exacerbations of myasthenia gravis when there is respiratory muscle weakness or significant bulbar involvement.
  2. Guillain-Barré syndrome: Plasmapheresis is an effective treatment option for severe cases of Guillain-Barré syndrome to remove circulating autoantibodies and inflammatory mediators.
  3. Polymyositis: Plasmapheresis may be considered in select cases of severe, refractory polymyositis, especially when associated with significant muscle weakness or respiratory compromise.
 
  • However, plasmapheresis is not typically indicated in Cholinergic crisis.
  • It is not due to antibodies formation. 
  • Cholinergic crisis is an acute exacerbation of symptoms in patients with myasthenia gravis due to excessive cholinesterase inhibitor medication (such as pyridostigmine) intake.
  • The management of Cholinergic crisis involves reducing or stopping the cholinesterase inhibitor medication and providing supportive care.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3514, 3515.

choices.text: Type IV hypersensitivity - epitheloid cells, giant cells, macrophages

questions.text: A patient who arrives at the hospital has had a cough and low-grade fever for the past two weeks. An X-ray of the chest revealed caseous necrosis in the lung's apex. What is the disease's underlying mechanism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Type IV hypersensitivity - epithelioid cells, giant cells, macrophages 
 

  • The given clinical history (low grade fever, cough for 2 weeks) is suggestive of TB infection of lung, caused due to inhalation of Mycobacterium Tuberculosis.
  • The inhaled organism activate cell mediated immunity (type 4 hypersensitivity) resulting in the formation of an epithelioid granuloma with central caseous necrosis.
  • Granuloma is composed of slipper shaped cells called epithelioid cells; multinucleated giant cells called Langhan’s Giant cell with a central area of necrosis.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 212.

questions.text: Xenograft resistance in naked mice is not present due to the lack of
questions.solution:
Nude mice are not resistant to xenograft due to absence of T cell. A xenograft is a tissue graft or organ transplant form a donor of a different species.

Nude mice lack body hair hence the name. They lack a thymus and thus cannot generate mature T-lymphocytes. The absence of T-lymphocytes makes them unable to mount adaptive immune responses requiring helper T-cells and cytotoxic T-cells. The absence of functioning T-cells also prevents the rejection of allografts and xenografts.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathology,10th edition, page no 217.

questions.text: Of the following, which one is not a second-generation antihistamine?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Cyclizine

Cyclizine is a first generation antihistaminic and cetirizine, loratadine and fexofenadine are second generation antihistaminic.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 179.

questions.text: Antiphospholipid Antibody (APLA) syndrome is not associated with:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Bleeding disorders
 
  • APLA syndrome is an autoimmune disorder characterized by the presence of antiphospholipid antibodies in the blood, which can lead to an increased risk of thrombotic (clotting) events and pregnancy complications.
 
  • The main clinical manifestations of APLA syndrome include thrombotic disorders such as deep vein thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, stroke, and arterial thrombosis. It is also associated with pregnancy complications, including recurrent fetal loss, pre-eclampsia, and intrauterine growth restriction.
 
  • While bleeding can occur in some cases of APLA syndrome, it is not a typical feature of the condition. In fact, APLA syndrome is primarily characterized by a prothrombotic (increased clotting) state rather than a bleeding disorder.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2749, 2750.

questions.text: After being stung by a bee, a patient develops anaphylaxis. Identify the antibody that is causing this reaction.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) IgE

  • The given history is suggestive of a Type I hypersensitivity reaction to a bee sting. It is mediated by Ig E antibody.
  • Type I hypersensitivity involves immunoglobulin E (IgE) mediated release of antibodies against the soluble antigen.
  • This results in mast cell degranulation and release of histamine and other inflammatory mediators.
  • Most immediate hypersensitivity (Type I) disorders are caused by excessive Th2 responses, and these cells play a central role by stimulating IgE production and promoting inflammation.
  • When a mast cell armed with IgE antibodies previously produced in response to an antigen is exposed to the same antigen, the cell is activated, leading to the release of an arsenal of powerful mediators that are responsible for immediate hypersensitivity reactions.
  • Systemic anaphylaxis is characterized by vascular shock, widespread edema, and difficulty in breathing. It may occur in sensitized individuals in hospital settings after administration of foreign proteins (e.g., antisera), hormones, enzymes, polysaccharides, and drugs (e.g., the antibiotic penicillin), or in the community setting following exposure to food allergens (e.g., peanuts, shellfish) or insect toxins (e.g., those in bee venom).

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 205.

choices.text: Proximal domains of alpha and beta subunit
Distal domains of alpha and beta subunit

questions.text: For the purpose of delivering processed antigen to CD8 T lymphocytes, the peptide binding site on class I MHC molecules is produced by:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Distal domain of alpha subunit MHC 1 molecule is made of Alpha1,2,3 and Beta 2 microglobulin. Alpha 1 and 2 form peptide binding groove in which peptides of endogenous antigens connect with CD8 cytotoxic T Lymphocytes. MHC is found in all nucleated cells, APCs and Platelets (except RBCs).


Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 141.

questions.text: The following Prostaglandin causes both vasodilatation and vasoconstriction:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) PGF2α

Among the four types of prostaglandins mentioned in the question, PGF2α is the only one that causes both vasodilatation and vasoconstriction.
  • PGF2α is produced by the smooth muscle cells of blood vessels and has a potent vasoconstrictive effect. This means that it causes the blood vessels to narrow, which increases the resistance to blood flow and raises blood pressure.
  • However, PGF2α also has a vasodilatory effect on certain blood vessels, such as those in the coronary arteries and the uterus. This means that it causes these blood vessels to relax and widen, which increases blood flow to these areas.
Option 1 PGE2 is primarily a vasodilator, which means that it causes blood vessels to relax and widen.
Option 3 PGI2 (prostacyclin) is a potent vasodilator and inhibitor of platelet aggregation.
Option 4 Thromboxane A2, on the other hand, is a potent vasoconstrictor and platelet aggregator.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 200.

questions.text: The following statement about Antiphospholipid antibody syndrome (APLAb) is false:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Single titer anticardiolipin is diagnostic 

Single titer anticardiolipin is not diagnostic for Antiphospholipid Antibody Syndrome (APLA syndrome). The diagnosis of APLA syndrome requires the presence of persistent antiphospholipid antibodies (such as anticardiolipin antibodies, lupus anticoagulant, or anti-beta-2 glycoprotein I antibodies) on at least two occasions, at least 12 weeks apart.

The other options are true:
     2.  APLA syndrome commonly presents with recurrent fetal loss, which is one of the hallmark features of the  condition.
  1. APLA syndrome may cause pulmonary hypertension as a result of thrombotic events in the pulmonary arteries.
  2. Warfarin is often used as a treatment for APLA syndrome, particularly in patients with thrombotic events, to prevent further clot formation. Other anticoagulant medications may also be used depending on the individual's specific situation.



 

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2750.

choices.text: Anti-CTLA-4 Antibody is being used in the treatment of cancer in advanced stage
Mutation of tumor suppressor genes decreases the antigen toxicity
PD-1 and PD-1L activation leading to tumor suppression
Binding of CD28 leads to immune tolerance

questions.text:
Which of the following statements about immune surveillance is correct
 1. Anti-CTLA-4 Antibody is being used in the treatment of cancer in advanced stage
 2. Mutation of tumor suppressor genes decreases the antigen toxicity
 3. PD-1 and PD-1L activation leading to tumor suppression
 4. Binding of CD28 leads to immune tolerance
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Anti-CTLA-4 Antibody is being used in the treatment of cancer in advanced stage
 
  • Anti CTLA-4 antibody is a new modality, used in treatment of cancers, particularly in advanced stages.
  • Mutation of tumor suppressor gene will increase the antigen toxicity.
  • PD-1 and PD-1L inhibition leads to tumor suppression Binding of CD-28 leads to inhibition of immune tolerance.
  • Binding of CD28 leads to immune tolerance: CD28 binding provides costimulatory signals that promote T cell activation, not tolerance.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 313.

questions.text: Mention the class of antibody shown in the immunoglobulin structure.
questions.solution:
Immunoglobulin A (IgA) is a type of antibody found in the secretions of the body such as saliva, tears, respiratory and intestinal mucosal secretions. IgA is a dimer, consisting of two monomers joined together by a J-chain. There are two subclasses of IgA, IgA1, found predominately in serum, and IgA2, found predominantly in the body secretions. Due to its secretory component, IgA is effective at mediating local or mucosal immunity, meaning it can protect against infection on the mucosal surface like in the digestive or respiratory system. IgA is the most abundant antibody found in the human body and is therefore important in protecting against infections.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 99.

questions.text: Which biological agent for rheumatoid arthritis is a JAK inhibitor?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Tofacitinib
 
  • Tofacitinib is a novel, oral JAK inhibitor which will inhibit the JAK-STAT pathway responsible for the production of cytokines and chemokines.
  • It is a new synthetic drug approved for severe cases of RA that are not responding to Methotrexate. Tofacitinib can be used alone or concurrently with Methotrexate, but should not be combined with azathioprine, cyclosporine or biological DMARDs.
  • It has been approved for the treatment of psoriatic arthritis and is also used in rheumatoid arthritis and ulcerative colitis.
Option 1 Etanercept is a recombinant fusion protein of TNF-receptor with Fc portion of human IgG1. It binds to and prevents TNFα from activating TNF receptors on the membrane of T-cells/macrophages.
Option 2 Tocilizumab, an IL-6 receptor antagonist, is FDA-approved for treatment of rheumatoid arthritis and systemic juvenile idiopathic arthritis, giant cell arteritis, polyarticular juvenile idiopathic arthritis, and cytokine release syndrome.
Option 3 Abatacept is a recombinant fusion protein which combines part of Fc domain of human IgG with extracellular domain of T-cell inhibitory receptor CTLA4. It is approved for moderate-severe active RA not responding to Mtx. It can be combined with Mtx and other DMARDs, but not with TNFα antagonists due to greatly increased risk of infections.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 229.

questions.text: The following statement about Guillain Barre Syndrome (GBS) is false:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Sensory level
 
  • Guillain-Barre Syndrome typically presents with ascending paralysis, starting from the lower extremities and progressing upwards. It is characterized by flaccid paralysis, meaning there is loss of muscle tone and weakness.
  • Sensory symptoms such as paresthesias (abnormal sensations) and numbness can also occur in GBS.
  • Additionally, GBS is associated with a characteristic CSF laboratory finding known as albumino cytological dissociation, which refers to elevated protein levels in the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) without a corresponding increase in white blood cell count.
  • But there is NO sensory level in GBS


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3501-3503.

questions.text: What causes affinity maturation?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Somatic hypermutation

Affinity maturation is due to somatic hypermutation.
Helper T cells also stimulate the production of antibodies with high affinities for the antigen. This process, called affinity maturation, improves the quality of the humoral immune response.

* [Extra Edge]: Affinity development
i. The process by which B cells create antibodies with higher antigen specificities during an immune response.
ii. Compared to an initial reaction, a secondary response has the potential to produce antibodies with higher affinity.
iii. Takes place in secondary lymphoid organs' germinal centers.
iv. Takes place in 2 interconnected processes:
  • Somatic Hypermutation (SHM), which causes mutations in the immunoglobulin genes variable regions.
  • Clonal Selection in which somatically hypermutated B cells struggle for scarce growth resources, including the presence of antigen.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 203.

choices.text: resides in the epithelial layer of mucosa.

questions.text: Identify the function/correct option about gamma-delta T-cells from the following options-
questions.solution:
5–10% of the T cells in circulation are gamma-delta T cells, located in epithelial surfaces. They have gamma-delta heterodimer receptors, which have limited diversity and can identify phospholipid antigens, as opposed to helper and cytotoxic T cells, which have alpha-beta heterodimer receptors.
  • They differ from the conventional alpha-beta T cells by the fact that they do not require antigen processing and MHC presentation of peptides
  • They are part of innate immunity as the gamma-delta receptors exhibit limited diversity for the antigens.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 136.

questions.text: Which of the following antihistamines has the least sedative effect?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Chlorpheniramine 
 
  • Chlorpheniramine is an antihistamine that is commonly used to treat allergic conditions such as hay fever, allergic rhinitis, and hives.
  • Chlorpheniramine is considered to have a relatively low sedative effect compared to some other antihistamine.
  • Chlorpheniramine has a relatively lower ability to cross the blood-brain barrier compared to other antihistamines like Diphenhydramine or Promethazine. This is believed to be the reason why Chlorpheniramine is associated with less sedation.
Option1, 2 and 3 Drugs are high or moderately sedating compounds as they cross BBB easily.  



Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 180.

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in the AIDS-related complex?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Ectopic pregnancy
 
  • AIDS-related complex (ARC) refers to a condition characterized by symptoms and signs that are less severe than those seen in full-blown AIDS (Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome).
  • It is considered an earlier stage of HIV infection. The features typically seen in ARC include recurrent infections, generalized lymphadenopathy, chronic diarrhea, weight loss, fever, fatigue, and night sweats.
  • Ectopic pregnancy is a separate medical condition unrelated to the immune status of an individual. Therefore, is not included in the AIDS-related complex.





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1527, 1540-1543.

questions.text: What causes a type 4 hypersensitivity reaction?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Cell-mediated

Type IV hypersensitivity is also known as cell-mediated hypersensitivity because it is the result of the interaction of T lymphocytes and the specific antigen to which they have been sensitized.

Other options: -
  • Antibodies mediated is Type II HSN reaction 
  • Immune complex mediated is Type III HSN reaction 

* [Extra Edge]: Mechanisms of T cell mediated cytotoxicity
 
  • Cytokine-mediated inflammation: CD4+ T cells are activated by exposure to a protein antigen and differentiate into Th1 and Th17 effector cells. Subsequent exposure to the antigen results in the secretion of cytokines. IFN-γ activates macrophages to produce substances that cause tissue damage and promote fibrosis, and IL-17 and other cytokines recruit leukocytes, thus promoting inflammation. The classical T cell–mediated inflammatory reaction is DTH.
  • T cell–mediated cytotoxicity: CD8+ cytotoxic T lymphocytes (CTLs) specific for an antigen recognize cells expressing the target antigen and kill these cells. CD8+ T cells also secrete IFN-γ.
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 212.

questions.text: Mast cells are activated by?
questions.solution:
Mast cells are activated by the cross-linking of high-affinity IgE receptors, as are their circulating counterparts, basophils.
Mast cells can also be activated by a variety of different factors, such as complements C5a and C3a, which work by binding to receptors on the mast cell membrane and are known as anaphylatoxins because they generate reactions that resemble anaphylaxis.

Some chemokines, such as IL-8, as well as medications like codeine and morphine, adenosine, and melittin (found in bee venom), are additional mast cell secretagogues.

Molecules/Cytokines functioning as Mast cell secretagogues
  • C3a
  • C5a
  • IL- 8
  • Codeine
  • Morphine
  • Adenosine
Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 100.

questions.text:
How is Buprenorphine classified?
1. Partial agonist at \(\mu\) receptor 
2. Partial agonist at \(\kappa\) receptors
3. Full agonist at \(\mu\) receptor 
4. Full agonist at \(\kappa\) receptors
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Partial agonist at μ receptors

Buprenorphine is a partial μ agonist and an antagonist at δ and κ receptors. It is used as an analgesic and in the management of opioid dependence. It does not have an effect on the neuronal uptake of serotonin so is not implicated in causing serotonin syndrome. 

* [Extra Edge]: Opioids
All opioid agonist-antagonists are µ antagonists and k agonists, except buprenorphine and dezocine. Buprenorphine and dezocine are partial agonists at the μ receptor.



Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 508.

questions.text: Which of the subsequent investigations needs to be carried out right away in order to most effectively confirm a non-matched blood transfusion reaction?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Direct Coomb's test
 
  • A non-matched blood transfusion reaction occurs when there is a mismatch between the recipient's blood type and the donor blood type. In this situation, the recipient's immune system may produce antibodies against the donor blood cells.
 
  • The Direct Coomb's test is used to detect these antibodies that have attached to the patient's own red blood cells. It helps confirm the presence of immune-mediated hemolysis, which is a characteristic feature of a non-matched blood transfusion reaction.





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 893.

questions.text: Which is the very first chemical barrier that microorganisms encounter for a commonly exposed body surface?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Acidic pH
 
  • First chemical barrier encountered by microorganism for common exposed surfaces of the body is acidic pH.
  • All surfaces of the body, which come in contact with the external environment, are equipped with mechanical and chemical barriers to prevent penetration by microorganisms.
  • Secretions of sebaceous glands contain both saturated and unsaturated fatty acids that kill bacteria and fungi.
  • The sebaceous secretions also have a low pH that inhibits bacterial growth.
Online Reference: Janeway CA Jr, Travers P, Walport M, et al. Immunobiology: The Immune System in Health and Disease. 5th edition. New York: Garland Science; 2001. The front line of host defense. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK27105/

questions.text: The delayed hypersensitive reaction is caused by what type of cell or mediator
questions.solution:
In type IV Hypersensitivity reactions, Antigen-presenting cells activate Th1/cytotoxic T cells. T-cells then recruit macrophages and release inflammatory cytokines.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 169.

questions.text: What is not true about serotonin syndrome ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 3) Dantrolene is the drug of choice

Serotonin syndrome occurs due to the combined side effects with any drug that increases serum serotonin levels like MAOIs (monoamine oxidase inhibitors), SSRIs (selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors), SNRIs (serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitors), TCAs (tricyclic antidepressants), tramadol, ondansetron, triptans, linezolid, MDMA (amphetamine), dextromethorphan, etc.

* Serotonin syndrome – TRIAD:
  • Autonomic instability - hyperthermia, hypertension, tachycardia, diaphoresis, vomiting, diarrhea.
  • Altered mental status - agitation, confusion, delirium.
  • Neuromuscular hyperactivity - tremor, hyperreflexia, myoclonus.
* Cyproheptadine is the drug of choice in serotonin syndrome.

Option 3 Dantrolene reduces spasticity in upper motor neuron disorders, hemiplegia, paraplegia, cerebral palsy and multiple sclerosis. 
Used I.V. it is the drug of choice for malignant hyperthermia which is due to persistent release of Ca2+ from sarcoplasmic reticulum (induced by fluorinated anesthetics and Succinylcholine in genetically susceptible individuals with abnormal RyR1).

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 488.

questions.text: Bence Jones proteinuria is observed in:
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Gamma heavy chain disease
 
  • Bence Jones proteins are found in urine of a patient with Multiple Myeloma. 
  • There are several subtypes of multiple myeloma.
  • The most common is IgG kappa subtype, which has IgG as heavy chain i.e Gamma heavy chain and Kappa as Light chain. So the answer is 2.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 867, 872.

questions.text: What causes hyperacute rejection?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Preformed antibodies
 
  • Hyperacute rejection is mediated by preformed antibodies specific for antigens on graft endothelial cells.
  • The preformed antibodies may be natural IgM antibodies specific for blood group antigens or may be antibodies specific for allogeneic MHC molecules that were induced by prior exposure of the organ recipient to allogeneic cells through blood transfusions, pregnancy, or transplantation of another organ.
        
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 235.

questions.text:
What cell mediators are involved in the Type 1 hypersensitivity reaction
i. Mast cell
ii. Histamine
iii. Prostaglandins
iv. Neutrophils
questions.solution:
Mast Cells, histamine, and Prostaglandins are involved in Type I hypersensitivity reaction.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 166.

questions.text: Which of the statements is not true about 'Aprepitant' ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Agonist at Neurokinin receptor (NK1) 
 
  • Aprepitant is a neurokinin receptor antagonist that is used treatment of cytotoxic (chemotherapy) drug-induced vomiting. It is the doc of late onset chemotherapy induced nausea and vomiting.
  • It works by blocking the action of substance P, a neurotransmitter that plays a role in triggering nausea and vomiting.
  • Aprepitant is known to cross the blood-brain barrier, which allows it to exert its effects centrally in the brain.
  • It is metabolized primarily by the CyP3A4 pathway in the liver.
  • The primary therapeutic use of Aprepitant is to ameliorate the nausea and vomiting associated with chemotherapy regimens.
* [Extra Edge]: Mechanism of Action



Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 718.

questions.text: Which type of cells is prominently prevalent in joints of rheumatoid arthritis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Macrophages
 
  • Macrophages are responsible for engulfing and destroying foreign invaders, such as bacteria and viruses. 
  • In rheumatoid arthritis, macrophages are activated and become overactive. They produce inflammatory chemicals that damage the lining of the joints, leading to pain, swelling, and stiffness.
  • B cells, T cytotoxic cells, and dendritic cells are also involved in the immune response to rheumatoid arthritis, but they are not as prominently prevalent in the joints as macrophages





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2755-2757.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male patient has swollen tonsils, a sore throat, lymphadenopathy, and hepatosplenomegaly. The following image depicts the removed tonsil's histological features. What is the responsible organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) EBV
 
  • The histological features of swollen tonsils, sore throat, lymphadenopathy, and hepatosplenomegaly suggest infectious mononucleosis, which is caused by the Epstein-Barr virus (EBV).
  • The image provided shows characteristic histological findings of infectious mononucleosis, including hyperplastic germinal centers, infiltrating lymphocytes, and reactive lymphoid follicles.
  • EBV is a member of the herpesvirus family and is transmitted through saliva, making it a common cause of infectious mononucleosis.
  • The virus infects B cells, leading to their proliferation and subsequent immune response, resulting in the clinical presentation observed in the patient.
* [Extra Edge]: Epstein-Barr virus (EBV)

  • EBV is a ubiquitous herpesvirus implicated in the pathogenesis of Burkitt lymphomas, B-cell lymphomas in patients with T-cell immunosuppression (HIV infection, transplant recipients), and several other cancers.
  • The EBV genome harbors several genes encoding proteins that trigger B-cell signaling pathways; in concert, these signals are potent inducers of B-cell growth and transformation.
  • In the absence of T-cell immunity, EBV-infected B cells can rapidly “grow out” as aggressive B-cell tumors.
  • In the presence of normal T-cell immunity, a small fraction of infected patients develops EBV-positive B-cell tumors (Burkitt lymphoma, Hodgkin lymphoma) or carcinomas (e.g., nasopharyngeal carcinoma).
Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 357.

questions.text: Which of the following is the basis for the Paul-Bunnel test?
questions.solution:
Heterophile antibodies are antibodies directed against external antigens which cross react with self antigens.

In Paul - Bunnell test, heterophile antibodies in the patient’s blood sample is made to react with sheep, horse or cow red blood cell antigens. This works on the principle of latex agglutination reaction.

Paul - Bunnell test was used for the diagnosis of infectious mononucleosis by Ebstein - Barr Virus (EBV).

In patients with IMN, there is production of heterophile antibodies.

Other examples of Heterophile antibodies: -

  • Weil-Felix test
  • Monospot test
  • Cold Agglutination test 


Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 92.

questions.text: The drug Pegloticase is used to treat which of the following diseases
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. Chronic tophaceous gout
 
  • Pegloticase is a biologic therapy specifically for the treatment of chronic gout in adults who have not responded to traditional therapy.
  • It works by breaking down the urate crystals in the joints that cause gout pain and stiffness.
  • Pegloticase was approved by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration in September 2010.
  • Pegloticase is administered as an intravenous (IV) infusion every two weeks and is gradually broken down by the body over two to three days.
  • It reduces the levels of excess uric acid in the blood, allowing the body to dissolve or flush out the urate crystals that have built up in the joints over time. This helps reduce pain, swelling and stiffness associated with gout.
  • It can also help to improve mobility and range of motion by decreasing inflammation of the joints.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2865.

questions.text: Michaelis-Gutmann bodies can be seen in the following:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Malakoplakia
 
  • Michaelis-Gutmann bodies are intracellular basophilic inclusion bodies that can be observed in the cytoplasm of certain cells in specific conditions.
  • The presence of Michaelis-Gutmann bodies is most commonly associated with malakoplakia, a rare chronic inflammatory condition typically affecting the genitourinary tract.
  • Malakoplakia is characterized by the accumulation of macrophages with defective bacterial killing mechanisms, leading to the formation of basophilic inclusion bodies called Michaelis-Gutmann bodies. These bodies consist of undigested bacteria and calcium salts.
  • Michaelis-Gutmann bodies can also be seen in other conditions such as chronic granulomatous disease and Crohn's disease.
Other options: - 
  • Xanthogranulomatous cystitis- foam cells found
  • LCH- Birbeck granules are found
  • Tuberculosis- Caseous granuloma seen 


Fig: Malakoplakia

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 956.

questions.text: \(\gamma\delta\)-T cell is associated with:
questions.solution:
T cells that are mature and have a population that is small have a TCR that is of a different kind and consists of gamma and delta polypeptide chains. This gamma delta TCR is able to identify peptides, lipids and small molecules, not needing any assistance of MHC's proteins.

This type of T cell has a tendency to group together on epithelial surfaces, like skin, gastrointestinal and urinary mucosa, suggesting they serve as guard against organisms that try to enter by means of epithelial membranes. Nonetheless, the specificities of gamma delta T cells are yet to be figured out.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 136.

questions.text: The deformity shown in the given image occurs in which of the following
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Rheumatoid arthritis
 
  • The Swan neck deformity is a type of deformity that occurs in the hands and fingers in people with rheumatoid arthritis.
  • It is characterized by flexion of the proximal interphalangeal joints and extension of the metacarpophalangeal joints, giving the fingers a curved, “swan-like” appearance.
  • The deformity can cause difficulty with activities that require finger movement and strength, such as grasping and pinching. The picture shows this deformity in its classic form.

Hand deformities in RA:





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2751, 2752.

questions.text: The presence of_____characterises Langerhans cell histiocytosis.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Linear grooves in the nuclei 
 
  • LCH is typically positive for CD1a, S100, and CD207(Langerin). 
  • It's characterized by cells having vacuolated abundant pale eosinophilic cytoplasm containing linear groves on the nucleus and the presence of Birbeck granules. 
  • CD15 positivity is seen in Hodgkin's Lymphoma. 
* [Extra Edge]: Langerhans cell Histiocytosis


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 627.

questions.text:
There was a brucellosis suspicion regarding a patient. A sample of serum was sent for a routine agglutination test. When the sample was diluted, the test result changed from negative to positive.
What might have caused the original negative test results?
questions.solution:
Antibody overproduction occurs in the prozone. Due to their modest size, the immunological complexes generated in this zone are challenging to find. IgG, IgA, and IgM antibodies are discovered using the Standard Agglutination Test. 48 hours are spent incubating the sample at 37 degrees Celsius.
A titre of 1:160 or higher is regarded as important. Prozone phenomenon and the presence of insufficient or blocking antibodies are both associated with false negative SAT.


Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 111.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis when patient comes with H/O arthritis with involvement of PIP and DIP and 1 MCP with sparing of wrist and ankle joints
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Osteoarthritis
  • OA typically affects proximal and distal interphalangeal joints, first carpometacarpal (CMC) joints, hips, knees, first metatarsophalangeal joints, and joints of the lower cervical and lumbar spine.
 
  • OA can be monoarticular or polyarticular in the presentation. Joints can be at different stages of disease progression.
 
  • Classic physical exam findings in hand OA include Heberden’s nodes (posterolateral swellings of DIP joints), Bouchard’s nodes (posterolateral swellings of PIP joints), and “squaring” at the base of the thumb (first CMC joints).




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2855, 2858, 2859.

questions.text: Which is the most common/frequently seen antibodies in Antiphospholipid Syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4): Anti-beta 2 glycoprotein antibody 
 
  • Antiphospholipid syndrome (APS) is an autoimmune disorder characterized by the presence of antiphospholipid antibodies (aPL) and a predisposition to thrombotic events.
  • The most commonly detected antibodies in APS are anti-beta 2 glycoprotein antibodies.
  • Anti-beta 2 glycoprotein antibodies target beta 2 glycoprotein I, a protein that binds to phospholipids on cell surfaces, including those on platelets and endothelial cells.
  • Other commonly seen antibodies in APS include anticardiolipin antibodies and lupus anticoagulant.
  • APS is an autoimmune disorder characterized by:

    1. Presence of one or more antiphospholipid (aPL) autoantibodies
    2. Venous or arterial thromboses, or pregnancy complications such as recurrent miscarriages, unexplained fetal death, and premature birth.
     

* [Extra Edge]: Autoantibodies 


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 128.

questions.text: Identify the conjugated antibody in the following figure:
questions.solution:
In the given figure, the antibody numbered 1 is the conjugate antibody.
 
The figure shows a molecular investigation technique which is used for the detection of the antibody marked 2. Since the antibody 1, is attached to the primary antibody (marked 2), it is known as the secondary or conjugated antibody with which a conjugated enzyme is attached. This conjugated enzyme is used to form an end product which can be easily detected. In this manner, the levels of Antibody 2 are measured indirectly.
Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 116.

questions.text:
Woman with morning stiffness that gradually goes away over the course of an hour. Which of the following is true regarding the treatment and findings?
a. NSAIDS improve symptoms and are having disease modifying activity
b. Absence of erosion on X ray rules out diagnosis
c. Raised ESR and CRP
d. HLA DR4 is related with prognosis
questions.solution:
The patient is most probably suffering from Rheumatoid Arthritis.

Raised ESR and CRP and relation of HLA DR4 with prognosis are true statements.

Investigations which can be done:
  • Elevated CRP and ESR - Non specific
  • Serum IgM RF has been found in 70-80%
  • Rheumatoid factor
  • Anti CCP
  • Synovial fluid analysis
NSAIDS only help in pain relief they are not DMARDs
Initially there is no erosion, first clinical sign on x ray is periarticular osteopenia. 


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2754, 2759-2761.

questions.text: Which is an exception to an autoimmune disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 4) Sickle Cell Disease
 
  • Sickle cell disease is not an autoimmune disease, but a genetic disorder characterized by the presence of abnormal hemoglobin (hemoglobin S) within red blood cells, inherited in an autosomal recessive manner.
  • Autoimmune diseases result from an abnormal immune response directed against self-antigens, leading to tissue damage and inflammation.
  • In contrast, sickle cell disease is caused by a mutation in the beta-globin gene, leading to the production of abnormal hemoglobin and the formation of sickle-shaped red blood cells.
* [Extra Edge]: Autoimmune Disease


Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathological basis of disease, 10th edition, Page No 641.

questions.text: What does the process of phagocytosis by polymorphonuclear leukocytes involve after the binding of complement and antibodies to the surface of encapsulated bacteria?
questions.solution:
After binding of complement and antibody on the surface of encapsulated bacteria, the process of phagocytosis by polymorphonuclear leukocytes involves C3b and Fc. One of the most efficient ways of enhancing the phagocytosis of particles is coating the particles with IgG antibodies specific for the particles, which are then recognized by the high-affinity Fc receptor of phagocytes.
Components of the complement system, like fragments of the complement protein C3, are also potent opsonins.(C3b)

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 177.

choices.text: Tenosynovitis of extensor tendon of MCP joints
Post traumatic dystrophy with Complex regional pain syndrome

questions.text: A woman presents with pain, swelling and redness of knee joint and hand. There were associated complaints of morning stiffness with problem in squatting. The swelling spared the DIP joints. The image of the patient's hands is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This individual is likely suffering from Rheumatoid arthritis due to the presence of pain, swelling, and redness in both the knee and hand joints, as well as early morning stiffness and difficulty squatting that does not affect the DIP joints.
 
  • The presenting symptoms of RA typically result from inflammation of the joints, tendons, and bursae. Patients often complain of early morning joint stiffness lasting >1 hour that eases with physical activity.
  • The wrists and metacarpophalangeal (MCP) and proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints stand out as the most frequently involved joints
  • Distal interphalangeal (DIP) joint involvement may occur in RA, but it is rare and usually is a manifestation of coexistent osteoarthritis.






Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2751, 2752.

questions.text: Necrotizing lymphadenitis is characteristically seen in:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Kikuchi disease 
 
  • Necrotizing lymphadenitis, also known as Kikuchi disease or histiocytic necrotizing lymphadenitis, is a rare benign condition that primarily affects young adults.
  • It is characterized by tender, enlarged lymph nodes, most commonly in the cervical region.
  • Histologically, Kikuchi disease is characterized by necrotizing lymphadenitis with karyorrhexis (fragmentation of the cell nucleus) and abundant histiocytes.
  • The exact etiology of Kikuchi disease is unknown, but it is believed to involve a dysregulated immune response, possibly triggered by viral infections.
  • Kikuchi disease is usually self-limiting, and treatment is supportive.
Option 1 Kimura disease: A rare chronic inflammatory disorder that primarily affects the lymph nodes and soft tissues. It is characterized by painless subcutaneous nodules, lymphadenopathy (especially in the head and neck region), and increased eosinophil levels in the blood.

Option 3 Hodgkin's disease (Hodgkin lymphoma): A type of lymphoma characterized by the presence of Reed-Sternberg cells in the lymph nodes. It typically presents as painless, rubbery lymph node enlargement, commonly in the neck, armpits, or groin. Other symptoms may include fever, night sweats, weight loss, and generalized itching.

Option 4 Castleman disease (also known as angio follicular lymph node hyperplasia): A rare lymphoproliferative disorder that affects the lymph nodes. It can manifest as unicentric or multicentric disease. Unicentric Castleman disease involves a single lymph node region, while multicentric Castleman disease involves multiple lymph node regions and can be associated with systemic symptoms like fever, fatigue, and weight loss.

Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 1364.

questions.text: Which of the following characteristics does not apply to both "T cells" and "B cells"?
questions.solution:
Positive selection during development is a feature not shared between T-cells and B-cells.

During the course of development B-cells undergo negative selection while T-cells undergo both positive and negative selection.

Class I MHC is present in both T cells and B cells have additionally Class II MHC. Both have antigen specific receptors. 

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 131.

questions.text:
A 50 yr old male had been complaining of fatigue for a year. Evaluation revealed severe splenomegaly and moderate an++aemia.
Neutrophils make up 60% of the blood, whereas basophils and eosinophils make up 4%, 6%, and 15% of the lymphocytes, respectively. In PBS, Myeloblasts, myelocytes, metamyelocytes, and bands were also seen. The M:E ratio is 18:1. What investigation is the most sensitive?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2: FISH with PCR.
 
  • The patient's clinical presentation, including severe splenomegaly, moderate anemia, abnormal blood cell differentials, and an elevated M:E ratio of 18:1, strongly suggests Chronic myeloid leukemia.
 
  • FISH with PCR is a molecular cytogenetic technique used to detect specific chromosomal abnormalities or genetic mutations associated with myeloproliferative neoplasms.
Plan of action : -
Acute Leukemia - Bone Marrow Aspiration 
CML - FISH
CLL- Flow cytometry 



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 820, 821.

questions.text:
Which is the most common complement component deficiency?
1. C1
2. C2
3. C3
4. C4
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: C2

The most common complement deficiency is c2. It is seen in 1 in 10,000 to 1 in 20,000 patients. It is often associated with IgG deficiency.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 128.

questions.text: The fingertips of a female patient feel numb. Her skin was tighter on her face. A positive ANA result was obtained. The nucleolar pattern was seen using immunofluorescence. Which diagnosis is more likely?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Systemic sclerosis
 
  • The condition is known as Systemic sclerosis (SS). This indicates that it is an autoimmune disease in which the body is attacked by the immune system. The immune system wrongly believes it to be a foreign material or illness, which causes healthy tissue to be destroyed. Many autoimmune illnesses exist that can impact various body systems.
  • Scleroderma patients frequently have a nucleolar pattern of ANA staining.
  • This patient also has Raynaud's phenomenon.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2772, 2776.

questions.text: Identify the example of Type-II hypersensitivity.
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Myasthenia gravis

Type 2 hypersensitivity reaction refers to an antibody-mediated immune reaction in which antibodies (IgG or IgM) are directed against cellular or extracellular matrix antigens, resulting in cellular destruction, functional loss, or tissue damage. In myasthenia gravis, antibodies are produced against the neuromuscular junction.
Atopic asthma- Type 1
Contact dermatitis- Type 4
Arthus reaction- Type 3

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 165.

questions.text: A triad of eosinophilia, asymmetric mono neuritis multiplex, and skin lesions are observed in:
questions.solution:
Patients with Churg-Strauss syndrome often present with similar nonspecific symptoms, a severe asthmatic attack, mononeuritis multiplex in up to 72%, allergic rhinitis and/or sinusitis in up to 61%, heart disease in 14%, and a triad of skin lesions, asymmetric mononeuritis multiplex and eosinophilia in 51%.
 
  • The characteristic laboratory finding in virtually all patients with eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (Churg-Strauss) is a striking eosinophilia, which reaches levels >1000 cells/μL in >80% of patients.
  • Mononeuritis multiplex is the second most common manifestation and occurs in up to 72% of patients.
  • Skin lesions occur in ~51% of patients and include purpura in addition to cutaneous and subcutaneous nodules.

Other manifestations include less common and less severe renal disease compared to granulomatosis with polyangitis and microscopic polyangitis.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2810.

questions.text: What do we call the sort of immunity to a specific infectious agent that comes after recovery from that infection?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Active adaptive immunity
Adaptive immunity is a type of immune response that is specific to a particular pathogen.
  • Active adaptive immunity refers to the immune response that develops after an individual is exposed to a pathogen and recovers from the resulting infection. During this process, the immune system produces memory cells that "remember" the pathogen and can mount a rapid and effective response if the individual is exposed to the same pathogen again in the future.
  • It involves the activation of lymphocytes, such as B cells and T cells, which recognize and respond to specific antigens on the surface of the pathogen.
  • This type of immunity is acquired over time, either through natural exposure to a pathogen or through vaccination.
  • This is why individuals who have had certain infections, such as chickenpox or measles, are typically immune to those diseases for the rest of their lives.
  • Passive adaptive immunity, on the other hand, refers to the transfer of pre-formed antibodies or immune cells from one individual to another. This type of immunity is typically short-lived and does not involve the activation of the recipient's own immune system. An example of passive adaptive immunity is the transfer of maternal antibodies to a developing fetus during pregnancy.
  • Innate immunity, both active and passive, is the first line of defense against pathogens and is not specific to a particular pathogen. It includes physical barriers, such as the skin and mucous membranes, as well as cellular and molecular components of the immune system that recognize and respond to common features of pathogens.
    Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 83.

questions.text:
A young child has an itchy, hyperpigmented plaque with exudation on the back of the knee and elbow flexural, as illustrated.
What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Atopic dermatitis
 
  • Psoriasis primarily affects the extensor side, whereas hyperpigmented plaque with exudation covering flexural aspects of the elbow and knee in a youngster indicates Atopic dermatitis. 
  • A chronic, excruciatingly itchy skin disorder with blisters called dermatitis herpetiformis is linked to gluten-sensitive enteropathy. Erythematous papules and vesicles collected together at extensor locations are characteristic lesions. 
  • Pemphigus - Initial lesions are easily ruptured superficial vesicles and bullae that leave shallow erosions covered with crust and dried serum.




Reference: Fitzpatrick's Dermatology, 9th edition, Page no 364, 365.

questions.text: Which of the following does not use labelled antibody?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Haemagglutination

Except for haemagglutination, all other tests use labelled antibodies. Hemagglutination is a reaction that causes clumping of red blood cells in the presence of some enveloped viruses, such as the influenza virus. A glycoprotein on the viral surface, namely hemagglutinin, interacts with red blood cells, leading to the clumping of red blood cells and the formation of a lattice.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 112.

questions.text: What are the most common symptoms of a child with dermatomyositis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Gottron papules
 
  • Gottron papules are a type of rash that is characteristic rash of dermatomyositis. They are raised, red or violaceous, and scaly lesions that typically appear on the knuckles, elbows, and knees.


 
  • Other common symptoms of dermatomyositis:




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2820.

questions.text: Vaccines are not prepared using:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Antiserum

Antiserum is a blood serum that contains antibodies against an antigen. This is not used in the preparation of vaccines.
Example is Anti Snake Venom(ASV).

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 85.

questions.text: What is the preferred treatment for Kawasaki illness?
questions.solution:
Treatment of choice of Kawasaki disease is Intravenous immunoglobulin (IVIg).
 
  • Kawasaki disease causes swelling (inflammation) in children in the walls of small to medium-sized blood vessels that carry blood throughout the body. Kawasaki disease commonly leads to inflammation of the coronary arteries.
 
  • High-dose IV γ-globulin (2 g/kg as a single infusion over 10 h) together with aspirin (100 mg/kg/d for 14 days followed by 3–5 mg/kg per day for several weeks) has been shown to be effective in reducing the prevalence of coronary artery abnormalities when administered early in the course of the disease.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2816.

questions.text: Which of the following characteristics does T cells and B cells not share?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Positive Selection During Development

In positive selection, T cells in the thymus that binds moderately to MHC complexes receive survival signals. However, T cells whose TCRs bind too strongly to MHC complexes, and will likely be self-reactive, are killed in the process of negative selection. This property is not shown by B cells.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 131.

questions.text: Which of the following antibiotics is the most specific for the diagnosis of rheumatoid arthritis?
questions.solution:
• Anti-CCP antibodies are the most specific blood test for the diagnosis of rheumatoid arthritis.
  • It is a chronic systemic inflammatory disease characterized by persistent involvement of synovial membrane of multiple joints and variety of systemic manifestations.
  • The presence of serum anti-CCP antibodies has about the same sensitivity as serum RF for the diagnosis of RA. However, its diagnostic specificity approaches 95%, so a positive test for anti-CCP antibodies in the setting of an early inflammatory arthritis is useful for distinguishing RA from other forms of arthritis.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2759.

questions.text: A child who has bacterial sinopulmonary infections on multiple occasions with polysacchride rich capsules Which of the following immunoglobulin subclass deficiencies is most likely to result in these infections?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: IgA + IgG2
  • Low levels of IgA can be seen with deficiencies of one or more IgG subclasses mostly IgG2. Infections by encapsulated bacteria (Hemophilus influenza and Streptococcus pneumoniae) are seen here which present as recurrent sinopulmonary infections.
  • IgA + IgG2 deficiency is the most likely immunoglobulin subclass deficiency to result in bacterial sinopulmonary infections with polysaccharide-rich capsules.
  • IgA is the primary immunoglobulin found in mucosal secretions and is important in preventing infections at mucosal surfaces.
  • IgG1 and IgG3 are important in opsonization and complement activation, which are important mechanisms for clearing bacterial infections. IgG2 is important for opsonization and complement activation against encapsulated bacteria.
  • Polysaccharide capsules are a virulence factor used by bacteria to evade the immune system.
  • The antibodies against these capsules are primarily IgA and IgG2.
  • Therefore, a deficiency in both IgA and IgG2 would make a person more susceptible to bacterial infections with polysaccharide-rich capsules, such as Streptococcus pneumoniae.
  • In summary, a child with bacterial sinopulmonary infections on multiple occasions with polysaccharide-rich capsules is most likely to have an IgA + IgG2 deficiency.
Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 100.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents with non-blanching macules and papules on the skin. A skin biopsy revealed a perivascular IgA deposition. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Presence of non-blanching palpable purpura (vasculitis of skin) and colicky abdominal pain (vasculitis of gastrointestinal tract) in a five-year-old child together with evidence of lgA deposition in immune complexes suggests the diagnosis of Henoch Scholein Purpura. HSP is a systemic vasculitis syndrome involving small and medium size vessels.

Pathogenesis and clinical feature: 
  • The presumptive pathogenic mechanism for IgA (Henoch-Schönlein) vasculitis is immune-complex deposition.
  • In pediatric patients, palpable purpura is seen in virtually all patients; most patients develop polyarthralgias in the absence of frank arthritis. Gastrointestinal involvement, which is seen in almost 70% of pediatric patients

Diagnosis: 
  • The diagnosis of IgA vasculitis (Henoch-Schönlein) is based on clinical signs and symptoms.
  • Skin biopsy specimen can be useful in confirming leukocytoclastic vasculitis with IgA and C3 deposition by immunofluorescence.
  • Renal biopsy is rarely needed for diagnosis but may provide prognostic information in some patients.

DIF of skin 


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2814.

questions.text: A child who has polysaccharide-rich capsulated bacterial sinopulmonary infections on multiple occasions. Which of the following immunoglobulin subclass deficiencies has to be specifically looked into?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: IgG2
  • IgG2 infections are most commonly associated with capsulated organisms such as H. influenza. These present as recurrent sinopulmonary infections.
  • IgG2 deficiency needs to be specifically looked into in a child who has polysaccharide-rich capsulated bacterial sinopulmonary infections on multiple occasions.
  • IgG2 is an important immunoglobulin subclass that plays a crucial role in the defense against bacterial infections, particularly those caused by encapsulated bacteria such as Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae, and Neisseria meningitidis.
  • These bacteria have polysaccharide capsules that protect them from phagocytosis by macrophages and neutrophils.
  • However, IgG2 can recognize and bind to these capsules, facilitating opsonization and phagocytosis by immune cells.
  • Therefore, a deficiency in IgG2 can lead to recurrent infections with these bacteria.
  • On the other hand, deficiencies in IgA and IgG1 are associated with recurrent respiratory and gastrointestinal infections, but not specifically with polysaccharide-rich capsulated bacterial sinopulmonary infections.
  • IgD deficiency is very rare and is not known to cause recurrent infections.
Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 175.

questions.text: A man with a 6-month history of recurrent oral ulceration has a yellowish ulceration on his lip that is erythematous with a central halo and nodular lesions on his shin. What ailment does he most likely have?
questions.solution:
• Diagnosis of a patient who presents with a 6-month history of recurrent oral ulceration, yellowish ulcerations on the lip, erythematous , with a central halo and nodular lesions on shin is Behcet's disease.
  • It is chronic multisystem relapsing vascular inflammatory disease (vasculitis) of unknown origin.
 
  • The most common symptoms are associated with mucocutaneous tissues. Oral ulcers are seen in virtually all patients and are commonly the first manifestation. Commonly, like ordinary cancer sores, they are usually multiple. They last around 10 days but recur unless treated. Only the uncommon, major ulcers tend to scar.
 
  • Genital ulcers are the most specific lesions, most commonly occurring on the scrotum or labia. They are larger and deeper and take longer to heal than oral ulcers and tend to form scars.

Behcet's disease has a clinical triad of:
  1. Oral ulcers
  2. Genital ulcers
  3. Arthritis


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2817, 2818.

questions.text: A foundational idea behind vaccination is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Immunologic Memory 

Vaccinations take advantage of memory lymphocyte development by artificially generating active immunity, a process called immunization. During a vaccination, the antigen of a pathogen is introduced into the body and stimulates the immune system to develop specific immunity against that pathogen. It doesn’t cause the disease that the pathogen brings because the vaccine uses an attenuated form of the pathogen that contains the same antigen but doesn’t have the capacity for replication.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 85.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding polymyositis is false?
questions.solution:
The following statement is not true about polymyositis: Ophthalmoplegia
 
  • Polymyositis usually mimics other myopathies and involvement of extra-ocular and facial muscles rules out polymyositis.
  • Both DM and PM are associated with paraneoplastic syndrome.
  • EMG of weak muscles shows increased insertional and spontaneous activity in the form of positive sharp waves and fibrillation potentials, or complex repetitive discharges.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2819, 2821.

questions.text: Except for_______, all of the following tests include Heterophile agglutination.
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Rose-Waaler test

The Waaler Rose test is a slide hemagglutination method for the qualitative and semi-quantitative detection of RF in human serum. Stabilized sheep erythrocytes sensitized with rabbit IgG anti-sheep erythrocytes are agglutinated when mixed with samples containing RF.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 92.

questions.text: Which of the following describes a temporal arteritis feature?
questions.solution:
Giant cell arteritis among following is a feature of temporal arteritis.
 
  • Giant cell arteritis, historically referred to as temporal arteritis, is an inflammation of medium- and large-sized arteries.
  • It characteristically involves one or more branches of the carotid artery, particularly the temporal artery.
  • However, it is a systemic disease that can involve arteries in multiple locations, particularly the aorta and its main branches.
  • Clinical features include- Headache, Jaw claudication, Amarausis fugax. 


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2811.

questions.text: Which of the following immunoglobulins is a pentamer?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4:  Ig M 

IgM is a pentamer. It forms groups of five in solution.
Other options- IgA - Dimer
IgD - Monomer
IgG - Monomer

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 106.

choices.text: X-ray of cervical area of neck in flexion and extension

questions.text: A patient of rheumatoid arthritis develops sudden onset quadriparesis, Babinski sign was positive, increased muscle tone of limbs with exaggerated tendon jerks and worsening of gait with no sensory, sphincter involvement. The best initial investigation is:
questions.solution:
The initial investigation is X-ray of cervical area of neck in flexion and extension.

 
  • The next inquiry to be performed in rheumatoid arthritis patients with compressive myelopathy or neurological dysfunction is an X-ray of the cervical area of the neck in flexion and extension
  • However, the best investigation to diagnose Compressive myelopathy is MRI Spinal cord with or without contrast.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2759, 3450.

questions.text: A 26-year-old woman was seen with a history of dysphonia, dysphagia, impaired vision, and growing limb weakening. The patient's chest X-ray displays the following picture. The most likely finding is:
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2: Thymoma.
 
  • The chest X-ray shows a mass in the anterior mediastinum, which is the area of the chest between the lungs. This is a common finding in thymomas, which are tumors that arise from the thymus gland.
  • Thymomas can cause various symptoms such as dysphonia, dysphagia, impaired vision, and limb weakness.





Reference: Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, 7th edition, Page no 70, 71.
Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 992.

choices.text: Infection with campylobacter jejuni is the most common cause
Typically there is an areflexic ascending paralysis
Most common cranial nerve involved is optic nerve causing blindness

questions.text: The following statement is not correct regarding  Guillain-Barre syndrome:
questions.solution:
Correct option is 4: Most common cranial nerve involved is optic nerve causing blindness.

Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS) is an autoimmune disorder that affects the peripheral nervous system. 
  • Typical presentation: Progressive weakness and areflexic ascending paralysis that typically starts in the legs and ascends to the arms and trunk. 
  • Most common cause: Infection with Campylobacter jejuni.
  • Complications: Respiratory failure may occur due to muscle weakness affecting breathing.
Optic nerve involvement causing blindness is NOT a common feature of GBS. GBS involves lower brainstem cranial nerves like, VII, IX, X etc.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3501, 3502.

questions.text: The following is not a clinical feature of CREST syndrome in scleroderma:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Butterfly rash on face 

CREST is the most common form of limited scleroderma, which means that it affects the skin and internal organs, but not the lungs or heart.

It includes:
  • C- Calcinosis cutis
  • R- Raynaud's phenomenon
  • E- Esophageal dysmotility (causing Dysphagia, GERD)
  • S- Sclerodactyly (causing Claw fingers)
  • T- Telengiectasia

CREST is a subset of scleroderma. It is an acronym for the following clinical features:



However, a butterfly rash on the face is not a characteristic feature of scleroderma. Butterfly rash (malar rash) is typically associated with Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2771, 2778.

questions.text: MALToma is positive for the following marker:
questions.solution:
Correct option is 4: CD 20.
 
  • MALTomas are low-grade B-cell lymphomas that typically arise in the stomach.
  • They are positive for pan B cell markers such as CD19, CD20 ,CD 22 ,CD79a marker, which is a surface protein that is found on a subset of B cells.
  • Negative for CD5,CD10,CD23.





Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 777.

questions.text: Treatment of choice in acute Sarcoidosis is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Prednisolone
 
  • Sarcoidosis is a chronic inflammatory disease that forms granulomas in various organs.
  • Acute sarcoidosis is a severe form of sarcoidosis with symptoms like fever, cough, and chest pain.
  • Prednisolone is the treatment of choice for acute sarcoidosis, as it suppresses the immune response and reduces inflammation.
  • Other treatments for severe cases include cyclophosphamide, methotrexate, and infliximab.

Sarcoidosis treatment :





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2835.

questions.text: HBV vaccination is indicated by which of the following serum markers?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Anti-HBs
 
  • Anti-HBs: Indicates successful response to hepatitis B vaccine, providing protection against the virus.
  • HBsAg: Present in blood of individuals with active hepatitis B infection.
  • Anti-HBcIgM: Signals recent hepatitis B infection, present for a few months after infection.
  • Anti-HBc IgG: Indicates past hepatitis B infection, remains in the blood for many years after recovery.






Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2576.

questions.text: Haloperidol (5 mg) was initiated as a treatment for schizophrenia in a young male patient. He arrived at the hospital with his father on the third day, his eyes rolling upward. There were no signs of spasticity or other abnormalities after a thorough neurological evaluation. It was discovered that visual acuity was normal. The most likely conclusion is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 1) Acute dystonia

The clinical scenario in question describes Oculogyric crisis.

* Oculogyric Crisis
Oculogyric crisis (OGC) is the name of a dystonic reaction to certain drugs (mostly antidopaminergic drugs like Haloperidol) characterized by a prolonged involuntary upward deviation of the eyes. It's a type of acute dystonia.



* Audio Explanation:


Reference: Goodman & Gilman’s the Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 14th edition, Page No 366.

questions.text: A schizophrenic patient with agitation and violent behaviour was being treated with haloperidol. He became rigid after that and couldn't even move his eyes. Which medication should be included in his intravenous therapy for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. Promethazine
 
  • Rigidity and inability to move eyes after haloperidol use in a patient of Schizophrenia is highly suggestive of Acute muscular dystonia.
  • Treatment with IM anticholinergic (benztropine) or IV/IM antihistaminic (diphenhydramine, Promethazine hydrochloride) almost always relieves the symptoms
  • Promethazine is a first-generation antihistamine with anticholinergic and sedative properties. It is commonly used to treat nausea, vomiting, and motion sickness, but it can also be used to manage acute dystonia caused by antipsychotic medications.
  • Promethazine works by blocking dopamine receptors in the brain, which helps to alleviate the muscle spasms and rigidity associated with acute dystonia.


Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 782.

questions.text: Which of the following medications has no effect on DNA synthesis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer is (Option 2) Linezolid
 
  • Linezolid inhibits protein synthesis by attaching to the 50S subunit and preventing the initiation complex formation.
  • Nitrofurantoin acts by damaging bacterial DNA.
  • Metronidazole acts by forming toxic free radicals that damage DNA.
  • Rifampin acts by inhibiting the DNA-dependent RNA polymerase.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page No 807.

questions.text: A 30-year-old pregnant woman arrives at a clinic with 2 weeks of decreased sleep, increased appetite, and hyperactivity. A manic episode diagnosis is made.
